LG.HEAD: (1) (Proem)
LG.L: THe double sorwe of Troylus to tellen.
That was þe kyng Priamus sone of Troye.
In louynge how hise Auentures fellen.
Fro wo to wele and after out of Ioye.
MY purpos is er þat I parte froye.
Thesiphone þow helpe me for tendite.
This woful vers! þat wepen as I write.

LG.HEAD: (2) (Invocation)
LG.L: To þe clepe I þow goddesse of torment.
Thow cruel furie sorwyng euere yn peyne.
Help me that am the sorwful Instrument.
That helpeth louers as I kan to pleyne.
For wel sit it the sothe for to seyne.
A woful wight to han a drery feere.
And to a sorwful tale / a sory cheere.
For I þat god of loues seruauntȝ serue.
Ne dar to loue for myn vnliklynesse.
Preyen for speed al sholde I. þerfor sterue.
So fer am [I] fro his help in derknesse.
But natheles if þis may don gladnesse.
Vn to ony louere and his cause auayle.
Haue he my þank / and myn be his trauayle.
But ye loueres þat baþen in gladnesse.
If ony drope of pite in yow be.
Remembre yow on passed heuynesse.
That ye han felt. and on þe aduersite.
Of other fok. and þenketh how þat ye.
Han felt þat loue dorst yow displese.
Or ye han wonne hym with to gret an ese.
And preyeth for hem þat ben yn the cas.
Of Troylus. as ye may after here.
That loue hym brynge yn heuene to solas.
And ek for me preyeth to god so dere.
That I haue myght to shewe in som manere.
Swych peyne and wo. as loues. folk endure.
In Troylus vnsely auenture.
And byddeth ek for hem þat ben desespeyred.
In loue / þat neuere nyl recouered be.
And ek for hem þat falsely ben apeyred.
Thorugh wykked tonges be it he or she.
Thus biddeth god for his benignite.
So graunte hem soone out of þis world to pace.
That ben desespeyred out of loues grace.
And biddeth ek for hem that ben at ese.
That god hem graunte ay goode perseueraunce.
And sende hem myght hire loues for to plese,
That it to loue / be worship and plesaunce.
For so hope I my soule best auaunce.
To preye for hem þat loues seruauntȝ be.
And write hire wo / and lyue in charite.
And for to haue of hem compassioun.
As þough I were here owene broþer deere.
Now herkeneth with a goode entencioun.
For now wol I gon streyght to my matere.
In whiche ye may the double sorwes here.
Of Troylus in louyng of Criseyde.
And how that she forsok him er she deyde.

LG.HEAD: (9 (Story)
LG.L: YT is wel wist how þat the Grekes stronge.
In armes with a þousand shippes went.
To Troyewardes / and þe Cite longe.
Assegeden neigh ten yer er þei stente.
And in diuerse wyse and oon entente.
The raueshyng to wreken of Eleyne.
By Parys don þei wroughten al hire peyne.
Now fil it so þat in þe toun þer was.
Dwellyng a lord of gret auctorite.
A gret Deuyn þat cleped was Calkas.
That in science so expert was þat he.
Knew wel þat Troye sholde destroyed be.
By answere of his god þat high þus.
Daun Phebus or Apollo Delphebus.
So whanne this Calkas knew by Calkulynge.
And ek by answere of this Appollo.
That Grekes sholden swych a peple brynge.
Thorugh which þat Troye moste ben for-do.
He caste anoon out of þe town to go.
For wel wyst he by sort þat Troye sholde.
Destroyed ben ye wolde who-so nolde.
For which for to departen softely.
Took purpos ful þis forknowyng wyse.
And to þe Grekes ost ful pryely.
He stal a noon / and þey in curteys wyse.
Hym deden bothen worship and seruyse.
In trust þat he hath konnyng hem to rede.
In euery peril which þat is to drede.
The noyse vp ros whanne it was first aspied.
Thorugh al þe town / and generally was spoken.
That Calkas traytor fals fled was and allyed.
With hem of Grece / and casten to ben wroken.
On hym þat falsly hadde his feith so broken.
And seyden he and al his kyn at onys.
Ben worthi for to brennen fel and bones.
Now hadde Calkas left in þis meschaunce.
Al vnwist of þis fals and wikked dede.
His douhter which þat was in gret penaunce.
For of hire lyf sche was ful sore in drede.
As she þat nyst what was best to rede.
For bothe a wydowe was she and allone.
Of ony frend to whom she dorst make hire mone.
Criseyde was þis lady name al right.
As to my dome in al Troyes cyte.
Nas noon so faire for-passyng euery wyght.
So angelyk was here natyf beaute.
That lyk a þing inmortal semed she.
As doth an heuenysh parfit creature.
That down were sent in scornyng of nature.
This lady which þat alday herde at ere.
Hire fadres shame / his falsnesse / and tresoun.
wel nygh out of here wit for sorwe and fere.
In widewes habit large of samyt broun.
On knees she fil byforn Ector a doun.
with pitous voys and tendrely wepynge.
His mercy bad / here selue excusynge.
Now was þis Ector pitous of nature.
And saw þat she was sorwfully bigon.
And þat she was so fair a creature.
Of his goodnesse he gladed her anoon.
And seyde lat youre fadres treson gon.
Forth with mischaunce / and ye youre self in Ioye.
Dwelleth with vs whil yow good lyst in Troye.
And al thonour þat men may don yow haue.
As ferforth as youre fader dwelled here.
Ye shul han and youre body shal men saue.
As fer as I may ought enquere or here.
And she hym þonked with ful humble chere.
And ofter wolde and it hadde ben his wylle.
and toke hire leue home / and held hire stille.
And in hire hous she abod with swych meyne.
As to hire honour nede was to holde.
And whil she dwelled yn þat Cite.
Kept here estat. and bothe of yong and olde.
Ful wel beloued / and wel men of here tolde.
But wheþer þat sche hadde children or noon.
I rede it nought / þerfore I late it goon.
The þinges fellen as þei don of werre.
Bitwixen hem of Troye and Grekes ofte.
For som day boughten they of Troye it derre.
And ofte þe Grekes founden no thing softe.
The folk of Troye and þus fortune on lofte.
And wonder ofte gan hem to weylen bothe.
After hire cours / ay whil þei were wroþe.
But how þis toun com to destruccion̄.
Ne falleth nought to purpos me to telle.
For it were a long disgression̄.
Fro my matere and yow to longe to dwelle.
But the Troiane gestes as þei felle.
In Omer of yn Dares or in Dite.
who-so þat kan may rede hem as þei write.
But þough þat Grekes hem of Troye shetten.
And hire Cite bisegede al a boute.
Hire old vsage wolde þei not letten.
As for to honoure hire goddes ful deuoute.
But aldermost yn honour out of doute.
Thei hadde a relyk hight Palladion.
That was hire tryst a bouen euerichon.
And so bifeɫɫ whan come was þe tyme.
Of Aperil whan cloþed is þe mede.
with newe grene of lusti ver þe pryme.
And swoot smellen floures white and rede.
In sondry wyses shewed as I rede.
The folk of Troye hire obseruaunces olde.
Palladions feste for to holde.
And to þe temple yn al here goodly best wyse.
In general þere went many a wight.
To herkenen of Palladion þe seruyse.
And namely so many a lusti knyght.
So many a lady fresch and mayden bright.
Ful wel arayed bothe meene meste and leste.
Ye boþe for the seson and for þe feste.
Among þese oþere folk was Criseyda.
In widewes habite blak but naþeles.
Right as oure first lettre is now an .a.
In beaute first so stode she makeles.
Hire goodly lokyng gladede al þe prees.
Nas neuere yet þing seyn to ben presed derre.
Nor vnder cloud blak / so bright a sterre.
As was Criseyde as folk seyde euerichone.
That here bihelden yn here blake wede.
And yet she stood ful lowe and stille allone.
Byhynden oþere folk / in litel brede.
And neigh þe dore / ay vnder shames drede.
Symple of a-tyr / and debonaire of chere.
with ful assuryd lokyng and manere.
This Troilus as he was wont to gyde.
His yonge knyghtes ladde hem vp and doun.
In þilke large temple on euery syde.
Byholdyng ay þe ladyes of þe toun.
Now here now þere for no deuocioun.
Hadde he to noon to reuen hym his reste.
But gan to preyse and lakken whom hym leste.
And yn his walk ful fast he gan to wayten.
If knyght or squyer of his companie.
Gan for to sike or lete his eien beyten.
On ony woman þat he koude aspye.
He wolde smyle and holden it folye.
And sey hym þus god wot she slepeth softe.
For loue of þe whan þou tornest ofte.
I haue herd told pardieux of youre lyuynge.
Ye louers / and youre obseruaunces.
And swych labour as folk han yn wynnynge.
Of loue / and yn þe kepyng which doutaunces.
And whan youre preye is lost woo and penaunces.
O. verrey loues nice and blynde be ye.
Ther nys not oon kan war by oþer be.
And with þat word he gan cast vp þe browe.
Ascaunces lo is þis nought wysly spoken.
At which þe god of loue gan to loken rowe.
Right for despit. and shop for to ben wroken.
And kyd a-noon his bowe nas not broken.
Ful sodeynly he hit hym at þe fulle.
And yet as proud a pekok can he pulle.
O blynd world .o. blynd entencion̄.
How ofte falleth al þeffect contraire.
Of Suriquidrie and foul presumpcion̄.
For caught is proud and caught is debonaire.
This Troylus is clomben on þe staire.
And litel weneth þat he moste descenden.
But alday falleth þyng þat foles ne wenden.
As proude bayard gynneth for to skyppe.
Out of þe wey / so priketh hym his corn.
Til he a lassħ haue of þe long whippe.
Than þenketht he þough I praunce al by-forn.
First yn þe trays ful fat and newe shorn.
Yet am I but an hors and horses lawe.
I moot endure and with my felawes drawe.
So ferd it by þis fers and proud knyght.
Though he a worthi kynges sone were.
And wende no þing hadde had swych myght.
A-yens his wil þat sholde his herte dere.
yet with a lok his hert wax a fere.
That he þat now was most in pride a-boue.
wax sodeynly most subget vn to loue.
For-þi ensample taketh of þis man.
Ye wyse proude and worthi folkes alle.
To scornen loue which þat so soone kan.
The fredom of youre hertes to hym þralle.
For euere it was / and euere it shal bifalle.
That loue is he þat alle þing may bynde.
For may no man for-do þe lawe of kynde.
That this be soth hath preued [? MS. d] and doth yet.
For this trowe I ye knowen alle or some.
Men reden not þat folk han gretter wit.
Than þei þat han be most with loue y-nome.
And strengest folk ben þerwith ouercome.
The worthiest and grettest yn degre.
This was and is / and yet men shal it se.
And trewelycħ it sit wele to be so.
For alderwisest han þer with ben plesed.
And þei þat han ben addermost in wo.
with loue han ben conforted most and esed.
And ofte it hath þe cruel herte apesed.
And worthi folk maad worthier of name.
And causen most to dreden vice and shame.
Now sith it may not goodly be withstonde.
And is a thyng so vertuous yn kynde.
Refuseth not to loue for to be bonde.
Syn as hym seluen lyst he may yow bynde.
The yerde is bet þat bowen wole and wynde.
Than þat / þat brest / and þerfor .I. yow rede.
To folwen hym þat so wel kan yow lede.
But for to tellen forth yn special.
Of þis kynges sone of which I tolde.
And letten oþer þing collateral.
Of hym þenk I my tale for to holde.
Boþe of his Ioyes and of his cares colde.
And al his werk as touchyng þis matere.
For I it gan I wil þer-to refere.
With-Inne þe temple he went hym forth pleynge.
This Troylus and euery wyght aboute.
On þis lady and now on þat lokynge.
where so she were of towne or of with oute.
And vp on cas bifel þat þorugh a route.
His eye procede / and so depe it wente.
Til on Criseyde it smot and þere it stente.
And sodeynly he wax þer-with astoned.
And [gan] hire bet biholde yn thrifty wyse.
O mercy god þoughte he wher hastow woned.
That art so fair and goodly to deuyse.
And þer-with his hert gan to sprede and ryse.
And softe sighed lest men myghte hym here.
And caughte a-yen his firste pleynge chere.
She nas not with the leste of here stature.
But alle here lymes so wel answerynge.
weren to womanhode þat creature.
was neuer lasse mannyssħ in semynge.
And ek þe pure wyse of here meuynge.
Shewed wel þat men myght yn here gesse.
Honour estat and wommanly noblesse.
To Troylus right wonder wel with alle.
Gan for to lyke here menyng and here chere.
whicħ somdel deynous was for she leet falle.
Here look a lite a-side in swycħ manere.
Ascaunces what may I not stonden here.
And after þat here lokyng gan she lyghte.
That neuere þought hym seen so fair a sighte.
And of here look yn hym þer gan to quyken.
So gret desir and sucħ affeccioun.
That in his hertes botme gan to stiken.
Of here / his fixe and depe impressioun.
And þough he erst hadde poured vp and doun.
He was þo glad his hornes yn to shrynke.
Vnneþes wyst he how to loke or wynke.
Lo he þat leet hym seluen so konnynge.
And scorned hem þat loues peynes dryen.
was ful vnwar þat loue hadde his dwellynge.
with-Inne þe subtile stremes of here eyen.
That sodeynly hym þoughte þat he sholde dyen.
Right with hire look þe spirit yn herte.
Blyssyd be loue þat kan þus folk conuerte.
She þis in blak lykynge to Troylus.
Ouer al þyng he stood to byholde.
Ne his desir ne whefor he stod þus.
He neiþer chere ne made ne word tolde.
But from a fer his maner for to holde.
On oþer þing his look som tyme he caste.
And eft on here while þat þe seruise laste.
And after this not fullyche al a-whaped.
Out of þe temple al esilyche he wente.
Repentynge hym þat he hadde euere y-Iaped.
Of loues folk. lest fully þe descente.
Of scorn fille on hym self. but what he mente.
Lyst it were wyst on ony maner side.
His wo he gan dissimulen and hide.
Whan he was fro þe temple þus departed.
He streyght anoon / vn to his paleys turneth.
Right with here look þurgh shoten & þurgh darted.
Al feyneth he yn lust þat he soiorneth.
And al his speche and cher also he borneth.
And ay of loues seruantȝ euery while.
Hym-self to wre at hem her gan to smyle.
And seyde lord so ye lyue al yn lyst.
Ye loueres / for þe konnyngest of yow.
That serueth most ententiflych and best.
Hym tyt as often harme þer-of as prow.
Youre hire is quyt a-yeyn ye god wot how.
Nought wel for wel. but scorn for good seruice.
In feith youre ordre is ruled in good wyse.
I noun certeyn ben alle youre obseruaunces.
But it a sely fewe poyntes be.
Ne no þing asketh so grete attendaunces.
As doth youre lay and þat knowe alle ye.
But þat is not þe worste as mot .I. the.
But tolde I yow þe worste poynt I leue.
Al seyde I soth ye wolden at me greue.
But tak þis þat ye loueres ofte eschuwe.
Or elles don of good entencioun.
Ful ofte þi lady wole it mys construe.
And deme it harm yn hire opinyoun.
And yet yf she for other enchesoun.
Be wroth þan shalt þow han a groyn a-noon.
Lord wel is hym þat may be of yow oon.
But for al þis whanne he say his tyme.
He held his pes noon oþer bote hym gayned.
For loue bygan his fetheres so to lyme.
That wel vnneþe vn-to his folk he feyned.
That oþere besye nedes hym destrayned.
For wo was hym þat what to done he nyste.
But bad his folk to gon wher þat hym lyste.
And whan þat he yn chaumbre was allone.
He down vp on his beddes feet hym sette.
And first he gan to syke and to grone.
And þoughte ay on here so with-outen ony lette.
That as he sat and wok his spirit mette.
That he here saw a temple and al þe wyse.
Right of hire loke / and gan it newe auyse.
Thus gan he make a myrrour of his mynde.
In whicħ he saugh alle holly hire figure.
And that he wel koude yn his herte fynde.
It was to him a right good auenture.
To loue swych on and yf he dede his cure.
To seruen here yet myght he falle in grace.
Or elles for on of hire seruauntȝ pace.
Ymagynynge þat trauaylle nor grame.
Ne myghte for so goodly on be lorn.
As she. ne hym for his desir no shame.
Al were it wist but yn prys and vp born.
Of alle louers wel more þan byforn.
Thus argumented he yn his gynnynge.
Ful vnauysed of his wo comynge.
Thus toke he purpos loues craft to suwe.
And þoughte he wolde werken priuely.
First to hide his desir yn muwe.
From euery wyght y-born al outrely.
But he myght ought recouered be þerby.
Remembryng hym þat loue to wyde y-blowe.
Yelt bittre fruyt þough swete be sowe.
And ouer aɫɫ þis yet muche more he þoughte.
For what to speken and what to holden Inne.
And what to arten hire hire to loue he soughte.
And on a song a-noon right to bygynne.
And gan loude on his sorwe for to wynne.
For wiþ good hope he gan fully assente.
Criseyde for to loue and nought repente.
And of his song nought only þe sentence.
As writ my Auctor called Lollyus.
But pleynly saue oure tonge deference.
I dar wel sayn yn al þat Troylus.
Seyde yn his song / lo euery word right þus.
As .I. shal seyn. and who lyst it to hire.
Lo nexst þis vers he may it fynden here.

LG.HEAD: (58) (Troilus's Song, from Petrach's 88th Sonnet.)
LG.L: Yf loue is o god what fele .I. so.
And if loue is. what þyng and what is he.
yf loue be good from whens cometh my wo.
If it be wykke a wonder þenketh me.
whenne euery torment and aduersite.
That cometh of hym may me so goodly þynke.
For ay þurst I þe more þat I it drynke.

LG.HEAD: (59) (From Petrarch.)
LG.L: And yf þat at myn owene lust I brenne.
Fro whennes cometh my walyng and my pleynte.
If harme agree me wher-to pleyne I þanne.
I not. ne whi vnweri þat I feynte.
O quyke deth o swete harme so queynte.
How may of [þe] yn me swiche quantite.
But if þat I consente þat it so be.

LG.HEAD: (60) (From Petrarch.)
LG.L: And if þat I consente .I. wrongfully.
Compleyne .I.-wys þus possed to and fro.
Al sterles with-Inne a bot am .I.
A-myd þe see by-twen wyndes two.
That yn contrarye stonden euere mo.
Allas what is þis wonder maladye.
For hete of cold for cold of hete I deye.
LG.TRAILER: (End of Troilus's Song from Petrach's 88th Sonnet.)

LG.L: And to the god of loue þus seyde he.
with pitous voys .o. lord now youres is.
Mi spirit whicħ þat aught youre be.
Yow þank I lord þat han me brought to þis.
But wheþer goddesse or womman .I.-wys.
She be / I not which þat ye do me serue.
But as here man .I. wole ay leue and sterue.
Ȝe stonden yn hire eyen myghtily.
As yn a place vn-to your vertu digne.
wherfore my lord if my seruyse or .I.
May lyke yow so beth to me benygne.
For myn estal royal here I resigne.
In-to hire ħond and with ful humble chere.
By-come here man as to my lady dere.
In hym ne deynede sparen blood royal.
The fyr of loue þe wherfro god me blysse.
Ne hym forbar in no degre for al.
His vertu or his excellent prowesse.
But hold hym as his þral lowe yn distresse.
And brend hym so in sondry wyse ay newe.
That sixty tyme a day he loste his hewe.
So muche day by day his owene þought.
For lust to here gan quyken and encrese.
That euery oþer charge he sett at nought.

For faylyng for to assayn ouer al.
Now may I iape of þe if þat I shal.
But naþeles þough þat I sholde deye.
That þow art none of þo þat dorst I seye.
Now beet þi brest and seye to god of loue.
Thi grace lord for now I me repente.
If I mys spak / for now my-self I loue.
Thus sey with al thyn hert yn good entente.
Quod Troilus a lord I me consente.
And pray to þe my Iapes þow for-yeue.
And I shal neuere more whil I leue.
Thow seyst wel quod Pandarus and now I hope.
That þow þe goddes wraþþe hast al apesed.
And siþen þat þow hast wopen many a drope.
And seyd swych þyng wher-with þi god is plesed.
Now wolde neuere god but þow were esed.
And þynk wel she of whom rist al þi wo.
Here after may þi comfort be al so.
For þilke ground þat bereth þe wedys wykke.
Bereth eke þese holsome herbes al ful ofte.
Next þe foule netle rough and þikke.
The rose waxeþ swote and smothe and softe.
And nexst þe valey is þe hil a-lofte.
And nexst þe derk nyght þe glade morwe.
And also Ioye is nexst after sorwe.
Now loke þat a-tempre be þy brydel.
And for þe beste ay suffre to þe tyde.
Or elles alle oure labour is on ydel.
He hasteþ wel þat wysly kan a-byde.
Be diligent and trewe and ay wel hide.
Be lusty fre perseuere yn þyn seruyse.
And al is wel if þow werk yn þis wyse.
But ne þat departed is yn euery place.
Is no wher hool as writen clerkes wyse.
what wonder is that such on haue no grace.
Ek wostow how it fareþ on som seruice.
As plaunte a tre or herbe yn sondry wyse.
And on þe morwe pulle it vp as blyue.
No wonder is þow it mowe neuere þriue.
And sith þat god of loue hath þe bystowed.
In place digne vn [to] þi worþynesse.
Stond fast for to good port hastow rowed.
And of thy self for any heuynesse.
Hope alwey wel / for but if drerynesse.
Or ouer-haste oure boþe laboure shende.
I hope of þis to make a good ende.
And wostow whi I am þe lasse a-fered.
Of þis matere with my Nece trete.
For þis haue I herd seyd of wyse y-lered.
was neuere man ne woman yet bygete.
That was vnapt to suffren loues hete.
Celestial. or elles loue of kynde.
For-þi som grace I hope yn here fynde.
And for to speke of here yn special.
Hire beaute to by-þynke and hire youþe.
It sit hire nought to be Celestial.
And yet þough þat hire lyste boþe and kouþe.
But trewly it sat here wel right nowþe.
A worthy knyght to loue and cherice.
And but she do I holde it for a vice.
Wherfore I am and wole be ay redy.
To peyne me to do yow þis seruyse.
For boþe yow to plese þus hope I.
Her-afterward for ye beth boþe wyse.
And konne it counseyl kepe yn such a wyse.
That no man schal of it þe wiser be.
And so we may be gladed alle þre.
For be my trowþe I haue right now of þe.
A good conceyt yn my wit as I gesse.
And what þat is I wol now þat þow se.
I þenke. sith þat loue of his goodnesse.
Hath þe conuerted out of wikkednesse.
That þow shalt be þe best post I leue.
Of al his lay / and most hise foos to greue.
Ensample whi. se ye þese wyse clerkes.
That erren aldermost a-yen þe lawe.
And ben conuerted from hire wykkede werkes.
Thorugh grace of god þat lyst hem to hym drawe.
Than arn þei folk þat han most god yn awe.
And strengest feyþed ben I vnderstonde.
And konne an errour alder best wiþstonde.
Whanne Troylus had herd Pandare assentyd.
To ben his help yn louyng of Criseyde.
wex of his wo as who seyth vntormentid.
But hotter weex his loue and þus he seyde.
with sobre chere al-þough his herte pleyde.
Now blysful Venus help er þat I sterue.
Of þe Pandare I may som þank deserue.
But dere frend how shal myn wo ben lesse.
Til þis be don and good eke telle me þisse.
How wyltow seyn of me and my destresse.
Lest she be wroth þis drede I most I-wysse.
Or nyl not heren or trowen how it ysse.
Al þis drede I. and ek for þe manere.
Of þe here Em she nyl no swych þyng here.
Quod Pandarus þou hast a ful grete care.
Lest þat þe Cherl wole falle out of þe mone.
whi lord I hate of þe þi nyce fare.
whi entremete of þat þow hast to done.
For goddes loue I bydde þe a bone.
So lat me allone. and it shal be þi beste.
whi frend quod he / now do riþt as þe leste.
But herke Pandare o word for I nolde.
That þow in me wendest so gret folye.
That to my lady I desiren sholde.
That toucheþ harm or ony vilenye.
For dredles me were leuere dye.
Than she of me ought elles vnderstode.
But þat / þat myght sownen yn to gode.
Tho lough þis Pandare & a-noon answered.
And I þi borw / fy / no wyght doth but so.
I rought nought þough þat she stode and herde.
How þat þow seyst. but farewel I wole go.
A dieu / be glad / god spede vs boþe two.
yeue me þis labour and þis besynesse.
And of my sped be þyn al þat swetnesse.
But Troylus gan doun on his knees to falle.
And Pandare yn his armes hent faste.
And seyde now fy on þe Grekes alle.
yet parde god shal helpe vs at þe laste.
And dredles yf þat my lyf may laste.
And god to-forn / lo som of hem shal smerte.
And yet me of-þynketh þat þis auaunt me a-sterte.
Now Pandare I kan no more seye.
But þow wys / þow wost / þow mayst / þow art al.
My lyf / my deth / hool yn thyn hond I leye.
Help now quod he / yis by my trouþe I shal.
God yelde þe frend and þis yn special.
Quod Troylus / þat þou me recomaunde.
To here þat to þe deth me may comaunde.
This Pandarus tho desirous to serue.
His fulle frend þenne seyde yn þis manere.
Farwel and þenk I wole þi þank deserue.
Haue here my trouthe and þat þou shalt wel here.
And went his wey þenkyng on þis matere.
And how he myght here beseche of grace.
And fynde a tyme þer to and a place.
For euery wyght that hath an hows to founde.
Ne renneth nought þe werk for to bygynne.
With rakel hond / but he wole byde a stounde.
And send his hertes lyne out fro with Inne.
Alderfirst his purpos for to wynne.
Al þis Pandare yn his herte þoughte.
And caste his werk ful wyaly or he wroughte.
But Troilus lay þo no lengere down.
But vp a-noon vp on his stede bay.
And yn þe feld he pleyde þo lyoun.
who was þat Grek þat wiþ hym mette þat day.
And yn þe town his manere þo forþ ay.
So goodly was / and gat hym so yn grace.
That eche hym louede þat loked on his face.
For he by-come þe frendlyeste wyght.
The gentileste and ek þe most fre.
The þriftieste and oon þe beste knyght.
That yn his tyme was or myghte be.
Dede were his Iapes and his cruelte.
His heigh port and his manere estraunge.
And ech of þo gan for a vertu chaunge.
Now late vs stynte of Troylus a stounde.
That fareth lyk a man þat hurt is sore.
And is somdel of akynge of his wounde.
Ilyssed wel / but heled no del more.
And as an esy pacient þe lore.
Abit of hym þat goþ aboute his cure.
And þus he drieth forth his auenture.

HEADNOTE.P: [Harl. MS. 2280, Brit. Mus., ab. 1410-25, vellum, leaf 1.]
[The þ & y are of the same form, tho printed þ & y here.]

LG.HEAD: (1) (Proem)
LG.L: THe double sorowe of troilus to tellen
Þat was þe kynge Priamus sone of Troye
In louynge how hise auentures fellen
Fro wo to wele and after out of Ioye
My purpos is er þat I parte fro ye
Thesphone thow help me for tendite
This woful vers þat wepen as I write

LG.HEAD: (2) (Invocation)
LG.L: ¶ To the clepe I thow goddesse of torment
Thow cruel furye sorowynge euer in peyne
Help me þat am þe sorowful Instrument
That helpeþ louers as I kan to pleyne
For wel sit it þe sothe for to seyne
A woful wyght to han a drery feere
And to a sorwful tale a sory chere
¶ For I þat god of loues seruaunt serue
Ne dar to loue for myn vnliklynesse
Preyen for speed al sholde I þer-fore sterue
So fer I am from his helpe in derkenesse
But natheles if þis may done gladnesse
Un to any louere and his cause a-vaylle
Haue he my þonk and myn by þis trauaille
¶ But ye louers þat oathen in gladdenesse
If any drope of pite in ȝow be
Remembreth ȝow on passed heuynesse
Þat ȝe han felt and on þe aduersite
Of oþer folk and thenketh how þat ȝe
Han felt þat loue dorste ȝow displeese
Or ȝe han wonne hym wiþ to grete an ese
¶ And preyeth for hem þat ben in þe cas
Of Troilus as may after heere
Þat Loue hem brynge in heuene to solas
And ek for me preyeth to god so deere
Þat I haue mygth to shew in som manere
Swich peyne and wo as loues folk endure
In troilus vnsely auenture
¶ And byddeþ ek for hem þat ben despeyred
In loue þat neuere nyl recouered be
And ek for hem þat falsly ben a-peyred
Þorwgh wikked tonges. be it he or sche
Þus byddeþ god for his benignite
So graunte hem sone out of þis world to passe
Þat ben despeyred out [of] loues grace
¶ And byddeþ ek for hem þat ben at ese
Þat god hem graunte ay goode perseueraunce
And sende hem myght hire loueres for to plese
Þat it to loue be worschip and plesaunce
For so hope I best my soule to auaunce
To preye for hem þat loues scruauntes be
And write hire wo and lyue in cherite
¶ And for to haue of hem compassyoun
As þough I were hire owne broþer deere
Now herkeneth with a goode entencioun
For now wol I gone streght to my matere
In þe whiche ȝe may double sorwes here
of troilus in louynge of Criseyde
And how þat she for-soke him or sche deyed

LG.HEAD: (9) (Story)
LG.L: ¶ It is wele wist how þat þe grekes stronge
In armes with a thousand shippes wente
To troye wardes and þe cite longe
asseȝeden nygh ten yer er theye stente
And in diuerse wise and oon entente
Þe rauysynge to wreken of Eleyne
By paris doun they wroughten al hir peyne
¶ Now fel it so þat in þe town þer was
Dwellynge a lord of grete autorite
A grete deuyn þat cleped was calkas
Þat in science so expert was þat he
Knew wele þat troye sholde destroyed be
By answer of his god þat hyghte þus
Daun phebus or appollo delphicus
¶ So when þis calkas knew by calkulynge
And ek by answer of þis appollo
Þat grekes sholden swiche a peple brynge
Þorwgh whiche þat Troye most ben fordo
He cast o non out of þe town to go
For wel west he by soȝt þat troye sholde
Destroyed ben. ȝe wold who so nolde
¶ For which for to departen softely
Took purpos ful þis for-knowynge wyse
And to þe grekes oost ful pryuely
he stal a non / and þei in curtas wyse
Hym deden bothen worschipp and seruyse
In truste þat hee hath knowynge him to rede
In euery peril which þat is to drede
¶ Þe noyse up rose when it was first aspied
Þorwgh al þe town and generally was spoken
Þat calkas traitor fals fled was and allied
with hem of grece and casten to ben wroken
on him þat falsly hadde his faith so broken
and sayden þat he and alle his kyn at oones
Ben worþi for to brennen alle fel and bones
¶ Now had calkas left in þis mischaunce
Alle vnwiste of þis fals and wikked dede
His douȝter which þat was in grete penaunce
For of hir lyf sche was ful sore in drede
As sche þat nyst what was best to rede
For boþe a wydew was sche and allone
of any frend to whom sche dorst hir mone
¶ Criseyde was þis lady name al riȝth
As to my doom in alle troyes cite
was non so fayre for-passynge euery wyght
So aungellyke was hir natif beaute
Þat lyke a thynge in-mortal semed sche
As doth an heuenyssh parfit creature
Þat down war sent in scornyng of nature
¶ Þis lady whiche alday þat herd at ere
Hire faderes chame his falsenesse and tresoun
wel neȝgh out of hire witt for sorw and fere
In widewes habit large of samyt broune
On knees sche fel by-forne ector a-doune
with pitous vois and tenderly wepynge
his mercy bad hire seluen excusynge.
¶ Nowe was þis ector pitous of nature
And sauȝgh þat che was sorowfully bygone
And þat sche was so fayre a creature
Of his godenesse he gladded hire anone
And sayde lat ȝoure faderes tresoun gone
forth with mischaunce and ȝourself in Ioye
Dwellyt with us whil ȝow goode list in troye
¶ And alle þe honour þat men may don ȝow haue
as fer forth as ȝour fader dwelled here
Ȝe schal han and ȝour body schal men saue
as fer as may ouȝght enquere or here
And sche him þankked with ful humble chere
And ofter wald and it hadde ben his wille
And toke hyre leue and hoom and held hir stille
¶ And in hire house sche abode with swhich meyne
As til hire honour neded was to holde
And whil sche was dwellynge in þat cite
Kepte hire astate / and boþe of ȝonge and olde
Ful wel by-loued / and wel men of hire tolde
But wheþer þat sche children hadde or non
I rede it noȝgh þer-fore I latt it gone
¶ Þe thynges fellen as þai don of werre
Bitwixen hem of Troye and grekes ofte
For somday boughten þai of troye it dere
And eft þe grekes founden no þinge softe
Þe folk of troye and þus fortune on loft
And vnder eft gan hem to whielen bothe
Aftir hire cours / ay whil þat þai were wroþe
¶ But how þis town com to destruccioun
Ne falleþ noȝth to purpos me to telle
For it were a longe discrecioun
Fro my matere // and ȝow to longe to dwelle
But þe troyan geestes as þei felle
In Omer or in dares or in dite
who-so þat kan may rede hem as þai write
¶ But though þat grekes hem of troye shetten
And hire cite be-seged alle a-boute
Hire old vsage wold þai noȝth letten
As for to honour hire goddes ful deuoute
But aldermost in honour out of doute
Þey had a relyk heet palladioun
Þat was hire trist a-bouen euerichoun
¶ And so byfel whan comen was þe tyme
Of aperil whan cloþed is þe mede
With new grene of lusty veer þe prime
And swote smellen floures white and rede
In sondry wises schewed as I rede
Þe folke of troye hire obseruaunces olde
Palladyons fest for to holde
¶ And to þe tomple in alle hire godely best wise
In general þer wente many a wyȝt
To herken of palladyoun þe seruise
And namely so mony a lusti knyght
So many a lady fresshe and mayden bryght
Ful wele araied boþe most meyne and leste
Yo boþe for þe seson and þe feeste
¶ Among þise oþer folke was crisayda
In wydewes habit blak but naþeles
Right as oure furste lettre is nowe an a
In beaute firste so stoode sche makeles
Hire goodely lokkyng / gladde al the prees
Was neuere þat seyn thyng / to ben preysed derre
Nor vnder cloude blake so bright a sterre
¶ As was criseyde as folk seyde euerychon
Þat hire by-helden in hire blak wede
And þat scho stood ful low and stille allone
Byhynden oþer folk in litel brede
And neȝgh þe dore ay vnder chames drede
Symple of a-tyre and debonar of cheere
wyth ful asseured lokynge and manere
¶ Þis troylus as he was wont to gyde
Hire ȝonge knyghtes led hem vp and down
In þilke large temple on euery syde
Byholdynge ay þe ladys of þe town
Now here now þare for no deuocioun
Hadde he to non / to reuen him his reste
But gan to preyse and lakken whom him leste
¶ And in his walk ful fast he gan to wayten
If knyght or swyer of his compaynye
Gan for to sigh or lete his eyen baten
On any woman þat he koude aspye
He wolden smyle and holden it folye
And seye him þus god wote sche slepeþ softe
For loue of þe whan þow turnest ful oft
¶ I haue herd telle pardieux of ȝour lyuynge
Ye louers and ȝoure obseruaunces
And which a labour folk han in wynnynge
of loue / and in þe kepynge whiche doutaunces
And when ȝour preye is lost wo and penaunces
O verrey fooles nice and blynde be ȝe
Þer is not oon kan war by oþer be
¶ And wiþ þat worde he gan cast vp þe browe
Ascaunces lo / is þis nouȝt wysely spoken
At whiche þe god of loue gan loken rowe
Riȝght for despit / and shope for to ben wroken
He kydde onon his bow nas not broken
For sodenly he hitte him atte fulle
And þat as proude a pakoc can he pulle
¶ O blynde world O blynd entencioun
How often falleþ alle þe effecte contrarie
Of surquidrye and foule presumpcioun
For kaught is pryde and kaught is debonaire
Þis troylus is clomben on þe starre
And litel weneþ þat he schall descenden
But alday fayleth þinge þat fooles wenden
¶ As proude bayard gynneþ for to skyppe
out of þe wey / so prikeþ him his corne
Til he a lassch haue of þe longe whippe
Þan thynkeþ he thoȝgh I praunce al by-forne
First in þe trayse ful fat and new shorne
Ȝet am I but an hors and horses lawe
I mote endure and with my feers drawe
¶ So ferd it by þis fiers and proude knyght
Thought he a worþi kynges sonne were
And wende no þinge had had swiche myȝt
a-ȝeynis his wille þat schold his hert stiere
Þat wiþ a look his wax a feere
Þat he þat now was moost in pride aboue
wax sodeynly most subgit vnto loue
¶ For-þe ensaumple taketh of þis man
Ye wise proude and worþi folkes alle
To scornen loue whiche þat so soon kan
Þe fredom of ȝoure hertes to him þralle
For euere it was and euere it schal be-falle
Þat loue is he þat alle þinge may bynde
For may no man fordon þe lawe of kynde
¶ Þat þis be sothe haþ proued and doþ ȝett
For þis trowe I ȝe knowen alle or some
Men reden þat folk han gretter witte
Þan þei þat haþ ben most wiþ loue ynome
And strengest folk ben þer-wiþ ouer-come
Þe worthiest and þe grettest of degree
Þis was and is and ȝett men schal it see
¶ And trewliche it sitt wele to be so
For alderwysest han þar-wiþ ben plesed
And þai þat han ben aldermost in wo
with loue han ben conforted most and esed
And oft it haþ þe cruel herte apesed
And worþi folk made worþier of name
And causeth most to dreden vice and chame
¶ And sith it may not godely ben with-stonde
And is a þinge so vertuous in kynde
Refuseth not to loue for to ben bonde
Syn as him seluen liste he may ȝow bynde
Þe ȝerde is bet þat bowen wole and wynde
Þan þat þat brest / and þer-for I ȝow rede
To folowen him þat so wele kan ȝow lede
¶ But for to tellen forthe in speciale
Of þis kynges sone of which I told
And leten oþer þinge collateral
Of hym þenke .I. my tale for to holde
Boþe of his Ioie and of his cares colde
And alle his werk as towchynge þis matere
For I it gan .I wol þer-to refeere
¶ with-Inne þe temple he wente him forth pleyinge
Þis Troylus of euery wyght a-boute
On þis lady and now on þat lokynge
where-so sche were of towne or of with-oute
And vp-on cas bifel þat þorwȝ a route
His eyghe percede and so depe it wente
Til on criseyde it smoot and þer it stente
¶ And sodeynly he wex þer-with astoned
And gan hire bet biholde in thrifry wise
O mercye god thoughte he where hastow woned
Þat ert so fair and goodely to deuyse
Þer-with his hert gan to sprede and ryse
And soft syghed lest men myght him here
And caughte aȝeyn his firste playinge chere
¶ Sche nas not with þe leste of hire stature
But alle hire lymes so wele answerynge
weren to womanhode þat creature
Was neuer lesse mannyssh in semynge
And ek þe poure wyse of hire menynge
Schewed wele þat men myght in hire gesse
Honor estate / and womanly noblesse
¶ To troylus right wonder wele with alle
gan for to like / hire menynge and hire chere
whiche somdele deignous was for sche lete falle
Hire loke a lite a side / in swiche manere
ascaunces what may I nat stonden here
And after þat hire lokynge gan sche lyghte
Þat neuer thoughte hym seen so goode a sighte
¶ And of hire loke in him þer gan to quyken
So grete desire and swhiche affeccioun
Þer in his hertes botme gan to stiken
Of his fixe and depe impressioun
And thought he arst hadde poured up and donn
He was þo gladde his hornes in to shrynke
Vnnethes wiste he how to loke or wynke
¶ Loo he þat lete hym seluen so konnynge
And scorned hym þat loues peynes dryen
was ful vnwar þat loue hadde his dwellynge
with-inne þe subtile stremes of hir eyen
Þat so-deynly hym thoughte he felt deyen
Ryght with hire loke þe spirit in his herte
Blissed be loue þat þus kan folk conuerte
¶ Sche þis in blake likynge to troylus
Ouer alle þinge he stode for to beholde
Ne his desire ne wher-for he stode þus
He neyther chere made ne worde tolde
But fram a-fer his manere for to hold
On oþer þinge his loke som tyme he caste
And oft on hire while þat seruise laste
¶ And after þis nat fulliche alle awhaped
Out of þe temple alle esiliche he wente
Repentynge him þat he hadde euer I-iaped
Of loues folke lest fully the descente
Of scorne / fille on hym self but what he mente
lest it were wiste on any maner syde
His wo he gan dissimilen and hyde
¶ when he was fro þe temple þus departed
He streght anon vn-to his paleys torneth
Right with hire loke þorwh schoten and þorwh darted
Al feyneþ he in lust þat he soiorneth
And al his chere and speche al so he borneth
And ay of loues seruantes euery while
Him self to wrie at hem he gan to smile
¶ And seyde lorde so ye lyue al in leste
Ye louers / for þe konnyngest of ȝow
Þat serueþ most ententifliche and best
Him tit als often harme þer-of as prowe
Ȝour hire is quyt aȝeyn ye god wote howe
Nought wel for wel but scorn for gode seruise
In feithe ȝowr ordre is ruled in gode wyse.
¶ In non certeyn ben alle ȝoure obseruaunces
But it a sely fewe poyntes be
Ne no þinge asketh so grete attendaunces
As doþ your lay and þat know alle ȝe
But þat is not þe werste as mote I the
But tolde I ȝow þe werste poynt I leeue
Al seyde I soth ȝe wolden at me greue
¶ But take þis þat ȝe loueres oft eschewe
Or elles don of goode entencioun
Ful oft þi lady wol it misconstrewe
And deme it harme in hyr opinioun
And ȝit if sche for oþer encheson
Be wroth / þan schal þow haue a groyn onon
lord wele is hym / þat may be of ȝow one
¶ But for al þis when he sey his tyme
He held his pees non oþer boote him gayned
For loue bigan his feþeres so to lyme
That wel vnnethe vn-til his folk he fayned
Þat other besye nedes him destrayned
For wo was him þat what to don he nyste
But bad his folk to gon wher þat hem liste
¶ And when þat he in chaumber was allon
He down vp-on his beddes feet him sette
And first he gan to syke and eft to grone
And thoughte ay on hire so wiþ-outen lette
Þat as he satt and woke his spirit mette
Þat he here saugh and temple and al þe wyse
Right of hire loke and gan it new a-uise
¶ Þus gan he make a mirour of his mynde
In whiche he saughȝ alle holly hire figure
And þat he wel kouth in his hert fynde
It was to him ryght a goode auenture
To loue swhich oon and if he dydde his cure
To seruen hire ȝet myȝt he falle in grace
Or elles for oon of hir seruauntes pace
¶ Ymaginynge þat trauaille nor grame
Ne myȝt for so goodely one be lorne
As she ne him for his desire no shame
Al were it wiste but in pris and vp borne
of alle louers wele more þan byforne
Þus argumentede he in hijs gynnynge
Ful vnauised of his wo comynge
¶ Þus toke he purpos loues craft to suwe
And thought he wold wyrkyn prively
First to hiden his desire in muwe
From euery wyght yborne alle outrely
But he myght aught recouered be þerby
Rememberynge him þat loue to wyde yblowe
Ȝelt better fruyt thouge swete sede be sawe
¶ And ouer al þis ȝet muchel more he þouȝt
what for to speke and what to holden Inne
And what artu hire to loue he soughte
And on a songe a-non ryght to bigynne
And gan loude on his sorwe for to wynne
For wiþ goode hope he gan fully assente
Cryseyde for to loue and nought repent
¶ And of his songe nought only þe sentence
As write myn autour called lollius
But pleynly saue oure tonges difference
I dar wel seyn in alle þat troylus
Seyde in his songe loo euery word right þus
As I sal seyn and whoso liste it here
Lo next þis vers he may it fynde here

LG.HEAD: (58) (From Petrarch.) // cantus troili
LG.L: ¶ If no loue is o god what fele I so
And if loue is what þinge and whiche is he
If loue be gode from whennes comþ my wo
If it be wykke a wonder thynketh me
whenne euery torment and aduersite
Þat cometh of him may to me sauory thynke
For ay thirst I þe more þat iche it drynke

LG.HEAD: (59) (From Petrarch.)
LG.L: ¶ And if þat at myn owne lust I brenne
From whennes cometh my wailynge and my pleynte
If harme agree me I where-to pleyne I thenne
I noot / ne why vnworþi þat I feynte
O quyk deth o swete harme so queynte
How may of þe in me swhiche quantite
But if þat I consente þat it be

LG.HEAD: (60) (From Petrarch.)
LG.L: ¶ And if that I consente I wrongefully
Compleyne Iwhis þus possed to and fro
Al stierlees with-Inne aboot am I
Amyd þe see betwexen wendes two
Þat in contrarie standen euer mo
Allas what is þis wonder maladye
For hote of cold for cold of hete I dye
LG.TRAILER: (End of Troilus's Song from Petrarch's 88th Sonnet.)

LG.L: ¶ And to þe god of loue þus seyde he
with pitous uois o lord now ȝours is
Mi spirit whiche auȝght ȝours be
Ȝow þanke I lord þat haue me brought to þis
But wheþer goddesse or womman Iwys
She be I not / which þat ȝe do me serue
But as hire man I wol ay lyue and sterue
¶ Ȝe stonden in hire eyen miȝtyly
As in a place vn-to ȝour vertu digne
wher-for lord If my seruise or I.
May liken ȝow so beth to me benigne
For myn estate roial here I resigne
In to hire hond and with ful humble chere
By-come hire man as to my lady dere
¶ In hym ne deyned sparen blode roial
Þe fir of loue / ye wher-fro god me blisse
Ne him for-bar in no degre for al
His vertue or his excellent prowesse
But held hym as his þralle low in destresse
And brinde hym so in sondry wyse ay newe
Þat sexty tyme a day he lost his hewe
¶ So muchel day by day his owne þouȝt
For lust to hire be-gan quiken and encresse
Þat euery oþer charge he sett at nouȝt
For-þi ful oft his hote fir to cesse
To sene hire goodely loke he gan to preesse
For þar-by to ben esed wele he wende
And ay þe ner he was þe more he brende
¶ For ay the ner þe fir þe hatter is
Þis trowe I knoweth al þis companye
But were he fer or nere .I. dar seye þis
By nyght or day for wisdom or for folye
His herte which þat is his brestis eye
was on hire þat fairer was to sene
Þan euere were elyne or polixene
¶ Ek of þe day þer passed nouȝgth an houre
Þat to him self a þowsand tyme he seyde
Goode godely to whom serue I laboure
As I best kan now wold god cryseyde
Ȝe wolden on me rew er þat I dyede
Mi deere herte allas myn hele and hewe
And lif is lost but ȝe wol on me rewe
¶ Alle oþer dredes weren from him fledde
Bothe of thassege and his sauacioun
Ne in his desire none other fownes bredde
But argumentes to þis conclusion
Þat sche of him wolde han compassioun
And he to ben hire man whil he may dure
Lo here his lif and from þe deth his cure
¶ Þe charppe showres fille of armes preue
Þat ector or his othere bretheren diden
Ne made hym oonly þere-fore ones meue
And þat was he wher-so men went or riden
Founde oon þe best and lengest tyme abiden
Þer peril was and dide eke swiche trauaile
In armes þat to thynke it was meruaille
¶ But for none hate he to þe grekes hadde
Ne also for þe rescous of þe town
Ne made him þus in armes for to madde
But oonly lo for this conclusioun
To liken hire þe bette for his renoun
Fro day to day in armes so he spedde
That the grekes as þe deth him dredde
¶ And fro þis forth þo reft hym loue his slepe
And made his mete his foo and ek his sorwe
gan multiplye þat who-so toke kepe
It shewed in his hewe boþe eue and morwe
Þer-for a title he gan him for to borwe
of oþer sikenesse / lest men of him wende
Þat þe hote fire of loue him brende
¶ And seyd he hadde a feuyr and ferde amys
But howe it was certein kan I not seye
If þat his lady vnderstode nat þis
Or feyned hir she nyste on of þe tweye
But wele I rede þat by no maner weye
Ne semed it þat she of him roughte
Or of his peyne or what so euere he þoughte
¶ But þan felt þis troilus swiche wo
Þat he was wel nyghe wode for ay his drede
was þis þat sche som wyght hadde loued so
Þat neuer of him she wold haue taken hede
For whiche him þought he felt his hert blede
Ne of his wo ne dorst he nat by-gynne
to tellen hire / for al þis world to wynne
¶ But when he hadde a space from his care
Þus to him self ful oft he gan to pleyne
He sayd o fool now artow in þe sware
Þat whilom Iapedest at loues peyne
Now artow hent now gnawe þin own cheyne
Þow were ay wont eche louere reprehende
Of þingh fro which þow kanst þe nat defende
¶ what wol now euery louer seyn of þe
If þis be wiste / but euere in þin absence
Laughen in scorne / and seyn loo þer goþe he
Þat is man of so grete sapience
and held vs louers leest in reuerence
Now thanked god he may gone in þe daunce
of him þat loue liste fiebly for tauaunce
¶ But o þow woful troilus god wolde
Seth þow most louen þorwȝ þi desteyne
Þat þow by-sette were on swich on þat sholde
know al þi wo al lakked hire pite
But also colde in loue Towardes þe
Þi lady is / as froost in wynter mone
And þow for-doon as snowe in fire is soone
¶ God wold I were aryued in þe porte
of deth / to which my sorow wol me lede
A lord to me it were a grete comfort
Þan were I qwytte of langwysshynge in drede
For be myn hidde sorowe yblowe on brede
I shal by-Iaped ben a þowsand tyme
More þan þat fool / of whos folye men ryme
But now help god and ye swete for whom
I pleyne / caught ye neuer wygth so fast
O mercy dere hert and help me from
Þe deth for I whil þat my lif may laste
Mor than my self wol loue ȝow to my laste
And wiþ some freendly loke gladdeth me swete
Þowhȝ neuere more þynge ȝe me byhete
¶ Þis wordes and ful many a noþer to
He spak / and called euere in his compleynte
hire name / for to tellen hire his wo
Tyl neigh þat he in salte teris dreynte
Al was for noȝt she herd not his pleynte
And when þat he bithought on þat folye
A þousand folde his wo gan to multiplye
¶ Biwayllynge in his chaumber þus allone
A frende of his þat called was pandare
come ones vnwar and herde hym grone
And saye his freende in swich destresse and care
Allas quod he who causeth al þis fare
O mercy god what vnhap may þis mene
Han now þus soone grekes made ȝow leene
¶ Or hastow som remors of conscience
And art now falle in some devocioun
And waylest for þi synne and þin offence
And hast for ferde caught attricioun
God saue hym þat biseged han oure town
And so kan leye oure Iolyte on presse
And brynge oure lusti folk to holynesse
¶ Þise wordes seyde he for þe nones alle
Þat with swiche þinge he myght him angry maken
And with an angre don his wo to falle
as for þe tyme and his corage awaken
But wele he wyste as fer as tonges spaken
Þer nas aman of gretter hardinesse
Þan he ne more desired worþinesse.
¶ what cas quod troylus or what auenture
Hath gided þe to sen me languyssinge
Þat am refus of euery creature
But for þe loue of god at my prayinge
go henne a-way for certys my deynge
wol þe disese and I mote nedes deye
Þer-for go wey þer is no more to seye
¶ But if þow wene I be þus sik for drede
It is not so and þerfore scorne nought
Þer is anoþer thynge I take of hede
wel more þan aught þe grekes han y-wrogth
whiche cause is of my dethe for sorw and thought
But þough þat I now telle it þe ne leste
Be þow nought wroth I hidde it for þe beste
¶ Þis Pandare þat neyghe malt for wo and routhe
Ful often seyd allas what may þis be
Now frende quod he If euere loue or trouthe
hath ben / or is bytwixen þe and me
Ne do þow neuere swiche a cruelte
To hyden fro þi frende so grete a care
wostow not wel þat it am I pandare
¶ I wil parten with þe al þi peyne
If it be so I do þe no comfort
As it is frendes right soth for to seyne
To entreparten wo as gladde desport
I haue and schal for trew or fals report
In wronge and right I-loued þe al my lyue
Hide nat þi wo fro me but telle it bilyue
¶ Þan gan þis sorwful troilus to syke
And seyde him þus god leue it be my best
To telle it þe for syth it may þe like
Ȝet will I telle it though myn hert breste
And wele wote I þow mayst do me no reste
But leste þow deme I tryste not to þe
Now herke frende for þus it stonde with me
¶ Loue aȝeins þe which who so defendeth
Him seluen most / him alderlest availleth
wiþ dessespeir / so sorwfully me offendeth
Þat streght vn-to þe deth myn herte sailleth
Þer-to desire so brennyngly me assaileth
Þat to ben slayn it were a gretter Ioye
To me / than kyng of grece be and troye
¶ Suffiseth þis my ful frend Pandare
Þat I have seyde for now wostow my wo
And for þe loue of god my cold care
So hide it wele / I tolde it neuere to mo
For harmes myght folwen mo þan two
If it were wiste / but be þow in gladnesse
And lat me sterue vnknow of my destresse
¶ How hastow þus vnkyndly and longe
Hidde þis fro me þow fool quod pandarus
Paraunter þow myght after swiche oon longe
Þat myn auys a-non may helpe vs
Þis were a wonder þinge quod troilus
Þow coudest neuere in loue þi seluen wysse
How deuel maystow brynge me to blysse
¶ Ȝe Troilus herke now quod Pandare
though I be nyse / It happeth often so
That oon þat excesse doth ful yuele fare
By goode conseyl kan kepe his frende þer-fro
I haue my self ek seyen a blynde man go
Þer as he fel þat coude loken wyde
A fool may ek a wise man oft gyde
¶ A wheston is no keruynge Instrument
But ȝet it makeþ sharpe keruynge tolis
And þer þow whost þat I haue aught myswent
eshewe þow þat for swich þinge to þe scole is
Þus often wise men ben ware of folis
If þow do so þi witte is wele bywared
By is contrarye is euery þinge declared
¶ For how myght euere swetenesse han ben knowe
To hym þat neuere tasted betternesse
Ne noman may ben Inly glad I trowe
Þat neuere was in sorwe or som destresse
Ek whit by blak by chame ek worþinesse
Ech sett by oþer more for oþer semeþ
As men may se and so þe wise it demeþ
¶ Sith þus of two contraries is a loore
I that haue in love so oft asayde
greuaunces / ought konne and wele þe more
Conseyllen þe / of þat þow ert amayed
Ek þe ne aught not ben yuel apayed
Þoughe I desire with þe for to bere
Þin heuy charge it schal þe lesse dere
¶ I wote wele þat it farth þus by me
as to þi broþer paris an hierdesse
whiche þat cleped was oonone
wroot in a compleynt of hire heuynesse
Ȝe sey þe lettre þat sche wroot I gesse
Nay neuere ȝet Iwis quod troilus
Now quod pandare herken it was þus

LG.HEAD: (95) (Oenone's Letter to Paris. 1 st.)
LG.L: ¶ Ioebus þat þat first fond art of medcine [MS I]
quod she / and coude in euery wyghtes care
Remede and rede by herbes she know fyne
Ȝet to hym self his konnynge was ful bare
For loue had hym so bounden in a snare
Al for þe doughter of þe kynge Amete
Þat al his craft ne koude his sorwes beete
¶ Right so fare I vnhappily for me
I loue oone beste / and þat me smerteþ soore
And ȝet paraunter kan I reden þe
And nat my selfe repreue me no more
I haue no cause I wote wele for to sore
As doth an hauk that listeþ for to pleye
But to þi help ȝet som-what kan I seye
¶ And of o þyinge ryght siker maystow be
Þat certein for to dyen in þe peyne
Þat I shal neuer mo discoueren þe
Ne by my trouþe I kepe nat restreyne
Þe fro þi loue / theigh þat it were Eleyne
Þat is þi broþer wyf / if ich it wiste
Be what she be / and loue hyre as þe liste
¶ Þer-for as frend fulliche in me asseure
and tel me plat / what is thenchoeson
And fynali cause / of wo þat ye endure
For douteht no þinge myn entencion
Nys nat to ȝow of reprehencion
To speke as now / for no þinge may bireue
A man to loue / til þat hym list to loue
¶ And witeth wel þat both two ben vices
Mystrusten alle / or ellis alle loue
But wele I wote þe mene of it no vice is
For for to trusten som wyght is a preue
of trouthe / and for-þi wold I fayne remeue
Þi wronge conceyte / and do þe som wyght truste
Þi wo to telle / and tel me if þe liste
¶ Þe wise seith wo him þat is allon
For and he falle / he hath non helpe him to ryse
And sith þow hast a felow tel þi moone
For þis nis naught certeyne þe nexte wise
to wynnen loue / as techen vs þe wyse
To walow and wepe / as Nyobe þe quene
whos teerys ȝet in marbel ben yseene
¶ Lat be þi wepynge and þi drerynesse
And lat vs listen wo with oþer speeche
So may þi woful tyme seme lesse
Delite not in wo / þi wo to seche
As doon þis fooles / þat hire sorw eche
with sorowe / when þei han mysauenture
And listen nougth to seche hem ooþer cure
¶ Men seyn to wrecche is consolacion
to haue a noþer felaw in his peyne
Þat ought wel ben oure opynyon
For bothen þow and I of loue we pleyne
So ful of sorw am I soth for to seyne
Þat certanly no more harde grace
may sitte on me / for why þer is no space
¶ If god wil þow art nought agast of me
lest I wol of þi lady þe bigile
Þow woste þi self / whom þat I loue pardee
As I best kan / gon sithen longe while
And sith þow wost I do it for no wile
and sith I am he þat þow tristest moost
Tel me som-what syn al my wo þow woste
¶ Ȝet troilus for al þis [no] worde sayde
But longe he lay / as stille as he dede were
And after þis with sikynge he abreyde
And to pandarus voice he lente his ere
And vp his eighen cast he þat in feere
was pandarus / leste þat in frenesye
He sholde falle / or ellis sone dye
¶ And criede awake ful wondurliche and charpe
what slombrestow as in litargye
Or artow like an asse to þe harpe
That hereth sown whan men þe strenges plye
Bot in hys mynde of þat no melodye
May synken hym to gladden for þat he
So dul is of his bestialitee
¶ And wiþ þat Pandare of his wordes stente
But Troilus ȝet hym nothynge answerde
For why / to tellen nas not his entente
To neuere no man / for whom þat he so ferde
For it is seyde / men makeþ of a ȝerde
wiþ which þe maker is hym self ybeten
In sondry manere / as þise wyse treten
¶ And nameliche in his counseylle tellynge
Þat towcheth loue / þat oughte ben secree
For of hym self it wol nought out sprynge
But if þat it þe bette gouerned be
Ek som tyme it is a craft to seme flee
Fro thynge / which in effect men hunte faste
Al þis gan Troilus in his herte caste
¶ But nathelees when he hadde herde hym crye
Awak / he gan to syken wonder sore
And seyde frende / þoughe that I stil lye
I am not deef / now pees and crye namoore
For I haue herde þi wordes and þi loore
But suffre me my myschief to bywayle
For þi prouerbes may me nought avaylle
¶ Nor other cure kanstow none for me
Eke I nyl not ben cured / I wol dye
What know I. of þe quene Nyobe
Lat be þin olde ensaumples I þe preye
No quod tho Pandarus þer-fore I seye
Swiche is delit of fooles to be-wepe
Hyre wo / but seken boote thei ne kepe
¶ Now knowe I þat þer reson in þe failleth
But tel me / if I wyste what she were
For whom þat the al þis misauenture ailleth
Dorstestow þat I tolde in hyre ere
Þi wo / syth þow darst nought þi self for feere
and hyre bysought on þe to han som routhe
whi nay quod he by god and by my trouthe
¶ What nat as bisily quod pandarus
As though myn owen lyfe lay on þis nede
No certes brother quod þis Troilus
and whi / for þat þow sholdest neuere spede
wostow þat wele / ȝe þat is out of drede
quod troilus / for al þat euere ȝe konne
She nyl to noon swhich wreche as I ben wonne
¶ Quod pandarus allas what may þis be
Þat thow despired art þus causelees
what lyueth nat þi lady bendistee
How wostow so that þow art graceles
Swhiche yuel is nat alwey bootelees
why put nat impossible þus þi cure
Syth þinge to come / is oft in auenture
¶ I graunte wel þat þow endurest wo
as sharpe / as doth tycius in holle
Whos stomak fowles tyren euere mo
Þat hyghten Volturis / as bokes telle
But I may noth endure þat þow dwelle
In so vnskilful an opynyon
Þat of þi wo is no curacion
¶ But oones nyltow for þi coward herte
And for þin ire / and foolysh wilfulnesse
For wantruste tellen of þi sorwes smerte
Ne to þin own help / don besynesse
as muche / as speke a reson more or lesse
But liste as he þat lest of nothynge recche
what woman koude loue sweche a wriche
¶ what may she demen oother of þi deeth
If þow þus deye / and she noot whi it is
But þat for feere / is ȝolden vp þi brethe
For grekis han biseged vs Iwys
Lord which a thank þan shaltow han of þis
Þus wol she seyn and alle þe town atonees
Þe wreche is deed / the deuel haue his bones
¶ Þow mayst allone here wepe and crye and knele
But loue a woman þat she wote it nought
And she wol qwyte þat þow shalt not feele
Vnknow vnkyst / and lost þat is vnsought
What many a man þat loue ful deere a-bought
Twenty wynter þat his lady wyste
Þat neuer ȝyt his lady mouth he kyste
¶ What{punctel} scholde he ther-for fallen in dispayr
Or be recreaunte for his own tene
Or sleen hym self al be his lady faire
Nay nay / but euere in oone be fresch and grene
To serue and loue his deere hertes queene
And thynke it is a guerdon hire to serue
A þowsand folde / moore þan he kan deserue
¶ Of þat worde took hede Troylus
And thought o-none what folye he was Inne
And how þat sothe hym seyde pandarus
Þat for to slen hym self myghte he nat wynne
But bothe doon vn-manhode and a synne
And of his deth his lady nougth to wyte
For of his wo god wote she knewe ful lyte
¶ And with þat þought he gan ful soore syke
And seyd allas what is me beste to do
To whom Pandare answered / if þe lyke
Þe beste is þat þow telle me al þi wo
And have my trouhte but þow it fynde so
I be þi boote / or þat it be ful longe
To pieces do me draw / and sythen honge
¶ Ȝe so þow seyst quod Troylus tho allas
But god woote it nought þe raþer so
Ful harde were it to help in þis cas
For wele fynde I þat fortune is my wo
Ne alle þe men þat ryden konne or go
May of hyre cruel whiel þe harme wiþstonde
For as hire luste she pleyeht with fre and bon̄de
¶ Quod Pandarus / than blamestow fortune
For þow art wrothe / ȝe now at arst I se
wostow nat wel þat fortune is comune
To euery maner wyght in some degre
And ȝet þow hast þis comfort lo parde
Þat as hire Ioyes moten ouer gone
So mote hire sorwes passen euerychone
¶ For if hire whiel stynte any þinge to torne
Þanne cessed she fortune a-non to be
Now sith hire whiel by no way may soiorne
what wastow if hire mutabilite
Ryght as þi seluen list wol don by the
Or þat she be nought fer fro þin helpynge
Paraunter þow hast cause for to synge
¶ And þer-for wostow what I þe be[se]che
Lat be þi wo / and tornynge to þe grounde
For who so liste haue helynge of his leche
To hym behoueth first vnwre his wonde
To Cerberus in helle ay be I bounde
were it for my suster al þi sorwe
By my wille / she sholde al be þin to morwe
¶ Loke vp I seye / and telle me what she is
Anon þat I may gone aboute þi nede
Know iche hire ought / for my loue telle me þis
Þanne wolde I hopen the raþer for to spede
Þo gan þe veyne of troilus to blede
For he was hit / and wex alle rede for chame
A ha quod pandare / here bygynneth game
¶ And with þat worde he gan hym for to schake
And seyde þeef / þow shalt hir name telle
But þo gan sely Troylus for to quake
As þough men sholde han led hym in-to helle
And seyde / allas of al my wo þe welle
Þanne is my swote foo / called cryseyde
And wel neygh with þat worde for feere he deyede
¶ And whan þat pandare herde hyre name neuene
lord he was glad / and seyde frende so dere
Now fare a right for Iouues name in heuene
loue hath by-set þe welle / be of goode shere
For of good name and wisdom and manere
She hath ynough / and ek of gentilesse
If she be fayre / þow wost þi self I gesse
¶ Ny neuere saugh / a moore bountevous
of hyre estate / ne gladder / nor of speche
A frenlyer na moore graciouse
For to do wel / ne lasse hadde nede to seche
what for to don / and al þis bet to eche
In honor to as fer as she may stretche
A kynges herte semeth by hires a wreche
¶ And also thynk / and þer-with gladde þe
Þat syth þi lady vertuouse is alle
So folweth it þat þer is som pyte
Amange alle þis oþer in general
And for-þi se þat thow in speciale
Requere nought / þat is aȝanys hir name
For vertue streccheth naught hym self to shame
¶ But wele is me þat euer þat I was borne
Þat þow bisett art in so goode a place
For by my trouth in loue I dorst haue sworne
Þe sholde neuere han tyd þus fayre a grace
And wostow / for þow were wonte to chace
At loue in scorne / and for despite him calle
Seint ydiot lorde of þise fooles alle.
¶ How often hastow made þi nyce Iapes
and seyde þat loues seruauntȝ euerichon
Of nycete ben verrey goddes apes
And some wold muche hire mete allone
Lyggynge a bedde / and make hem for to grone
And some þow seydest hadde a blaunche feuere
And preydest god he shold neuer keuere
¶ And som of hem / took on hym for þe colde
More þan I-nough / so seydestow ful ofte
And some han feyned ofte tyme and tolde
How þat þei waken whan þei slepten softe
And þus þei wolde han brought hym self a-lofte
And naþelees were vnder att laste
Þus seydestow and Iaped fulfaste
¶ Ȝet seydestow þat for þe moore part
Thyse louers wolden speke in general
And þoughten þat was a syker art
For faylinge for tassayen ouer alle
Now may Iape of þe if þat I shalle
But naþeles þough þat I sholde deye
Þat þow art noon of þo I dorst seye
¶ Now beet thy breest / and sey to god of loue
Þi grace lord for now I me repente
If I misspake / for now my-self I loue
Þus seye with al þin herte in goode entente
Quod Troylus a lorde I me consente
And preye to þe my Iapes þow for-ȝiue
And I schal neuer more whil I lyue
¶ Þow seyst wele quod Pandarus / and now I hope
Þat þow þe goddes wrathe hast al apesed
And sithen þow hast wepen many a drope
And seyd swiche þinge where-with þi god is plesed
Now wold neuere god but þow were esed
And thynke wele she of whom rist al þi wo
Here after may þi comfort ben also
¶ For þilke grounde þat bereth þe wedes wykke
Bereth eke þise holsom herbes / as ful oft
Nexte þe foule netle rough and þikke
Þe rose waxeth swote and smoþe and softe
And next þe valay is þe hille o lofte
And nexte þe derke nyght þe glad morwe
And also loye is next þe fyn of sorwe
¶ Now looke þat a-tempree be þi brydel
And for þe beste ay suffre to þe tyde
Or elles alle oure labour is on ydel
He hasteth wele / þat wysly kan abyde
Be diligent and trewe and ay wele hyde
Be lusti / fre / perseuere in þi seruyse.
And al is wele / if þow wyrke in þis wise
¶ But he þat departed is in euery place
Is no wher hool / as writen clerkes wyse
what wonder is þough swiche an haue no grace
Ek wostow how it fareth of som scruyse
As plaunte a tree or erb in sondry wyse
And on þe morwe pulle it vp as bylyue
No wonder is þough it may neuere þryue
¶ And sith þat god of loue hath þe by-stowede
In place digne vn to þi worþ[y]nesse
Stonde fast / for to goode port hastow rowede
And of þi self for any heuynesse
Hope alwey wele / for but-if drerinesse
Or ouer haste / our bothe laboure schende
I hope of þis to maken a ful gode ende
¶ And wostow why I am þe lesse a-fered
Of þis mater wiþ my nece trete
For þis haue .I. herde seyde of wyse lered
was neuer man or woman þat bigete
Þat was vnapt to soueren loues hete
Celestial / or elles loue of kynde
For-þi som grace / I hope in hyre to fynde
¶ And for to speke of hyre in special
Hyre beaute to be-thynken and hyre ȝouthe
It sitt hyre nought to ben celestial
As ȝet þough þat hir lyste bothe and kouthe
But trewly it sate hire wel ryght nought
A worthy knyght to louen and cherice
And but she do / I holde it for a vice
¶ whar-for .I. am and wol ben ay redy
To peynne me to do ȝow þis seruyse
For boþe ȝow to pleese thus hope I
Here efterwarde / for ȝe ben bothe wyse
And konne it conseyle kepe in swiche a wyse
Þat no man schal þe wyser of it be
And so we may ben gladded alle þre
¶ And by my trouthe I haue right now of þe
A good conceyte / in my wit as I gesse
And what it is / I wol now þat þow se
I thenke / sith that loue of his godenesse
Hath conuerted oute of wikkydnesse
Þat þow shalt ben þe beste post I leeue
of alle his lay and moost his foes to greue
¶ Ensaumple whi / se now þise wyse clerkes
Þat erren aldermost a-ȝayn a lawe
And ben conuerted from hire wikked werkes
Þorwgh grace of god þat list hem to him drawe
Þan are þei folk þat han moost god in awe
And strenghest feythed ben I vnderstonde
And konne an erroure alderbeste withstonde
¶ When Troylus had herd pandare assented
To ben his help in louynge of crisseyde
weex of his wo / as who syth vntormented
But hotter wex his loue and þus he seyde
wiþ sobre chere al-þough his herte pleyde
Now blisful Venus helpe ar þat I sterue
Of þe Pandare I mowe som thanke deserue
¶ But dere frend how shal my wo be lesse
Til þis be don / and goode ek telle me þis
how woltow seyn of me and my destresse
leste she be wroth / this drede I moost I-wis
Or nyl not here / or trowen howe it is
Al þis drede I / and eke for þe manere
Of þe hyre Em / she nyl no swich þinge here
¶ Quod Pandarus þow hast a ful grete care
lest þat þe cherl may falle out of þe moone
why lord I hate of þe þi nice fare
why entremette of þat þou hast to doone
For goddes loue I bydde þe a boone
So lat malon / and it schal be þi beste
why frend quod he / now do right as þe leste
¶ But herk Pandare o worde for I nolde
Þat þow in me wendest so grete folye
Þat to my lady I desyren scholde
Þat towcheth harme or any vilanye
For dredeles me ware leuere deye
Þan she of me aught ellis vndirstode
But þat þat myght sownen in-to goode
¶ To lough þis Pandare and anon answerde
And I þi borugh / fy no wyght doþe but so
I roughte naught þough þat she stode and herde
How þat þow seyste but fare wel I wol go
A dieu / be glad / go saue us bothe two
Ȝif me þis labour and þis bysynesse
And of my speede / be þin alle þat swettenesse
¶ Þo Troilus gan doun on knees to falle
And Pandare in his armes hente faste
And seyde / now fy on þe grekes alle
Ȝet pardee god schal help us at þe laste
And dredelees if þat my lif may laste
And god to-forne / lo som of hem shal smerte
And ȝet mathynketh þat þis a-vaunte may sterte
¶ Now Pandare I kanne no more seye
But thow wys / þow wost / þow mayst / þow art alle
My lyf / my deth / hool in þin honde I leye
Helpe now quod he / ȝis by my trouthe I shal
God ȝelde þe frend / and þis in special
Quod Troilus þat þow me recomaunde
To hire þat to þe deeth me may comaunde
¶ This pandarus tho desyrous to serue
His ful frend / þan seyd in þis manere
Far wele / and thenk I wole þi thank deserue
Haue here my trouthe / and þat þow schalt wele here
And went his wey / þenkynge on þis matere
And how he best myȝte hire beseche grace
And fynde a tyme ther-to and a place
¶ For euery wyght þat hath an house to founde
Ne renneth naught þe werk for to bygynne
with rakel hond / but he wol byde a stounde
And sende his hertes lyne out fro with-Inne
Alderfirst his purpos for to wynne
Al þis Pandare in his herte thoughte
And caste his werk ful wysly ar he wroughte
¶ But troylus lay þo no langer down
But vp a-none vp on his steede bay
And in þe feelde he pleyde þo leoune
wo was þat grek þat wiþ hym mette a day
And in þe town his maner þo forth ay
So goodely was / and gat hym so in grace
That ech hym loued / that loked on his face
¶ For he by-come þe frendlyest wyght
Þe genlyest / and ek þe moost free
Þe thriftiest / and oone þe best knyght
Þat in his tyme was or myghte be
Dede ware his Iapes and his crueltee
His hieghe porte / and his manere estraunge
And ech of hem gan for a vertu chaunge
¶ Now lat vs stynte of Troylus a stounde
Þat fareth lyk aman þat hurte is soore
And is some deel of akynge of his wound
Ylissed wel / but heeled no deel more
And as an esy pacient þe loore
Abit of hym / þat gothe aboute his cure
And þus he dryeth forth his auenture

HEADNOTE.P: [Out of MS. Gg. 4. 27, University Library, Cambridge, the first 2 leaves of the Troilus have been cut.]
[Cambridge Univ. MS. Gg. 4. 27, vellum, ab. 1425 A. D. leaf 14: leaves 12 and 13 have been cut out.]

LG.L: ¶ So whan þat kalkas knew be kalkelyng
And ek be answere of þis Appollo
Þat Grekys schulde swich a pepele bryng
Þorow wheche þat troye muste be for-do
he caste anon out of þe toun to go
ffor wel woste he be sort þat Troye schulde
Dystroyed ben ȝe wolde ho so nolde
.. ffor wich to departyn softely
Tok purpos ful þis for-knowynge wyse
And to þe grekys oft ful preuili
He stal a-non & þey in curteys wyse
Hym dedyn boþe worschepe & seruyse
In trust þat he hath knowynge hem to rede
In euery peryl which þat is to drede
¶ þe noyse vp ros whan it was [. . .
. . . . . no gap in the MS.] spokyn
Þat calcas traytour field was & alyed
With hem of grece & castyn to ben wrokyn
On hym þat hade falsely hys feyt so broke
And seydyn þat he & al hys kyn atonys
Ben worþy to brennyn fel & bonys
..Now hadde calcas lefte in þis myschaunce
Onwost of þis false & wekede dede
Hys doughtyr which þat was in gret penaunce
ffor of hyre lyf sche was ful sore in drede
As sche þat nyste what was best to rede
ffor boþe a wedewe was sche & alone
Of oni frend to whom sche durste hyre mone
¶ Crysseyde was þis ladyis name al ryȝth
As to myn dom in al Troyis cete
Was non so fayr for-passynge euery wyȝt
So aungelli was hyre natyf beaute
Þat lyke a þyng inmortal semede sche
As is an heueneliche parfyt creature
Þat doun were sent in scornynge of nature
¶ Þis lady whych þat herde alday at ere
Hyr faderys schame falsenesse & tresoun
Wol nyh out of hyre wit for sorwe & fere
In wedewys abite blak of samite broun
On kneis be-fore ector sche fel adoun
With petous voys and tenderly wepynge
Hys merci bad hyre selue excusynge
..Now was þis ector petous of nature
And say þat sche was sorwefully begon
And þat sche was so fayr a creature
Of his goodnesse he gladede hyre a-non
And seyde let ȝoure faderis tresoun gon
fforth with myschaunce & ȝe ȝoure self in ioye
Dwellyth with vs whil ȝow good lyste in troye
¶ And al þe honour þat men may ȝow don haue
As fer forth as ȝoure fadyr dwellede here
Ȝe 1 schal haue & men schal youre body save 1 [1-1 by corrector]
As fer as I may ouȝt enquire or here
And sche hym þankede with ful vmble chere
And oftere wolde ȝif it hadde be his wille
And tok hyre leue & hom & held hyre stille
..And in hyre hous sche bod with swych mene
As to honour nede was to holde
And whil sche was dwellynge in þat cete
Kept hire estat & boþe of ȝonge & olde
fful wel belouid & wel men of hire tolde
But wheþer sche þat schilderyn hade or non
I rede it not þerfore I lete it gon
¶ The þyngis fellin as þey don of werre
Be-twixe hem of troye and grekys ofte
ffor sum day bouȝte þe of Troye so derre
And eft þe Grekis founden noþyng softe
Þe folk of Troye & þus fortune onloste
And eyþer ost gan hem to weyle boþe
Aftyr hyr cours ay whil þey were wroþe
¶ But how þis toun come to distruxioun
Ne fallit not to purpos me to telle
ffor it were here a long disgrecioun
ffor myn matyer & ȝow to longe dwelle
But þe troyan gestis as þey felle
In omere or in dares or in dyte
ho so can may rede hem as þey wryte
..But þow þat grekys hem of troye schentyn
And here cete besegede al aboute
Here olde vsage nolde þey not letten
As for to honoure here god ful deuoute
But aldermost in honour out of doute
Þey haddyn a relike hyȝt paladion
Þat was here trost a-boue hem euerychon
¶ And so befel whan comyn was þe tyme
Of aperille whan cloþid is þe mede
With newe grene of lusti ver þe prime
And swete smelle flouris whyte & rede
In sundery wyse schewede as I rede
Þe folk of troye þe obseruaunce olde
Palas dionis feste for to holde
..And to þe temple in al here beste wyse
Yn general þere wente manye a wyȝt
To herkenyn of palladyons seruise
And namely so manye a lusty knyȝt
So many a lady frosch [h by corrector] & maydyn bryȝt
fful wel arayed boþe meste & leste
Ȝe boþe for þe sesoun & þe feste
¶ Among þese oþere folk was Cresseyde
In wedewys abite blak but neuere þe les
Ryȝ as oure fyrst letter is now an .A.
In beaute fyrst so stod sche makeles
Hyre goodeli lokyng gladede al þe pres
Nas neuer ȝit seyen þyng to be preyse derre
Nor vndyr cloude blak so bryȝt a sterre
¶ As was Crisseyde fok seyde euerychone
Þat hire byhildyn in hyre blake wede
And ȝit sche stod ful stylle & lowe alone
By-hyndyn oþere folke in lityl brede
And ney þe dore vndir schamys drede
Symple of a-tyr & deboner of chere
With ful answered lokyng and manere
..Þis troylis as he was wone to gide
Hyse ȝynge knyȝtis lad hem vp & doun
In þe ilke large temple on euery syde
By-holdynge alle þe ladyis of þe toun
Now here now þere for non deuocioun
Hade he to non / to reuyn him his reste
But gan to prisyn / & lakkyn whan hym leste
¶ And in his walk faste he gan to wayten
Ȝyf kynȝt or squyer of his cumpany
Gan for to sykyn or let his eyen baytyn
On ony woman þat he coute aspy
He wolde smyle & holde it foly
And seyde him þus god wot sche slepith ful softe
ffor loue of þe / whan þu turnyst ful ofte
¶ I haue pardeux herd [herd later] of ȝoure lyuynge
Ȝe loueris & ȝoure lewede obseruaunces
And which a labour folk han in wynnynge
Of þe loue & in þe kepynge which dotaunce
And whanne ȝoure pray is lost wo & penaunce
Verray folis and blynde be ȝe
Þere nys not on þat can war by oþere be
¶ And with þat word he gan caste vp his browe
Asscauunis [c corrected] lo is not þis wel spokyn
At whiche þe god of loue gan loke rowe
Ryȝt for dispit & schop for to ben wrokyn
He ked a-non his bowe nas not brokyn
ffor sodeynly he hit hym at þe fulle
And ȝit as proud a pekok can he pulle
¶ O blynde world o blynde entencioun
How ofte fallyt al þeffecte contrarye
O sirquide & foule presumcioun
ffor cauȝt is proud & caut is debonoyre
Þis troylis is clombyn on þe steyre
And lityl wenyth þat he mot dessendyn
But alday faylyt þyngys þat folis wendyn
..As proude bayard [corrected] gynnyth for to skyppe
Out of þe woye so prykyth hym his corne
Tyl a lasche [corrected] haue of þe longe wyppe
Þanne þynkyth he þow I praunce al a-forn
ffyrst in þe trays ful fat & newe schorn
Ȝit am I but an hors & horsis lawe
Is ffor [corrected] tendure and with hyse [corrected] ferys drawe
¶ So ferde it by þis ferse & proude knyȝt
Þow he a worþy kyngis sone were
And wende noþyng hadde had swych amyȝt
A-ȝens his will þat schulde his herte stere
Ȝit with a lok his herte wex al fere
Þat he þat now was most in pryde aboue
Wex sodeynly most subiecht on to loue
..ffor-þy ensaumple takyt of þis man
Ȝe wise proude & wordely folk alle
To skorne loue wheche þat somme can
Þe fredam of ȝoure hertys to hym þralle
ffor euere it was & euere it schal be-falle
Þat loue is he þat alle þynge may bynde
ffor may no man for-do þe lawe of kynde
¶ þat þis be soþ hath preuyd & doþ ȝit
ffor þis trowe I ȝe knowe alle or some
Men redyn not þat folk han grettere wyt
Þan þey þat most with loue haþ ben nome
And strengest folk han þerwith ben ouercome
Þe worþiest & grettest of degre
Þis was & is & ȝit men schal it se
¶ And treweliche it seyth wel to be so
ffor aldyrwysest han þerwith ben plesid
And þey þat han ben aldyrmost in woo
With loue han ben most confortid & esed
And ofte it haþ þe crewel herte apesid
And worþy folk mad worþiere of name
And caused most to drede vice & schame
..Now syþe it may not godly be withstonde
And is a þyng so vertuous & kynde
Refuseþ it not to loue for to be bonde
Syþe as hymself lest he may ȝow bynde
Þe ȝerde is bet þat bowe wele & wynde
Þan þat þat brestyt & þerefore I ȝow rede
To folwyn loue / þat so wel can ȝow lede
¶ But for to tellyn forþe in specyal
Of þis kyngis sone / of whych I tolde
And letyn oþere þyngis collatrial
Of hym þynke .I. myn tale to holde
Boþe of hise ioyes / & of hise carys colde
And al his werk / as touchynge þis matere
ffor I it can / wel þerto refere
..With-inne þe temple he wente hym forth pleyinge
Þis Troylis of euery wyȝt aboute
On þis ladi & now on þat lokynge
Where sche were in toune or with oute
And vp on cas / fel þat þou a route
his eyȝen perseydyn / & so depe it wentyn
Tyl on cresseide it smot & þere it stente
..And sodeynly he wex þerwith astonyd
And gan bet hire biholde / in þryfty wyse
O merci god þouȝte he / where hast þou wonyd
Þat art so fayr & so godli to deuyse
Þerwyt his herte gan to sprede & ryse
And softe he sykyd lest men myȝte hym here
And cauȝte a-ȝyn his forme pleynynge chere
¶ Sche was not with þe leste of stature
But alle hyre lemys so wel answerynge
Where to woman-hode þat creature
Nas neuere lasse namely in semynge
And ek þe pore wyse of hire menyng
Schewede wel þat men myȝtyn in hyre gesse
Honour estat wommanly noblesse
..þo troylys wondyr wel with alle
Gan for to like hyre menynge & hyre chere
Wych sumdel deynous was for sche let falle
Hyre lok a lytil and seyde in swych manere
Aschaunis may I not stonde here
And aftyr þat hyre lokynge gan sche lyȝth
Þat neuere þoughte him sen so good a syȝth
¶ And of hyre lok in hym þere gan to queken
So gret desyr & swych affeccyoun
Þat in his herte boteme gan to quekyn
Of hyre his fyx & depe enpressioun
And þow he erst hade pourede vp & doun
He was þo glad hise hornys in to schrynke
Vnneþe woste he to loke or [a later to stuck in] wynke
..Lo hym þat let hym seluen so kunnynge
And scornede hem þat louys peynys dryen
Was ful on-war þat loue hade his dwellynge
With-inne þe subtyl stremys of hyre eyȝen
Þat sodeynly hym þouȝte for to deyen
Ryȝt with hyre lok þe spryt of his herte
Blessed be loue þat þus folk can conuerte
¶ Sche þis in blak lokynge to Troylys
Ouer alle þynge stod for to behelde
Ne his desyr ne war for he [corrected] stod þus
He neyþer schyr made ne word tolde
But from affer his maner for to holde
On oþer þyng sumtyme his lok he caste
And eft on hyre whilys þat seruyse laste
¶ And aftyr þis not fully alle askapide
Out of þe temple al eselyche he wente
Repentynge hym þat euere he iapide
Of louys folk lest fully þe descente
Of schorn fel on hym selfe but what he ment
Lest hit were wyst on ony manere syde
Hys wo he gan dissymylyn & seyde
..whan he was þus from þe temple departid
He styrte a-non vp to þe paleys turnyth
Ryȝt with hyre lok þour-schotyn & þour-dartyd
Al feynyþ he in lust þat þe soiournyth
And al his chyr & speche also he bornyth
And ay of louys seruauntys euery whyle
Hym self to wryþe at hym self ganto smyle
¶ And seyde lord so ȝe loue al in [r corrected] rest
Ȝe loueris for þe kunnyngest of ȝow
Þat seruyth most ententifully & best
Hym tyt as ofte harm þerof as prow
Ȝoure hyre is quyt aȝen god wot how
Not wel for þey wil schorne for good seruyse
Yn fay ȝoure ordere is rewelyd in good wyse
..In veyn sertayn ben alle ȝoure obseruauncis
But ȝif it / a fewe poyntis be
Ne no þyng askyth so gret intendauncis
As doþ ȝoure lay as knowyn alle ȝe
But is not þe werste so mot I þe
But tolde I ȝow þe werste poynt I leue
Al seyde I soþ ȝe wolde at me greue
¶ But þis þat ȝe loueris ofte eschewe
Or ellis don of good entencioun
fful ofte þyn lady wil it mysconstrewe
And deme it harm by hyre opinyoun
And ȝit ȝif sche for oþir entencioun
Be wroþ þan / that þou han a groyn a non
Now wel is hym þat may ben of ȝow on
¶ But for al þis whan þat he say his tyme
He held his pes non oþere bote him gayned
ffor loue he gan hyse federis so to lyme
Þat wel onneþe on-tyl his folk he faynid
Þat oþere busy nedis hym destreyned
ffor wo was hym þat what to done he nyst
But bad hyse folk to gon where hem lyst
..And whan þat he was in chambere a-lone
He doun vp on his bedis fet hym sette
And fryst he gan to sike & eft to grone
And þoughte so ay on hire with-oute lette
Þat as he sat & wok his spyrit mette
Þat he hire saw & temple & al þe wyse
Ryȝt of hire lok & gan it newe avyse
¶ þus gan he make a myrour of his mynde
In wich he say al holly hire figure
And þat wel he coude in his herte fynde
It was to hym riȝt a good auenture
To loue swychon & ȝif he dede his cure
To seruyn hyre ȝit myȝte he fallyn in grace
Or ellis for on of hyre seruauntis pace
..Imagenynge þat neyþer trauayle nor gaine
Ne myȝte for so godli on ben lorn
As sche ne hym for his desyr ne schame
Al were it wyst but in preys & vp born
Of alle loueris wel more þan by-forn
