Þus argumentid he in his gynnynge
fful on-avised of hise wocomynge
¶ þus tok he purpos louys craft to schewe
And seyde he wolde worschepe preuyly
ffyrst to hydyn his desyr in mewe
From euery wyȝt I-born al vttyrly
But he myȝt ouȝt recouered be þerby
Remembrynge hym þat loue to wyde I-blowe
Ȝildyth bittere freut þow swete seed be sowe
¶ And oueral þis meche more he þouȝte
What for to spek & what to heldyn in
And what for to artyn hire to loue he souȝte
And on a song a-non ryȝt to begyn
And gan loude on his sorwe towyn
ffor whiche good hope he gan fully assente
Cresseyde to loue & not forto repente
¶ And of þe song not only þe sentence
As wryt myn autour callid lollyous
But pleynly saue oure tungis differens
I dar wel say in al þat troylys
Seyde in his song lo euery word riȝt þus
As I schal sayn & ho so leste it here
Lo next þis vers he may it fynde here

LG.HEAD: (58) (From Petrarch.) Cantus [in margin]
LG.L: ..Ȝif no loue is O god what fele I so
And ȝif loue is what þyng & which is he
Ȝif loue be good from whennys comyt myn wo
Ȝif it be / awondyr þynkyth me
whanne euery turnement & aduersite
Þat comyth of hym may to me sauery þynke
ffor ay I preste þe more þat I drynke

LG.HEAD: (59) (From Petrarch.)
LG.L: ..And ȝit þat at myn owene lust I brenne
ffrom whenys comyth myn wele & myn pleynte
Ȝif harm a-gre me I wherto pleyne þenne
I not ne why onwery þat I feynte
O quyk deþ O swete harm so queynte
How may of þe in me swych quantite
But ȝif þat I consente / þat it be

LG.HEAD: (60) (From Petrarch.)
LG.L: ¶ And ȝif þat I consente / I wrongfully
Compleyne I-wis þus possed to & fro
As stereles wyȝt in a bot am I
Amyde þe se be-twexe wyndis too
Þat in contrayre stondyn euere mo
Allas what þis wondyr maladye
ffor cold of hete for hete of cold I. deye
LG.TRAILER: (End of Troilus's Song from Petrarch's 88th Sonnet.)

LG.L: ¶ And to þe god of loue þus seyde he
With petous voyce a lord now ȝoure is
Myn spyryt þe wheche þat auȝte ȝoure be
Ȝow þanke I lord þat broute me to þis
But wheþer goddes or woman I.-wys
I not wych þat ȝe don me serue
But as hyre man I wolde ay lyue & sterue
..Ȝe stondyn in hyre eyȝen myȝtily
As in a place on-to ȝore vertu dygne
Wherefore lord ȝif myn seruyse or I
May lykyn ȝow so beþ to me benygne
ffor myn estat / ryal I resyne [resyne corrected]
In to hyre hond & with ful vmble chere
Be-come hyre man as to myn lady dere
¶ In hym ne deyned to spare blod ryal
Þe fyr of loue wherefrom [corrected] god me blys
Ne hym forbar in no degre of alle
Hys vertu or his excellent prowesse
But helde hym as his þral lowe in distresse
And brende hym so / in sundery wyse ay newe
Þat sexty tyme a day he loste his hewe
..So mechil day from day his owene þought
ffor loue to hyre gan quekyn & encrese
Þat euery oþer charge he sette at nouȝt
ffor-why ful ofte his hote fyre to cece
To sen hyre goodly lok he gan to prese
ffor þerby to ben esed wel he wende
ffor ay þe ner he was þe more he brende
¶ ffor ay þe ner þe fyer þe hattere is
Þis trowe I knowyth al þis cumpanye
But were he fer or ny I dar sey þis
Be nyȝt or day / be wisdem of folye
His herte wich / þat is his brestys eyȝe
Was ay on hyre / þat fayrere was to sene
Þan euere were elyne / or polexene
¶ Ek of þe day þere passede not an oure
Þat of hym self a þousent syþis seyde
God goodly to whom I serue & laboure
As I best can now wolde god cresseyde
Ȝa wolde on me rewe or þat I deyede
Myn dere herte allas myn hele & hewe
And lyf is lost but ȝe on me rewe
..Alle oþere dredis were from hym fled
Boþe of þe asege and his sauacioun
Nyn hym desyred non oþer founys bred
But argumentis to his conclusion
Þat sche on hym wolde haue compascioun
And he to ben hire man whil þat he may dure
Lo here his lyf & from þe deþes cure
¶ þe scharpe schourris felle of armys proue
Þat ector or hise oþere breþeren deden
Ne madyn hym only þerfore onys moue
And ȝit was he where so men wente or ryden
ffounde on of þe beste & lengest tyme abyden
Þere peryl was & dede ek swych trauayle
In armys þat to þynke it was merauayle
..But for non hate he to þe grekys hadde
Ne also for þe rescous of þe toun
Ne made hym þus in armys for to madde
But only lo for þis conclusioun
To like hyre þe bet for his renoun
ffrom day to day in armys so he spedde
Þat þe grekys hym as of þe deþ dredde
¶ And from þis forth þo refte hym loue his slep
And made his mete his fo {punctel} & ek his sorwe
Gan multepleye þat who so tok kep
It semede in his hewe on euyn & on morwe
Þerfore a tytele he gan hym for to borwe
Of oþere seknesse lest men of hym wende
Þat þe hote fuyr of loue hym brende
¶ And seyde he hadde a feuere & ferde al amys
But hou it was serteyn I can not sey
Ȝif þat his lady vndyrstod not þis
Or feynede hyre he nyste on of þe tweye
But wel rede I þat be no maner weye
Ne semed it þat sche of hym rouȝte
Or of his peyne or what so euere he þouȝte
..But þanne fel to þis troylys so meche wo
Þat he was wol nygh wod. for ay his drede
Was þis þat sche / sum wyȝt hade louyd so
Þat neuere of hym sche wolde a takyn hede
ffor þat cause he þouȝte his herte blede
Ne of his wo ne durste he not begynne
To telle hyre for al þis world to wynne
¶ But whanne he hadde a space from his care
Þus tyl hym self ful ofte he gan to pleyne
He seyde O fol art þou now in þe snare
Þat whilhom iapedyst at louys peyne
Now art þou hent now gnaw þyn owen cheyne
Þou were ay wonyd eche louere reprehende
Of þyng from which þou can þe not defende
..What wele now euery louere seyn of þe
Ȝif þis be wyst / but euere in þyn absence
Laughyn in scorne & seyn lo þere goþ he
Þat is þe man of so gret sapience
Þat held vs loueris best in reuerence
Now þankyd be god he may gon in þe daunce
Of hem. þat loue lust febly for to auaunce
¶ But O þou woful troylys god wolde
Seþ. þou muste loue þour þyn destene
Þat þou be set where · on swechou · þat schulde
Knowe al þyn woo / al lakkede hyre pete
But also cold in loue towardys þe
Þyn lady is as frost in wyntyr mone
And þou fordon. as snow in fyre is sone
¶ God wolde I were aryuyd in þe porte
Of deþ þe wheche myn sorwe wolde me lede
A lord to me it were a gret confort
Þanne were I quit of languissyng in drede
ffor by myn hed sorwe Iblowe on brede
I schal beiapid ben a þousent tyme
More þan þat fole / of whos foly men ryme
..But now help god / & ȝe swete for whom
I pleyne. I-kauȝt / ȝe neuere wyȝt so faste
O mercy dere herte / & help me from
Þe deþ {punctel} for I whil myn lyf may laste
More þan myn selue. wylle loue ȝou to myn laste
And with sum frendli lok / gladede me swete
Þouȝ neuere noþyng more ȝe me behete
¶ þese wordys / & ful manye anoþer to
Spak & euere he callyd / in his compleynte
Hire name for to tellyn hire his wo
Til nyȝ þat he in salte teris drenkte
Al was for nouȝt sche herde nouȝt his pleynte
And whan he þouȝte on þat folye
A þousent fold his sorwe gan multeplye
..By-wailyng in his chambir þus a-lone
A frend of his þat callyd was pandaris
Came onys in on-war and herdde hym grone
And say his frend in distresse & care
Allas quod he ho causeþ al þis fare
O mercy god what on-hap may þis mene
Han now þus sone grekys mad þe lene
¶ Or hast þou sum remors of concience
And art now falle in sum deuocyoun
And waylyst for þyn synne & þyn offence
And hast for ferd cauȝt attriciouun
God saue hem þat han be segit oure toun
Þat so cunne leyn oure iolite on presse
And brynge oure lusty folk in holynesse
¶ þese wordis seyde he for þe nonys alle
Þat with sweche þyngis he myȝte him angery make
And with an angyr don his sorwe falle
As for þe tyme and his corage a-wakyn
But wel woste he as fer as tungis spakyn
Þere nas a man of grettere hardynesse
Þan he ne more desirede worþynesse
..What cas quod he or what mysauenture
Hadde gydit þe to se myn languissyng
Þat am refus of euery [or every] cryature
But for þe loue of god at myn preying
So hene awoy for sertys myn deying
Wele þe dissese & I mote 2 nedys deye 2 [2-2 corrector]
Þerfore go awoy þere nys no more to seye
¶ But ȝif þou wene I be þus sek for drede
It is not so & þerfore skorne me nouȝt
Þere is a noþer þyng I take of hede
Wel more þan ouȝt þat þe grekys han wrouȝt
Which cause is of myn deþ for sorwe & þouȝt
But þow þat I ne tellit þe ne lest
Be ȝe not wroþ I hyde it for þe best
..þis pandare þat wol ner mast for wo & rewthe
ffull ofte seyde allas what may þis be
Now frend quod he ȝif euere loue or treuthe
Haþ ben er þis be-tweþe þe & me
Ne do þou neuere swich a crewelte
To hydyn from þyn frend swich a care
Wost þou not wel þat it am I Pandare
¶ I wele partyn with þe al þyn peyne
Ȝif it be so I do þe non confort
As it is frendis ryȝt / soþ for to seyne
To interpartyn wo {punctel} as god disport
I haue & schal / for trowe or fals report
In wrong & ryȝt / loued þe al myn lyf
Hyd not þyn wo from me / but telle it blyue [Lines 582 to 595 were repeated in the MS. on leaf 21, back, and struck out by the rubricator.]
¶ þanne gan þis sorweful troylys sike
And seyde hym þus god leue it be myn best
To telle it þe / for sythe it may be like
Ȝit wele i telle it þe þow myn herte brest
And wele wot I þou mayt do me no rest
But lest to deme I truste not to þe
Now herkene frend for þus it stondith with me
..Loue a-ȝens whiche. who so defendyth
Hym selue most{punctel} al þere lest auaylyth
With disespeyr. so sorweful me offendyth
Þat streyt on to þe deþ myn herte saylyth
Þerto desyr so brenynge me assaylyth
Þerto ben slayn It were a gret ioye
To me{punctel} þan kyng of grece ben & Troye
¶ Suffyseþ þis myn fulle frend Pandare
Þat I haue seyd / for now hast þou myn wo
And for þe love of god myn colde care
So hyde it wel / for I tolde it neuere to mo
ffor harmys myȝtyn fallyn mo þan too
Ȝif it were wist but be þou in gladnesse
And let me sterue / onknowe of myn distresse
¶ How hast þou þus onkendely & longe
Hid þis from me / þou fool quod pandaris
Parauenture þou mayȝt aftyr swichon longe
Þat myn auys a-non may helpyn vs
Þat were a wondyr þyng quod Troylys
Þou coudyst neuere .in loue þyn selue wisse
How del mayst þou / bryngyn me to blysse
..Ȝa troylys now herkene / quod pandare
Þow I be nyse it happyþ ofte so
Þat on þat exces doþ ful euele fare
By good consayl may kepe his frend þerfro
I haue myn saelue / sen a blyng man go
Þere as he fel þat coude loke wyde
A fol may ek a wys man gyde
¶ A weston is non keruyng instrument
But ȝit it makyth scharpe keruyng tolys
And ȝif þou wyst þat I haue ouȝt mys went
Excuse þou þat for swich þyng to þe skole is
Þus ofte wyse men / ben war by folys
Ȝif þou do so þyn wyte is wel be-waryd
By his contrarye is euery þyng declarid
..ffor hou myȝte euere swetnesse a be knowe
To him þat neuere tastid bittyrnesse
Ne no man wot what gladnesse is I trowe
Þat neuere was in sorwe or in sum distresse
Ek whyt by blak be schame ek worþynesse
Eche set by oþer more for oþer semyth
As men may sen & so þe wise demyn
¶ Syþe þus in too contrarijs is on lore
I þat haue in loue so ofte asayed
Greuaunce ouȝte come / & wel þe more
Conseyle þe of þat þou art a-mayede
And ek þou not to ben euele payede
Þow I desese / with þe for to bere
Þyn heuy charg / it schal þe lasse dere
¶ I wot wel þat it faryth þus by me
As to þyn broþer Parys & hierdesse
Whech 1 that clepyde was senome 1 [1-1 corrector]
Wrot in a compleynt of hire heuynesse
Ȝe say þe lettere þat sche wrot I gesse
Nay neuere ȝit I-wis 2 quod Troylys 2 [2-2 corrector]
Now quod Pandaris herkenyt it was þis

LG.HEAD: (95) (Oenone's Letter to Paris. 1 st.)
LG.L: ..Phebus þat fyrst found art of medicynys
Quod sche & curere [corrected] in euery wyȝtis care
Remedye & red by herkis he knyt fyne
Ȝit to hym self his cunnyng is ful bare
ffor loue hadde so boundyn in a snare
As for þe douȝtyr of kyng Amete
Þat al his craft ne coude [corrected] his sorwe bete
¶ Ryȝt so fare I onhaply for me
I loue on best & þat me smertyth sore
And ȝit parauenture can I rede þe
And nouȝt myn self repreue me no more
I haue no cause I wot wel for to sore [next line in MS. scratcht out, then, l. 671
As doþ an hauk þat lestyþ for to pleye
But to þat helpe sumwhat I can seye
..And of on þyng ryt sekyr mayt þou be
Þat certeyn for to deyen in þe peyne
Þat I schal neuere more discouere þe
Ne be myn trouthe I kepe not restreyne
Þe from þyn loue þow It were Elyne
Þat is þyn broþeris wyf ȝif ich it wiste
Be what sche be & loue hire as þou lyste
¶ þerfore as frend fullych in me assure
And telle me plat what is þyn entencioun
And finially cause of wo þat þe endure
ffor doutyth no þyng myn entencioun
Ne is not to ȝow of reprehencioun
To speke as now for nowyȝt may bereue
A man to loue til hym luste to leue
¶ And þerfore wetyth wel þat boþe to ben vicis
Mistrostyn al or eɫɫ [elles] al leue
But wel I wot þat it no vice is
ffor forto trostene sum wyȝt is a preue
ffor-þi of treuthe / wolde I fayn remeue
Þyn wrong confort & do þe sum wyȝt truste
Þyn wo to telle & tel me ȝif þou lyste
..þe wise seyeth wo is hym þat is a lone
ffor and he falle he ne haþ non helpe to ryse
And syþe þou hast a felawe tel þyn mone
ffor þis nys not certeyn þe nexte wyse
To women loue as cechyn vs þe wysse
To walwe & wepe as I Nyob þe quene
Whos teris ȝit in marbil ben sene
¶ Let ben þyn wepynge & þyn drerynesse
And let vs wisse with oure speche
So may þyn woful tyme seme lesse
Delite not in wo þy wo to steche [or sceche]
As don þese folis þat here sorwys eche
With sorwe whan þey han mys auenture
And liste not to seche hem oþer cure
..Men seyn to wreche is consolacioun
To han a noþer felawe in his peyne
Þat auȝte wel to ben oure opinyoun
ffor boþe þou & I of loue we pleyne
So ful of sorwe am I soþ for to seyne
Þat certeynly no more harde grace
May sittyn on me for why þere nys non space
¶ Ȝyf god wil þou art not agast of me
Lest I wolde of þyn lady þe begile
Þou wost þyn self hom þat I loue parde
As I best kan gon [corrected] sithe longe while
And sey þou wilt it do for no gyle
And seyst þou þat I am he þat þou trostyst most
Tel me sumwhat syþyn al myn wo þou wyst
¶ Ȝit troylis for al þis no word seyde
But longe he lay as stylle & he dede where
And aftyr with sykynge he a-breyde
And to pandarys voys he bente his ere
And vp hise eyen caste he þat in fere
Was pandaris lest þat in frenesye
He schulde falle or eɫɫ sone deye
..He cryede a-wake ful wondyrliche & scharpe
What slomberyst þou as in lytargye
Or art þou lyk an asse to þe harpe
Þat heryth soun whan men þe stryngis pleye
But in his mynde of þat no melodye
May synkyn hym to gladdyn for þat he
So dul is of his bestialte
¶ And why þat pandarys of hise wordys stente
And troylys ȝyt hym non word answeryd
ffor why to tellyn was not his entent
To neuere no man for whom þat he so ferde
ffor it is seyd men makyth ofte a ȝerde
With whiche þe makere is hym self I-bete
In sundery maner as þese clerkis trete
..And nameliche in his conseyl tellyng
Þat touche loue þat auȝte to be secre
ffor of hym self it wele Inow out sprynge
But ȝif þat it þe bettyr gouerned be
Ek it is a craft for summe / sumtyme to fle
ffor þyng which in effecte men hunte faste
Al þis gan troylys in his herte caste
¶ But neuere þe les whan he hadde herd hym cry
A-wake he gan to sike wondyr sore
And seyde frend þow I stille lye
I nam not def / lye stylle & crye no more
ffor I haue herd þyne wordis & þyn lore
But suffere me myn myschif to be-waylyn
ffor þyne prouerbis moun me not auaylyn
¶ ffor oþer cure canst þou non for me
Ek I wele not ben cured I wele deye
What knowe I of þe quene Neoble
Let ben þyne olde examplys I þe preye
No quod pandarys þerfore I seye
Swich is delyt of folys to be-wepyn
Here wo but sychen bote þey ne kepyn
..Now I knowe þat þere resoun in þe faylyth
But telle me ȝif I wyste wych sche were
ffor whom al þis auenture mys-aylyth
Durstyst þou þat I told hyre in hyre ere
Þyn wo syþe þou darst not for fere
And hyre be-southe on þe to han sum reuthe
Why nay quod he by god & by myn treuthe
¶ What not as busily quod pandarys
As þow myn owene lyf laye on þis nede
No certys broþer quod þis tr[o]ylys
And why / for þat þou schuldyst neuere spede
Wost þou þat wel{punctel} ȝa þat is out of drede
quod troylys for al þat euere ȝe cunne
Sche wele to non swich wreche as I ben wonne
..Quod pandaris allas what may þis be
Þat þou dispeyred art þus causeles
What lyuyth not þyn lady benediste
How wost þou so þat þou art graceles
Swych euyl is not alwoy boteles
Why put not impossible þus þyn cure
Swich þyng to come is ofte in auenture
¶ I graunte wel þat þou enduryst wo
As scharpe as doþ he which is in helle
Whois stomak foulys tyryn euere & oo
Þat hyȝte wulturnus as bokys telle
But I may not endure þat þou dwelle
In so onskylful opynyoun
Þat of þe wo is non curacyoun
¶ But onys nylt þou for þyn coward herte
And for þyn yre & foly wilfulnesse
ffor wantrost tellyn of þynne sorwis smerte
Ne to þyn owene hele don besynesse
As meche as specke a resoun more or lesse
But lych as he þat leste of no þyng reche
What woman coude loue swich a wreche
..What may sche demyn / ouȝt of þyn deþ
Ȝif þou þus deye & sche not why it is
But þerfore fere is ȝuldyn vp þyn breþ
ffor Grekys han besegit vs I-wis
Lord wych a þank schuldyst þou han of þis
Þus wil sche say & al þe toun at onys
Þe wreche is ded þe deuyl haue hyse bony[s]
¶ þu mayȝt a-lone [a-boue corrected] hire wepe crye & knele
But loue a woman þat sche wote it not
And sche wele quite it þat þou schalt not fele
Vn-knowe on-kyst & lost þat is on-souȝt
What manye a man haþ loue ful dere abouȝt
Twenty wyntyr þat his lady not wyst
Þat neuere ȝit his ladyis mouth he ne kyst
..What schulde he perfore falle in dispeyr
Or ben recreaunt for his owene tene
Or slen hym selfe al by his lady fayre
Nay nay but euere in on boþe frossche & grene
To leuyn & to seruyn his dere lady quene
And þynkyn it is a gerdoun hyre to seruyn
A þousent fold more þan he can deseruyn
¶ And of þys word tok hed troylys
And þouȝte a non what foly he was inne
And hou þat soþ hym seyde pandaris
Þat for to slen hym he myȝte not wynne
Boþe to don on-manhod & a gret synne
And of his deþ his lady not to wyte
ffor of hys wo god wot sche k[n]ew but lyte
¶ And with þat þouȝt he gan ful sore syke
And seyde allas what is me best to do
To whom pandare answerde ȝyf þe lyke
Þe beste is þat þou telle me þyn wo
And haue myn treuthe but þou fynde it so
I be þyn bote or þat it be ful longe
To pecys do me drawe & sythe me honge
..Ȝa so seyst þou quod Troylys þo & allas
But god wot it is not þe raþere so
fful harde it were to helpyn in þis cas
ffor wel fynde I þat fortune is myn fo
Ne alle þe men þat ryde cunne or go
May of hyre whel / þe harm wel with-stonde
ffor as hyre lust sche pleyeþ with fre & bonde
¶ Qud pandaris þanne blamyst þou fortune
ffor þou art wroþ now / ȝa [other letters scratcht out] at [other letters scratcht out] e [other letters scratcht out] I see
Wost þou not wel þat fortune is comune
To euery maner wyȝt in sum de-gre
And ȝit þou hast þis confort lo parde
Þat as hyre ioye motyn ouergon
So motyn hire sorwys passyn euerychon
..ffor ȝif hire whelys styntyn ony þyng to turne
Þanne sesed sche / anon fortune to be
Now sythe hire whel ne may in no woye soiourne
What wyst þou ȝyf hire mutabilitie
Ryȝt as hire self lust wele don by þe
Or þat sche be now [now, overline, later] fer from þyn helpynge
Perauenture þou hast cause for to synge
¶ And þerfore wost þou I þe be-seche
Let be þyn wo / & turnynge to þe ground
ffor ho so lyst [lyst, overline, later] haue helpyng of his leche
To hym by-houyth fyrst onwrye his wounde
To serberus in helle ay be I bounde
Were it for myn sustyr al þyn sorwe
By myn wil [sche] schulde be þyn to-morwe
¶ Loke vp I say & tel me what sche is
A-non þat I may gon a-bout þyn nede
Knowe I hire ouȝt for myn loue tel me þis
Þat wolde I hope raþere for to spede
Þo gan þe veyne of Troylis for to blede
ffor he was hurt & wex al red for schame
A .a. quod Pandarys here be-gynnyth game
..And with þat word he gan hym for to schake
And seyde Ȝ scratcht out] if þou schalt hire name telle
But þo gan sely troylis for to quake
As þow men schulde han hym in to helle
And seyde allas of al myn wo þe welle
Þanne is myn swete fo callyd Crisseyde
And wol ner with þe word for fer he deyede
¶ And whan þat pandarys herde hyre name nemene
Lord he was glad & seyde frend so dere
Now fare a ryȝt for iouys name in heuene
Loue þou hast be-set wel / be of good chere
ffor of good name / wisdom & manere
Sche haþ I-now / & ek of gentillesse
Ȝyf sche be fayr / þou wyst þyn self I gesse
..Ne neuere ne say a more / bountyuous
Of hire estat / non / gladere ne of speche
A frendelyere / ne non more gracious
ffor to don wel ne lasse hadde nede to seche
What for to don & al þis bet to eche
In honour to as fer as sche may streche
A kyngis herte semyth bi hire awreche
¶ And also þyng & þerwith gladde þe
Þat sythyn þyn lady vertyuous is al
So folwyþ it / þat þere is sum pete
A-mong alle þese oþere / in general
And for þis se pat þow in specyal
Requere nat þat is a-ȝens hire name
ffor vertu strechith nouȝt hym self to schame
¶ But wel is me þat euere þat I was born
Þat þou be-set art / in so good a place
ffor myn trouthe in lyue / I durst a sworn
Þere schulde neuere in loue / han tyd þus fayr a grace
ffor wost þou why / þou were wone to chase
At loue on skorn / & for dispit hym calle
Seynt ideot / lord of folis alle
..How ofte hast þou mad / þyne nyse iapis
And seyd þat louys seruantis / euerychon
Of nycete ben but very gydde apis
And some wolde frete / meche here mone alon
Lyinge in bedde / & make hem for to gron
And some þou seydist / hade / a blaunche feuere
And preyedist to god / he schulde neuere keuere
¶ And some of hem tok on hem for þe cold
More þan I-now / so seydist þou ful ofte
And some han feyned / ofte tyme & told
How þat þey wake / whan þey slepe softe
And þus wolde a brouȝt hem self a lofte
And neuer þe les weryn vndyr at þe laste
Þus seydist þou / & iapedist ful faste
..Ȝit seydist þou þat for þe more part
Þese louerys wolde speke in general
And þouȝtyn þat it was a sekyr art
ffor failyng to a-sayen oueral
Now may I iapyn of þe ȝif þat I schal
But neuer-þeles þow I schulde deye
Þat þou art non of þo I durste seye
¶ Now bete þyn brest & sey to god of loue
Þyn grace lord for now I me repente
Ȝif I mys spak / for now myn self I loue
Þus say with al þyn herte in good entent
Quod Troylis a lord I me consent
And prey to þe myne iapis þou for-ȝeue
And neuere more wele iape whil I leue
¶ Þow sest wel quod pandarys & now I hope
Þat þou þe goddesse wrethe hast a-pesed
And syþe þat þou hast wepyn manye a drope
And seyd swych þyng wherwith þyn god is plesed
Now wolde neuere god but þou were esid
And þynke wel sche / of whom ryseþ al þyn wo
Here aftyr may þyn confort ben also
// ffor þynke ground þat beryth þe wedis wikke
Beryth ek þese holsome erbis / as ful ofte
Noþer [Noyeþ corrected] þe foule nettyl row & þekke
Þe rose wexit swete sauery & softe
And next þe valy is þe hil on lofte
And next þe derke [corrected] nyȝt þe gladde morwe
And alse þe ioye is next þe fyn of sorwe
¶ Now loke þat atempere wel þyn brydil
And for þe beste ay suffere to þe [f scratcht out] yde
Or ellis al oure labour is in ydil
He hastyth wel þat wisely can abide
Be diligent & trewe & ay wel hide
Fe lusty fre perseuere in þyn seruyse
And al is wel ȝif þou were in þis wyse
// But he þat partyd is in euery a place
Is nowher hol as wryte clerkys wise
What wondyr ist þow swich on haue no grace
Ek wost þou how it faryth of sum seruyse
As plante a tre or erbe in sundery wise
And on þe morwe felle it as blyue
Now wondyr ist þow it may neuere þryue
¶ And siþe god of loue haþ þe be-stowyd
In place digne on to þyn worþynes
Stond faste for to good port hast þou rowid
And of þyn self for ony heuynesse
Hope slwoy wel þat but ȝif dreurynesse
Or for euere hast þou oure boþis labour schende
I hope of þis to make a good ende
¶ And wost þou wel whi I am þe lasse aferyd
Of þys matyr with myn nece trete
ffor þis haue I herd seyd of leryd [ryd, corrector]
Was neuere non woman ȝit be-gete
Þat was on-hapi to soffere louys hete
Celestial or ellys loue of kynde
ffor-þy sum grace / I hope in hyre fynde
// And for to speke of hyre in specyal
Hyre beaute to be-heldyn & hyre ȝouþe
It sit hire not to be celestial
As ȝit þat hire lyste boþe & couþe
But trewely it sat hire wel riȝt nouþe
A worþy knyȝt to loue & cherice
And but sche do I holde it for a vice
¶ Þerfore I am & wele be al redy
To peyne me to don þis seruyse
ffor boþe ȝow to plese þis hope I
Here aftyrward for þe ben boþe wyse
And cunne conseyle & kepe in swich a wyse
Þat no man schal þe wysere of it be
And so we may be gladit alle þre
// And be myn treuthe I haue ryȝt now of þe
A good conseyt in myn wit as I gesse
And what it is I wele now þat þou se
I þynke to sey þat loue of his goodnesse
Hath þe conuertyd out of þyn wekedenesse
Þat þou schal be þe beste post I leue
Of al his lay & most his fois greue
¶ On-saumpele why se now þese grete clerkys
Þat arn aldyr most a-ȝen a lawe
And ben conuertyd from alle here wekede werkys
Þour grace of god þat lyste hem to hym drawe
Þanne are þey folk þat han god most in awe
And strengest fichid ben I vndyr-stonde
And cunnyn an erour aldyr best withstonde
¶ Whan Troylis hadde herd Pandaris assentyd
To ben his helpe in louynge of crysseyde
Wex of his wo as ho sey onturnementyd
But hottere wex his loue & þanne he seyde
With sobre chere as þow his herte pleyede
Now blysful venus help er þan I sterue
Of þe Pandare I may sum þank deserue
// But dere frend how schal myn wo ben lessed
Tyl þis be don & goode ek telle þou me þis
How wilt þow seyn of me & myn distresse
Lest sche be wroþ þis drede I most I-wis
Or nyl not heryn or trowyn how it is
Al þis dred I ek for þe manere
Of þe hyre em / sche wyl no swich þyng here
¶ Quod pandaris þu hast a wol gret care
Lest þat þe cherl / may falle out of þe mone
Whe lord I hate of þe / þyn nyse fare
Why entermetyst þe / of þyng þou hast not to done
ffor goddys loue / I bidde þe a bone
So let me a lone & it schal be þyn best
Why frend qud he now do ryȝt as þou lest
// But herke Pandare o word for 1 I ne wolde 1 [1-1 corrected]
Þat þou in me wendyst so gret folye
Þat myn lady. I desyryn schulde
Þat touchith harm or ony velenye
ffor dredles me were leuere deþe
Þat sche of me ouȝt ellis vndyrstode
But þat þat myȝte sounyn in to goode
¶ Þo low þis pandarys & a-non answerde
And I þyn borw nonwyt doþ but soo
I rouȝte not þow sche stod & herde
How þat þou seyst but fare wel I wele goo
Adew be glad god spede vs boþe too
Ȝif me þis labour & þis besinesse
And of myn sped be þyn al þe swetnesse

HEADNOTE.P: [Campsall MS, leaf 17, back.]

DIV3.HEAD: Hic Incipit Liber Secundus.

LG.HEAD: (1) (Proem)
LG.L: Owt of þese blake wawes for to sayle.
O wynd o wynd þe weder gynneth clere.
For yn þis see þe bot hath swych trauaylle.
Of my comynge that vnneþe I it stere.
This see clepe I þe tempestous matere.
Of desper þat Troylus was Inne.
But now of hope þe kalendes bygynne.

LG.HEAD: (2) (Invocation)
LG.L: O lady myn þat called art Cleo.
Thow be my sped fro þis forth and my muse.
To ryme wel þis book til I haue do.
Me nedeth here noon art to vse.
For-whi to euery louere I me excuse.
That of no sentement I þis endite.
But out of latyn in my tunge it write.
Wherfore .I. nel haue neyþer þank ne blame.
Of al þis werk but pray yow mekely.
Disblameth me yf ony word be lame.
For as myn auctor seyde so sey .I.
Ek þough I speke of loue vnfelyngly.
No wonder is / for it no þyng of newe is.
A blynd man ne kan Iuggen wel yn hewys.
Ye knowe ek þat in forme of speche is chaunge.
with-Inne a thousand yer / and wordes tho.
That hadden prys. now wonder nyce and straunge.
Vs thenkeþ hem / and yet þey spak hem so.
And sped as wel yn loue as men now do.
Ek for to wynne loue yn sondry ages.
In sondry londes{punctel} sondry ben vsages.
And for-thi yf it happe yn ony wyse.
That here be ony louere yn þis place.
That herkeneth as þe story wole deuyse.
How Troylus com to his lady grace.
And þenketh so nold I not loue purchace.
Or wondreth on his speche and his doyng.
I not but it is me no wonderynge.
For euery wyght whiche that to rome went.
Halt nat al o path or alwey o manere.
Ek yn some lond were al þe game shent.
If þei ferd yn loue as men don here.
As þus in opyn doyng or yn chere.
In vysitynge in forme or seyde hire sawes.
For-þi men seyth eehe contre hath hise lawes.
Ek skarsly ben þere yn þis place þre.
That han yn loue seyd lyk and don yn al.
For to þi purpos þis may lyken þe.
And þe right nought yet al is seyd or shal.
Ek som men graue in tre some in ston wal.
As it bitit. but syn I haue begonne.
Myn Auctor shal I folwe if I konne.

DIV3.P: Incipit liber. Secundus.

LG.L: IN may þat moder is of monethes glade.
That [fl alterd to fr] fresshe floures blew and white and rede.
Ben quyke a-gayn þat wynter dede made.
And ful of bawme is fletynge euery mede.
whan Phebus doth his bryghte bemes sprede.
Right yn þe white bole so it bytydde.
As I shal synge on mayes day þe þridde.
That Pandarus for al his wyse speche.
Felt ek his Part of loues shotes kene.
That koude he neuere so wel preche.
It made his hewe a day ful ofte grene.
So shop it þat hym felt þat day a tene.
In loue for which yn wo to bedde he wente.
And made er it was day ful many a went.
The swalwe proigne with a sorwful lay.
whan morwe com. gan make here weymentynge.
whi she forshapen was / and euere lay.
Pandare a bedde half yn a slomerynge.
Til she hym so neigh made here cheterynge.
How Tireux gan forth hire suster take.
That with þe noyse of here he gan a-wake.
And gan to calle and dresse hym vp to ryse.
Remembrynge hym his erand was to done.
From Troylus and ek þe gret emprise.
And cast and knew yn good plyt was þe mone.
To don viage and tok weye soone.
Vn to his neces Paleys þer by syde.
Now Ianus god of entre thow hym gyde.
Whan he was come vn to his Neces place.
wher is my Lady vn to hire folk seyde he.
And þey hym tolde. and he yn forth gan pace.
And fond two oþere ladyes sette and she.
wiþ-Inne a paued parlour / and þei þre.
Herden a mayden reden hem þe gest.
Of þe sege of þebes while hem leste.
Quod Pandarus ma dame god yow see.
with al yowre faire bok & al þe companye.
Ey vncle myn welcome y-wys / quod she.
And vp she ros / and by þe hond yn hye.
She tok hym fast / and seyde þis nyght þrie.
To good mot it turne of yow I mette.
And with þat word she doun on bench hym sette.
Ȝe nece ye shal fare wel the bet.
If god wole al þis yer quod Pandarus.
But I am sory I haue yow let.
To herken of youre book ye preysen þus.
For goddes loue what seith it telle it vs.
Is it of loue som good ye me lere.
Vncle quod she youre maystresse is not here.
With þat þei gonnen laughe and she seyde.
This romaunce is of Thebes þat we rede.
And we han herd how þat the kyng Layus deyde.
Thurgh Edyppus his sone and al þat dede.
And here we stenten at þese lettres rede.
How þe bisshop as þe bok kan telle.
Amphiorax fyl þurgh þe ground to helle.
Quod Pandarus al þis knowe I my selue.
And al þe assegé of Thebes and al þe care.
For herof ben þere maked bokes twelue.
But lat be þis and telle me how ye fare.
Do wey youre barbe and shewe youre face bare.
Do wey youre book rys vp and late vs daunce.
And lat vs don to may som obseruance.
A god forbede quod she be ye mad.
Is þat a wydewes lyf so god you saue.
By god ye make me right sore a-drad.
Ye ben so wylde it semeth þat ye raue.
It sat me wel bet ay in caue.
To bydde and rede on holy seyntes lyues.
Lat maydens gon to daunce and yonge wyues.
As euere I þriue quod Pandarus.
Yet kowde I telle a pyng to don yow pleye.
Now vncle dere / quod she tel it vs.
For goddes loue is þanne þe assege a-weye.
I am of Grekes so ferd þat I deye.
Nay nay quod he as euere mot I þryue.
It is a þyng is worth such fyue.
Ye holy god quod she what þyng is that.
what bet þan swych fyue .I. nay I-wys.
For al þis world ne kan I reden what.
It sholde ben / som Iape I trowe is þis.
And but youre seluen telle what it is.
My wit is for to arede it al to lene.
As help me god I not not what ye mene.
And I youre bourgh ne neuere shal for me.
This þing be tolde to yow as mote I þryue.
And why so vncle myn why so quod she.
By God quod he / that wole I telle as blyue.
For proudder womman were þere noon on lyue.
And ye it wyste yn al þe toun of troye.
I iape nought as euere haue I Ioye.
Tho gan sche Iape more þan byforn.
A þousand fold. and doun hire eyen caste.
For neuere sith þe tyme þat she was born.
To knowe ȝyng desired she so faste.

To don þat þyng as wel as hardynesse.
And eke to sen hym yn his gere hym dresse.
So fressh / so yong / so weldy semed he.
It was an heuene vp-on hym for to se.
His helm to-hewe was yn twenty places.
That by a tissew heng his bak byhynde.
His sheld to-dasshed was with swerdes and maces.
In which men myghte many an arwe fynde.
That þrilled hadde horn and nerf and rynde.
And ay þe peple cryede here comeþ oure Ioye.
And nexst his brother. holdere vp of Troye.
For which he wex a litel red for shame.
whan he þe peple vp-on hym herde cryen.
That to biholde it was a noble game.
How sobrelyche he caste doun his eyen.
Cryseyde gan al his chere aspien.
And let it so softe yn hire herte synke.
That to hire seluen she seyde who yaf me drynke.
For of here owene þought she wex al red.
Remembrynge here right þus lo þis is he.
which þat myn vncle swereth he mot be ded.
But I on hym haue mercy and pite.
And wiþ þat þought for pure a shamed she.
Gan yn here hed to pulle and þat as faste.
whil he and al þe peple forth by paste.
And gan to casten and rollen vp and down.
with-Inne here þought his excellent prowesse.
And his estat and also his renoun.
His wit [his] shap and ek his gentillesse.
But most hire fauour was for his distresse.
was al for here / and þought it was a rouþe.
To slen swych on yf þat he mente trouþe.
Now myghte som enuyous Iangle þus.
This was a sodeyn loue how myght it be.
That she so lyghtly louede Troylus.
Right for þe firste syght ye parde.
Now who so seyth so mot he neuere þe.
For euery þyng a gynnyng hath it nede.
Er al be wrought with-outen ony drede.
For I sey nought þat she so sodeynly.
Yaf hym here loue / but þat she gan enclyne.
To lyke hym first and I haue told yow why.
And after þat his manhod and his pyne.
Made loue with-Inne hire for to myne.
For which by proces and by good seruice.
He gat here loue and in no sodeyn wyse.
And also blisful Venus wel arayed.
Sat in here seuenethe hows of heuene þo.
Disposed wel and wiþ aspectes payed.
To helpen sely Troilus of his wo.
And soth to seyn she nas not al a fo.
To Troilus in his natiuyte.
God wot that wel þe sonner spedde he.
Now lat vs stynte of Troylus a þrowe.
That rideth forth and late vs tourne faste.
Vn-to Criseyde þat heng here hed ful lowe.
Ther as she sat allone. and gan to caste.
wher on she wolde a-poynt hire at þe laste.
If it so were hire Em ne wolde cesse.
For Troilus vp-on here for to presse.
And lord so she yn þought gan to argue.
In þis matere. of which I haue yow told.
And what to done best were & what eschue.
That plitede she ful ofte in many folde.
Now was hire herte warm now was it colde.
And what she þoughte somwhat shal I write.
As to myn Auctor lysteth for to endite.
She þought wel þat Troylus persone
She knew by sight and ek by gentillesse
And thus she seyde al were it nought to done.
To graunte hym loue / yet for his worþynesse.
It were honour with pley and with gladnesse.
In honeste / with swych a lord to dele.
For myn estat / and also for his hele.
Ek wel wot I my kynges sone is he.
And sith he hath to se me swych delit.
If I wolde vttirly his sight fle.
Paraunter he myght haue me yn dispit.
Thurgh which I mygh stonde in worse plyt.
Now were I wys me hate to purchace.
with-outen nede þere I may stonde in grace.
In euery þyng I wot þere lith mesure.
For þough a man forbede dronkenesse.
He nought for-bet þat euery creature.
Be drynklees / for alwey as I gesse.
Ek for me sith I wot is al his distresse.
I ne ought not for þat þyng hym despise.
Sith it is so he meneth in good wyse.
Eke .I. knowe of long tyme a-gon.
Hise þewes goode and þat she is not nyse.
Ne auaunter certeyn seyth men is he non.
To wys is he to do so gret a nyse.
Ne als I nel hym neuere so cherishe.
That he may make avaunt by Iuste cause.
He shal me neuere bynde yn swich a clause.
Now set a cas þe hardest is wys.
Men myghten deme þat he loueþ me.
what dishonour were it vn-to me þis.
May I hym lette of þat why nay parde.
I knowe also and alday here and se.
Men louen a woman al bysyde hire leue.
And whanne hem leste nomore lat hem byleue.
I þenk ek how he able is to haue.
Of al þis ilke noble town þe þryftiest.
To ben his loue so she here honour saue.
For out and out he is þe worþiest.
Saue only Ector which þat is þe best.
And yet his lyf al lyth now in my cure.
But swych is loue and ek myn auenture.
Ne me to loue a wonder is it nought.
For wel wot I my self so god me spede.
Al wolde I þat noon wyste of þis þought.
I am one þe fairest out of drede.
And goodlyest who-so taketh hede.
And so men seyn yn al þe town of Troye.
what wonder is it þough he of me haue Ioye. [Ioye is written in a later hand.]
I am myn owene woman wel at ese.
I þank it god / as after myn estat.
Right yong and stond vntyd in lusty lese.
with-out Ialousye or swych debat.
Shal non hosbonde seyn to me chekmat.
For eiþer þey ben ful of Ialousye.
Or maisterful or louen nouellerye.
What shal .I. don to what fyn lyue thus.
Shal I nat louen in cas yf þat me lyst.
What par dieux I am not religious.
And þough þat I myn herte sette at reste.
Vpon þis knyght þat is þe worþieste.
And kep alwey myn honour and my name.
By al right it may do me no shame.
But ryght as whanne þe sonne shyneth bright.
In Marche þat chaungeth ofte tyme his face.
And þat a cloud is put with wynd to flyght.
which ouer-sprat þe sonne as for a space.
A cloudy þought gan þorugh hire soule pace.
That ouer-spradde here brighte þoughtes alle.
So þat for fere almost she gan to falle.
That þought was þis allas syn I am fre.
Sholde I now loue and put yn Iupartie.
My sikernesse and þrallen liberte.
Allas how dorste I þenken þat folye.
May I nought wel in oþer folk aspie.
Hire dredful Ioye here constreynt and here peyne.
There loueth noon þat she nath weye to pleyne.
For loue is yet þe meste stormy lyf.
Right of hym self þat euere was by-gonne.
For euere som mystrust or nyce stryft.
Ther is in loue som cloud is ouer þat sonne.
Ther-to we wrecched wommen. no þyng konne.
whan vs is wo but wepe and sitte and þynke.
Oure wreche is þis oure owene wo to drynke.
Also þese wikkede tonges ben so prest.
To speke vs harm / ek men be so vntrewe.
That right a-noon as sesed is here lest.
So cesseth loue and forth to loue an newe.
But harm I-don / is don who-so it rewe.
For þough þese men for loue hem ferst to-rende.
Ful sharp bygynnynge{punctel} breketh ofte at þe ende.
How ofte tyme hath it knowe be.
The treson þat to womman hath be do.
To what fyn is swych loue I kan not se.
Or wher bycomþ it whenne it is go.
Ther is no wyght þat wot I trowe so.
wher it bycometh lo no wyght on it sporneth.
That erst was no þyng in-to nought it torneþ.
How bysy if I loue ek most I be.
To plesen hem þat Iangle of loue and dremen.
And coye hem þey sey noon harm of me.
For þough þere be no cause yet hem semen.
Al be for harm þat folk here frendes quemen.
And who may stoppe euery wykked tungen.
Or sown of belles whanne þat þei be rungen.
And after þat here þought bygan to clere.
And seyde he which þat no þyng vnder-taketh.
No þyng ne acheueth be hym loth or dere.
And with an oþer þought hire herte quaketh.
Than slepeþ hope and after dred a-waketh.
Now hot now cold / but þus by-twyxen tweye.
She rist here vp / and went here for to pleye.
Adoun þe steyre a-noon right þo she wente.
In to þe gardeyn with here neces þre.
And vp and doun þere made many a wente.
Flexippe she Tharbe and Antigone.
To pleyen þat it Ioye was to se.
And oþere of here wommen a gret rowte.
Here foleweden yn þe gardeyn al a-bowte.
This gardeyn was large and rayled aɫɫ þe aleyes.
And shadwede with bowes blosmy and grene.
And benched newe and sonded alle þe weyes.
In which she walketh arm yn arm by-twene.
Til at þe laste Antigone þe shene.
Gan on a Troian song to synge clere.
That it an heuene was hire voys to here.

LG.HEAD: (119) (Antigone's Song of Love. St. 1.)
LG.L: She seyde .O. loue to whom I haue and shal.
Ben humble subgit trewe yn myn entente.
As I best kan to yow lord yeue ych al.
For euere more myn herte lust to-rente.
For neuere yet þi grace no wyght sente.
So blysful cause. as me my lyf to lede.
In al Ioye and surete out of drede.

LG.HEAD: (120) (Antigone's Song of Love. St. 2.)
LG.L: Þe blisful god han me so wel beset.
In loue y-wys þat al þat bereth lyf.
ymagynen ne kowde how to ben bet.
For lord with-outen Ialousye or stryf.
I loue oon which is most ententyf.
To seruen wel vnwery or vnfeyned.
That euere was and lest with harm distreyned.
As he þat is þe welle of worþinesse.
Of trouþe ground myrour of goodlyhed.
with Appollo ston of Secrenesse.
Of vertu rote / of luf fyndere and hed.
Thurgh which is al sorwe fro me ded.
I-wys I loue hym best so doth he me.
Now good þryft haue he wher þat he be.
Whom sholde I þanke but yow god of loue.
Of al þis blysse yn which to baþe I gynne.
And þonked be ye lord for þat I loue.
This is þe right lyf þat I am Inne.
To flemen alle manere vice and synne.
This doth me so to vertu for to entende.
That day by day I yn my wil amende.
And who-so seyth þat for to loue is vice.
Or þraldom þough he fele yn it distressse.
He ouþer is enuyous or right nyce.
Or is vnmyghty for his shrewednesse.
To louen. for swych maner folk I gesse.
Defamen loue. as no þyng of it knowe.
They speken but þey bente neuere his bowe.

LG.HEAD: (124) (Antigone's Song of Love. St. 6.)
LG.L: What is the sonne wers of kynde right.
Though þat a man for feblesse of his eyen.
May nought endure on it to se for bryght.
Or loue þe wers þough wrecches on it crien.
No wele is worth þat may no sorwe dryen.
And for-þi he þat hath an hed of verre.
Fro cast of stones war hym yn þe werre.
But I with al myn hert and al my myght.
As I haue seyd wol loue vn-to my laste.
My dere herte and al myn owene knyght.
In whicħ myn herte is growen so faste.
And his in me. þat it shal euere laste.
Al dredde I first to loue hym to bygynne.
Now wote I wel þere is no peril Inne.
And of hire song right with þat word she stynte.
And þerwith-al now nece quod Criseyde.
who made þis song with so good entente.
Antigone answerde a-noon and seyde.
Ma dame I-wys þe goodlyeste mayde.
Of gret estat in al þe town of Troye.
And led here lyf in most honour and Ioye.
Forsothe so it semeth by hire song.
Quod þo Criseyde and gan þer-with to syke.
And seyde lord is þere such blysse among.
These louers as þey konne faire endite.
Ye wys quod fressħ Antigone þe white.
For alle þe folk þat han or ben on lyue.
Ne konne wel þe blysse of loue dyscriue.
But wene ye þat euery wrecche wot.
The parfit blysse of loue why nay y-wys.
They wenen al be loue yf oon be hoot.
Do wey do wey þey wot no þyng of þis.
Men moste axe of seyntes if it is.
Aught faire yn heuene whi for þey konne telle.
And axen of fendes / is it ful yn helle.
Criseyde vn-to þat purpos nought answerede.
But seyde y-wys it wole be nyght as faste.
But euery word which þat she of here herde.
She gan to prenten yn here herte faste.
And ay gan loue hire lasse for to agaste.
Than it dide erst and synken yn hire herte.
That she was somwhat able to conuerte.
The dayes honour and þe heuenes heighe.
The nyghtes fo al þis clepe I þe sonne.
Gan westren faste and downward for to wrye.
As he þat hadde his dayes cours y-ronne.
And white þynges wexen dymme and donne.
For lak of lyght and sterres for to appere.
That she and here folk in went y-fere.
So whan it liked hire to gon to reste.
And voyded were þey þat voyden oughte.
She seyde þat to slepe wel hire leste.
Hire wommen soone til hire bed here broughte.
whan al was hust þanne lay she stille and þoughte.
Of alle þis þyng þe manere and þe wyse.
Reherce it nedeth nought for ye ben wyse.
A nyghtyngale vpon a cedre grene.
Vpon þe chambre wal þere as she lay.
Ful loude sang a-yen þe mone shene.
Paraunter yn his bryddes wyse a lay.
Of loue þat made hire herte fressħ and gay.
That herkened she so longe yn good entente.
That at þe laste þe dede slep hire hente.
And as she slep a-noon right þo here mette.
How þat an Egle feþered whit as bon.
Vnder hire brest his longe clawes sette.
And out hire herte he rente and þat a-noon.
And dide his hert in to hire brest to goon.
Of which she nought a-gros ne no þing smerte.
And forth he fleygh with herte left for herte.
Now late here slepe and we oure tales holde.
Of Troylus þat is to palays ryden.
Fro þe skarmucħ of þe whiche I tolde.
And yn his chambre sit and hath a-byden.
Til two or þre of his messages yeden.
For Pandarus and sought hym ful faste.
Til þey hym founde and brought hym at þe last.
This Pandarus come lepyng in at ones.
And seide þus who hath ben wel y-bete.
To day with swerdes. and with slyng stones.
But Troylus þat hath caught hym now an hete.
And gan to Iape and seyde lord so ye swete.
But rys and late vs soupe and go to reste.
And he answered hym do we as þe leste.
With al þe haste goodly þat þey myghte.
They spedde hem fro souper vn-to bedde.
And euery wyght out at þe dore hym dyghte.
And wher hym lyst vpon his wey he spedde.
But Troilus þoughte his herte bledde.
For wo til þat he herde som tydynge.
He seyde frend shal I now wepe or synge.
Quod Pandarus ly stille and late vs slepe.
And don þyn hod thi nedes sped be.
Chese if þow wolt synge or daunce or lepe.
At short wordes þow shalt trowe me.
Sire my Nece wole do wel by þe.
And loue þe best by god and by my trouþe.
But lat of pursuyte make it in slouþe.
For thus ferforth I haue þi worke bygonne.
Fro day to day til þis day by þe morwe.
Here loue of frendship haue I to þe wonne.
And also hath she leyd hire feyth to borwe.
Algate a fot is hameled of þi sorwe.
what sholde I lengere sermon of it holde.
As ye han herd byfore al he hym tolde.
But right as floures thorugh þe colde of þe nyght.
Yclosed stoupen on hire stalk lowe.
Redressen hem a-yen þe sonne bryght.
And spreden on hire kynde cours by rowe.
Right so gan tho his eyghen vp to þrowe.
This Troylus / and seyde o Venus dere.
Thi might þi grace y-hered be it here.
And to Pandarus he held vp boþe his hondes.
And seyde lord al þyn be þat I haue.
For I am hol al brosten ben my bonden.
A þousand Troians who so þat me yaue.
Eche after oþer god so wys me saue.
Ne myght me so gladen. lo myn herte.
It spredeþ so for Ioye it wole to-sterte.
But lord how shal I don how shal I lyuen.
whanne shal I nexst my dere herte se.
How shal þis longe tyme a-wey ben y-drenen.
Til þat þow be ayen at here fro me.
Thow mayst answere a-byd a-byd but he.
That hangeth by þe nekke soth to seyne.
In grete dishese a-bydeþ for þe peyne.
Al esily now for þe loue of marte.
Quod Pandarus for euery þyng hath tyme.
So longe a-byd til þat þe nyght departe.
For al so syker as þow lyst here by me.
And god toforn I wole be þere at pryme.
And for þi werk somwhat as I shal seye.
Or on som other wyght þis charge leye.
For parde god wot I haue euere yet.
Ben redy þe to serue and to þis nyght.
Haue I nought fayned but emforth my wit.
Don al þi lust and shal wiþ al my myght.
Do now as I shal seye and do a ryght.
And if yow nylt / wyte al þi self þy care
On me ys nought y-long þin yuel fare.
I wot þat thow wysere art þan .I.
A þousand fold but if .I. were a[s] þow.
God helpe me so as I wolde outrely.
Of myn owene hond write here right now.
A lettre in which I wolde here telle how.
I ferd a-mys and here beseche of rouþe.
Now help þi self and leue it not for alouþe.
And I myn self wil þer-with to here gon.
And whanne þow wost þat I am with here þere.
worth vp on a courser right a non.
Ye hardyly yn þi beste gere.
And ryd forth by þe place as nought ne were.
And þow shalt fynde vs yf I may sittynge.
At som wyndowe yn to þe strete lokynge.
And yf þe lyke þan maystow vs saluwe.
And vp-on me make þi contenaunce.
But by þi lyf be war and faste eschuwe.
To taryen ought god shilde vs fro myschaunce.
Ride forth þi wey and hold þy gouernaunce.
And we shal speke of þe som what I trowe.
Than þow art goon to do þyne eeres glowe.
Towchyng þi lettre þat þow art wys ynowh.
I wot þow nylt it digneliche endite.
As make it with þise argumentus towh.
Ne scryuenyssh or craftily þow it wryte.
Be-blotte it with þi teeris eke a lyte.
And yf þow write a goodly word al softe.
Though it be good reherce it not to ofte.
For þough þe best harpour vpon lyue.
wolde on þe best sounded Ioly harpe.
That euere was with all hise fyngres fyue.
Touche ay o streng or ay o werbul harpe.
were hise nayles poynted neuere so sharpe.
It shulde make euery wyght to dulle.
To here his gle and of hise strokes fulle.
Ne Iompre ek no discordaunt þing y-fere.
As þus to vsen termes of Phisyk.
In loues / termes / hold vp þy matere.
The forme alwey / and do þat it be lyk.
For yf a peyntour wolde peynte a pyk.
with asses feet and hede it as an ape.
It cordeth nought / so were it but a Iape.
This counseyl liked wel vn-to Troylus.
But as a dredful louere he seyde þis.
Allas. my dere Broþer Pandarus.
I am a-shamed for to write y-wys.
Lest of myn Innocence I seyde a mys.
Or that she nolde for despit receyue.
Thanne were I ded þere myght it no thing weyue.
To þat Pandare answered yf þe lyst.
Do þat I seye and lat me þerwith gon.
For by hym that formede Est and west.
I hope of it to brynge answere anoon.
Of here hond and yf þat þow nylt non.
Lat be. and sory mot he ben his lyue.
A-yens þi lust þat helpeþ þe to þryue.
Quod Troylus depardieux I assente.
Syn þat þe lyst I wil a-ryse and wryte.
And blysful god I pray with good entente.
The viage an þe lettre I shal endite.
So spede it. and þow Mynerua þe white.
Yef þow me wit my lettre to deuyse.
And set hym down and wrot ryght yn þis wyse.

LG.HEAD: (153) (Troilus's Letter.)
LG.L: Fyrst he gan his right lady calle.
His hertes lyf / his lust his sorwes lece.
His blysse. and ek þis oþere termes alle.
That yn such cas alle þese loueres seche.
And yn ful humble wyse as in his speche.
He gan hym recomaunde vn-to here grace.
To telle al how it axeth muche space.
And after ful louely he here prayede.
To be nought wroth þough he of his folye.
So hardy was to hire to write and seyde.
That loue it made or elles moste he dye.
And pitously gan mercy for to crye.
And after þat he seyde and ley ful loude.
Hym self was lytel worth and lesse he koude.
And þat she wold han his konnyng excused.
That litel was and ek he dredde hire so.
And his vnworþynesse he ay acused.
And after þat þan gan he telle his wo.
But þat was endeles with-outen ho.
And seyde he wolde yn trouþe alwey hym holde.
And radde it ouer and gan þe lettre folde.
And with his salty teres gan he bathe.
The ruby yn his signet and it sette.
Vpon þe wex delyuerlyche and raþe.
Ther-with a þousand tymes er he lette.
He cussed þo þe lettre þat he shette.
And seyde / lettre / a blysful destene.
The shapen is my lady shal þe se.
This Pandarus tok þe lettre and þat by tyme.
A morwe and to his Neces paleys sterte.
And faste he swor þat is was passed pryme.
And gan to Iape and seyde y-wys myn herte.
So fressħ it is al-þough it so smerte.
I may not slepe neuere a Mayes morwe.
I haue a Ioly wo / a lusty sorwe.
Criseyde whan þat she here vncle herde.
with dredful herte and desirous to here.
The cause of his comynge þus answerede.

For whiche with sobre chere here herte lowh.
For who is þat ne wold here glorifye.
To mowen swych a knyght lyue or dye.
But al passe I lyst ye to longe dwelle.
For for o fyn is al þat euere I telle.
The tyme come fro dyner for to ryse.
And as hem oughte aryse euerychon.
And gonne a while of þis and þat deuyse.
But Pandarus brak al þis speche a-noon.
And seide to Deiphebus wole ye gone.
If youre wille be as I yow preyde.
To speke here / of þe nedes of Criseyde.
Eleyne whiche þat by þe hond here held.
To first þe tale and seyde go we blyue.
And goodly on Criseyde she by-held.
And seyde Ioues lat hym neuere þryue.
That doth yow harm and bryng hym soone of lyue.
And yeue me sorwe but he shal it rewe.
If þat I may / and alle folk be trewe.
Teɫɫ yow þi Neces cas quod Deiphebus.
To pandarus / for þow kanst best it telle.
My lordys and my ladyes it stant þus.
what sholde I lengere quod he do yow dwelle.
He rong hem a proces lyk a belle.
Vp-on here fo þat highte poliphete.
So heynous þat men myghte on it spete.
Answere of þis eche worse of hem þan oþer.
And Poliphete þey gonnen þus to waryen.
An-honged be swycħ on were he my broþer.
And so he shal for he ne may not varyen.
what sholde I lengere yn þis tale taryen.
Pleynly al at ones þey here hyghten.
To ben hire helpe yn al þat euere þey myghten.
Spak þan Eleyne and seyde Pandarus.
woot ought my lord my broþer þis matere.
I mene Ector or wot it Troylus
He seyde ye but wole ye now here.
Me þenketh þis / sith þat Troylus is here.
It wore good. If þat ye wolde assente.
She told here self / hym al þis er she wente.
For he wole haue þe more here grief at herte.
By cause / lo / þat she a lady ys.
And by youre leue I wole but right yn sterte.
And yow wete and þat a-noon y-wys.
If þat he slepe. or wole ought here of þis.
And yn he lepte and seyde hym in his ere.
God haue þi soule I-brought haue I þe bere.
To smylen of þis gan þo Troylus.
And Pandarus with-oute rekenynge.
Out wente a-noon to Eleyne and Deiphebus.
And seyde hem so þere be no trayinge.
Ne more pres he wole wel þat ye brynge.
Criseyda my lady þat is here.
And as he may endure he wole here.
But wel ye wot þe chaumbre is but lite.
And fewe folk lightly may make it warm.
Now loke ye for I wole haue no wyte.
To bryng yn pres þat myghte don harm.
Or hym dishesen for my bettre arm.
wher it be bet she byde til eft sones.
Now loke ye þat knoweth what to don is.
I sey for me best is as I kan knowe.
That no wight yn ne wente but ye tweye.
But it were I for I kan yn a þrowe.
Reherce here cas vnlyk þat she kan seye.
And after þis she may hym ones preye.
To ben good lord yn short and take here leue.
This may not mechel of his ese hym reue.
And ek for she is straunge he wole for-bere.
His ese. which þat he þar nought for yow.
Ek oþer. þing þat toucher not to here.
He wole me telle I wot it wel right now.
That secret is. and for þe townes prow.
And þey þat no þing knewe of þis entent.
with-oute more to Troilus yn þei went.
Eleyne in al here goode softly wyse.
Gan hym saluwe and womanly to pleye.
And seyde ywys ye moste alweyes a-ryse.
Now fare broþer beth al hool I preye.
And gan here arm right ouer his sholder leye.
And hym with al here wit to recomforte.
As she best kowde / she gan hym disporte.
So after þis / quod she we yow byseche.
My dere broþer Deiphebus and .I.
For loue of god and so doth Pandare eke.
To ben good lord and frende right hertely.
Vn-to Criseyde which that certeynly.
Receyueth wrong / as wot wel here Pandare.
That kan here cas wel bet þat I declare.
This Pandarus gan newe his tunge affyle.
And al here cas reherce and þat anoon.
whan it was seyd / soone after in a while.
Quod Troylus as soon as I may gon.
I wole right fayn with al my myght ben oon.
Haue god my trouþe here cause to susteyne.
Good þryft haue ye quod Eleyne þe queene.
Quod Pandarus and it youre wille be.
That she may take here leue er þat she go.
O elles god for-bede quod he.
If that she vouche saf for to do so.
And with þat word quod Troilus ye two.
Deiphebus and my suster leef and dere.
To yow haue I to speke of o matere.
To ben auysed by youre red þe bettre.
And fond as hap was at his beddes hed.
The copye of a tretes and a lettre.
That Ector hade hym sent to axen red.
If swych a man was worþi to ben ded.
woot I nought who but in a grysly wyse.
He preyede hem a-noon on it auyse.
Deiphebus gan this lettre to vnfolde.
In ernest gret{punctel} so dede Eleyne þe queene.
And romynge outward fast it gan byholde.
Downward a steyre in to an herber grene.
This ilke þinge þei redden hem by-twene.
And largely þe mountaunce of an owre.
Thei gon on it to rede and to powre.
Now late hem rede and turne we a-noon.
To Pandarus þat gan ful faste prye.
That al was wel and out he gan to gon.
In to þe grete chambre and þat yn hye.
And seyde god saue al þis companye.
Come Nece myn my lady queene Eleyne. [Eleyne later]
Abydeth yow / and ek my lordes tweyne.
Rys take with yow yowre Nece Antigone.
Or whom yow lyst or no fors hardyly.
The lasse pres þe bet come forth with me.
And loke þat ye þonke humbely.
Hem alle þre and whan ye may goodly.
Youre tyme y-se taketh of hem youre leue.
Lest we to longe of his reste hym reue.
Al Incocent of Pandarus entente.
Quod tho Criseyde go we vncle dere.
And arm in arm Inward with hym she wente.
Auysed wel here wordes and here chere.
And Pandarus yn ernestful manere.
Seyde alle folk for goddes loue I preye.
Stynteth right here and softely yow pleye.
Avise yow what folk ben here with-Inne.
And in what plit oon is god hym amende.
And Inward þus ful softely bygynne.
Nece I coniure and heighly yow defende.
On his by-halue which þat vs alle sowle sende.
And in þe vertue of corounes tweyne.
Sle nought þis man þat hath for yow þis peyne.
Fy on the deuel þenk whicħ on he is.
And in what plyt he lith com of a-noon.
Thenk þat al swych taried tid but lost it nys.
That wole ye bothe. seyn whan ye ben on.
Secundelich þer yet deuyneth noon.
Vp-on yow two com of now yf ye konne.
whil folk is blent / lo al þe tyme is wonne.
In titeryng and pursuyte and delayes.
The folk deuyne at waggynge of a stre.
And þough ye wolden han after merye dayes.
Than dar ye nought / and why for she and she.
Spak swych a word þus loked he and he.
Las tyme y-lost .I. dar not with yow dele.
Com of þerfore and bryngeth hym to hele.
But now to yow ye louers þat ben here.
was Troylus nought in a kankedort.
That lay and myghte whysprynge of hem here.
And þought o lord ryght now renneth my sort.
Fully to dye or han a-noon comfort.
And was þe firste tyme he shulde here preye.
Of loue .o. myghti god what shal I seye.

HEADNOTE.P: [Harleian MS 2280, leaf 13, back.]

DIV3.HEAD: Incipit Prohemium secundi libri./

LG.L: Out of þise blake wawes for to saylle
O wynde o wynde / þe weder gynneþ to clere
For in þis see þe boot hath swiche trauaylle
Of my coniynge þat vnnethe I it steere
Þis see clepe I the tempestous matere
Of desespeyre þat Troylus was Inne
But now of hope þe kalendes bigynne

LG.HEAD: Inuocacio (2)
LG.L: ¶ O lady myn þat called art cleo
Þow be my spede / fro þis forth and my Muse
To ryme wel þis book tyl I haue do
Me nedeth here noon ooþer art to vse
For why to euery louer I me excuse
Þat of no sentement I þis endyte
But out of latyn in my tonge it write
¶ Wher-for I nyl haue / neyther þanke ne blame
Of al þis werk / but preye ȝow mekely
Desblameth me / if any worde be lame
For as myn auctor seyde me / so seye I
Ek though I speke of loue vnfelyngly
No wonder is / for it no þinge of new is
A blynde man kan nat Iuggen wel in hewis
¶ Ȝe knowe ek þat in forme of speche is chaunge
with-Inne a thowsand ȝere and wordes tho
That hadden prys / now wonder nyce and straunge
Vs thynketh hem / and ȝet þai spake hem so
And spedde as wele in loue as men now do.
Ek for to wynnen loue in sondry ages
In sondry londes / sondry ben vsages
¶ And for-þi if it happe in any wyse
Þat heere be any louer in þis place
Þat herkeneth as þe story wol deuise
How Troylus com to his lady grace
And thynketh / so nolde nat I loue purchace
Or wondreth on his speche or his doynge
I not but it is me no wondrynge
¶ For euery wyght wheche þat to rome wente
Halt nat o path / or alwey o manere
Ek in some londe were al þe gamen shente
If þat þei ferde in loue as men doon here
As þus / in opyn doynge / or in chere
In visitynge / in forme / or seyde hire sawes
For-þi men seyn eche contree hath his lawes
¶ Ek scarsly ben þer in þis place thre
Þat han in loue seyd lik and done in alle
For to þi purpos þis may liken þe
Quid þe right naught / ȝet all is or schalle
Ek some men graue in tree some in stonwalle
As it bitit but syn I haue bigonne
Myn auctour shal I folwen If I konne.

DIV3.P: Incipit liber secundus.

LG.L: IN may þat moder is of monthes gladde
Þat fressch[e] floures / blew and white and rede
Ben quike agayne / þat wynter dede made
And ful of bawme is fletynge euery mede
when phebus dothe his bryght[e] bemes sprede
Ryght in þe white bool it so bytydde
As I shal synge / on mayes day þe thridde
¶ Þat Pandarus for alle his wyse speche
Felt ek his part of loues shotes keene
Þat koude he neuer so wele of louynge preche
It made his hewe a day ful ofte grene
So shope it þat hym fil þat day a tene
In loue / for whiche in wo to bedde he wente
And made ar it was day ful [ful later] many a wente
¶ So swalwe proignee wiþ a sorwful lay
whan morwe com̄ / gan make hire waymentynge
whi she for-shapen was / and euere lay
Pandare abedde / half in a slomberrynge
Til she so neygh hym made hire chiteringe
How Tryeux gan forth hire suster take
Þat with þe noyse of hire he gan a-wake
¶ And gan to calle / and dresse hym vp to ryse
Remembrynge hym his herand was to done
From Troilus / and eke his grete emprise
And caste and knew in goode plyte was þe moone
To doon viage and take his way ful sone
Vnto his neces paleys ther bysyde
Now Ianus god of entree þow hym gyde
¶ When he was com vn-to his neces place
where is my lady to hire folk quod he
And þei him tolde / and he forth In gan pace
And fond two oþer ladys sete and she
with-Inne a paued parlour and thay þre
Herden a maydyn reden hem þe geeste
Of þe segee of thebes whil hem leste
¶ Quod pandarus / madam god ȝow see
with al ȝoure faire book / and alle þe compaignye
Ey vncle myn / welcome y-wys quod she
And vp she roos / and by þe hond in hye
She took hym fast / and seyd þis nyght thrye
To goode mote it torne / of ȝow I mette
And with þat worde she down on bench hym sette
¶ Ȝe nece / ȝe shal faren wel þe bette
If god wole / alle þis ȝere quod Pandarus
But I am sory þat I haue ȝow lette
To herknen of ȝoure book ȝe preysen þus
For goddes loue / what syth it tel it vs
Is it of loue / o som goode ȝe me leere
Vncle quod she / ȝour maistresse is nat heere
¶ With þat þei gonnen laugh / and þo she seyde
This Romaunce is of thebes þat we rede
And we han herd / how þat kynge layus deyed
Thorugh Edippus his sone / and al þat dede
And heere we stynten at þise letteres rede
How þe bysshop as þe book kan telle
Amphyorax fil þorwh þe grounde to helle
¶ Quod Pandarus al þis know I my-selue
And alle thassage of Thebes and þe care
For her-of ben bokes ther maked Twelue
But lat be þis and tel me how ȝe fare
Do wey ȝoure barbe / and swow ȝoure face bare
Do wey ȝour book / ryse vp and lat vs daunce
And lat vs do to may som obseruaunce
¶ I god forbede quod she be ȝe made
Is þat a wydowes lyf / so god ȝow saue
By god ȝe maken me right soore a-drad
Ye ben so wylde / it semeth as ȝe raue
It sate me wel bet ay in caue
To bydde and rede on holy seyntes lyues
lat maydens gon to daunce and ȝonge wyues
¶ As euere thryue I quod þis Pandarus
Ȝet koude I telle a thynge to don ȝow pleye
Now vncle deere quod she telle it vs
For goddes loue / is þanne thassege a-weye
I am of grekes so ferde that I deye
Nay nay quod he as euere mote I thryue
It is a thynge wel bet þan swiche fyue
¶ Ȝe holy god quod sche / what thinge is þat
What bet þan swiche fyue I nay iwis
For al þis worlde. ne kan I reden what
It sholde ben / som iape I trow is þis
And but ȝoure seluen telle vs what it is
My wit is for thede it al to leene
As helpe me god / I not not what ȝe mene
¶ And I ȝoure borugh / ne neuere shal for me.
Þis thynge be told / to ȝow as mote I thryue
And why so vncle myn / whi so quod sche
By god quod he / þat wil I telle as blyue
For [later a interlined] pruder womman is þare noon on lyue
And ȝe it wist in al þe town of Troye
I iape nought as euer haue I ioye
¶ Tho gan sche wonder / moore þan byforn
A thousand folde / and down hire eighen caste
For neuere siht tyme þat sche was born
To knowe thynge desired she so faste
And with a syhg sche sayde hym atte laste
Now vncle myn / I nyl ȝow nought displese
Nor axen moore þat may do ȝow disese
¶ So after þis with manye wordes gladde
And frendely tales / and with mery cheere
Of þis and þat þay playde and gonnen wade
In many an vnkouth glad and deepe matere
As frendes doon / when they ben met Ifeere
Tyl she gan axen hym how Ector ferde
That was þe townes wal and grekes ȝerde
¶ Ful wele I þonke it god quod Pandarus
Saue in his arme he hath a litil wounde
And eke his freeshe broþer Troylus
The wyse worthy ector þe secounde
In whom þat al vertue liste habounde
As alle trouthe / and alle gentillesse
wysdom / honour fredom and worthynesse
¶ In goode fayth eem quod she þat liketh me
Thay faren wel god saue hem bathe [? a alterd to o]
For treweliche I halde it grete deyntee
A kynges sone in armes wel to do
And ben of goode condicions þer-to
For greete power and moral vertue here
Is selde yseyn in o persone Ifeere
¶ In goode faith þat is sooth quod Pandarus
But by my trouthe þe kyng hath sones tweye
That is to mene Ector and Troylus
Þat certeynly though þat I scholde deye
They ben as voyde of vyces dar I seye
As any men that lyuen vnder þe sonne
Hyre myght is wyde Iknowe and what þei konne
¶ Of Ector nedeth it no more for to telle
In al þis world þer nys a bettre knyght
Þan he þat is / of worthinesse welle
And wel moore vertue hath / þan myght
Þis knoweth many a wys and worthi wyth
The same prys of Troilus I seye
God help me so / I knowe nat swiche tweye
¶ By god quod she / of Ector þat is soth
Of Troilus / the same thyng trowe ·I·
For dredelees men tellen þat he booth
In armys day by day so worthily
And bereth hem here at hoom so gentilly
To euery wyght that alle prys hath he
Of hem þat me were leuest preysed be
¶ Ȝe seye righ sooth ywys quod Pandarus
For ȝersterday who so hadde with hym ben
He myghte han wondred vp-on Troilus
For neuere ȝet so thikke a swarm of been
Ne fleigh / as grekes fro hym gonne fleen
And thorugh þe felde in euery wyghtes ere
Thar nas no cry / but Troilus is þare
¶ Now here now þar he hunted hem so faste
Þer nas but grekes bloode and Troylus
Now he hem hurte and hem alle down he cast
Ay wher he wente / it was a-rayde þus
He was hire deth and sheeld and lif for vs
Þat as þat day þer dorste noon withstonde
whil þat he held his blody swerd in honde
¶ Ther-to he is þe freendlyeste man
Of gret estate / þat euere I saugh my lyue
And wher hym liste best felaweschipe kan
To swiche as hym thynketh able for to thriue
And with þat worde tho Pandarus as blyue
He tooke his leue / and seyde I wol gon henne
Nay blame haue I vncle quod she thenne
¶ what eyleth ȝowe to be thus wery soone
And nameliche of wommen wol ȝe so
Nay sitheth down by god I haue to done
with ȝow to speke of wisdom er I go
And euery wyght that was aboute hem þo
That herd þat gan fer a-wey to stonde
whil þai two hadde alle þat hem liste in honde
¶ when þat hir tale alle brought was to an ende
Of hyre estate / and of hire gouernaunce
Quod pandarus / now is tyme I wende
But ȝet I seye / ariseth lat vs daunce
And cast ȝoure wydowes habit to myschaunce
what luste ȝow þus ȝoure self to disfigure
Syn ȝow is tyd þus fayre an auenture
¶ A wel bythought for luf of god quod she
Shal I nat wyten what ȝe mene of þis
No þis thyng asketh leyser þo quod he
And eke me wold nuch greue I-wys
If I it tolde / and ȝe it told a-mys
Ȝet were it bet my tonge for to stille
Þan seye a sooth þat were aȝenis ȝoure wille
¶ For Nece by þe goddesse Mynerue
And Iuppiter þat makeht þe thonder rynge
And by þe blysful Venus þat I serue
Ȝe ben þe womman in this world lyuynge
with-owten paramours to my wittynge
Þat I best loue / and lothest any to greue
And þat ȝe weten wele ȝoure seluen I leue
¶ Ywys vncle quod she graunt mercy
Ȝoure frendship haue I founden euere ȝit
I am to [no] man holden trewly
So muche as ȝowe / and haue so litil quyt
And with þe grace of god emforth my wyt
As in my gylt I shal ȝou neuere offende
And if I haue or þis / I wol amende./
¶ But for þe loue of god / I ȝowe be-seche
As ȝe ben he þat I loue moste and triste
Lat be to me ȝoure frende maner speche
And say to me ȝoure nece what ȝowe liste
And with þat word hire vncle anoon hire kiste
And sayde gladly loue nece dere
Tak it for goode þat I shal say ȝow here
¶ with þat she gan hire eyghen down to cast
And Pandarus to koghe gan a lyte
And sayde nece alway lo to the laste
How so it be þat som men hem delite
with subtile art hire tales for to endite
Ȝet for alle þat in hire entencioun
Hire tale is al [for] som conclusioun
¶ And sithen thende is euery tales strenghte
And þis matere is so byhouely
what shold I pointe or drawen it on lengthe
To ȝow þat ben my frende so faythfully
And with þat word he gan right Inwardly
Byholden hire and loken on hire face
And sayde on swihch a myroure goode grace
¶ Þan thought he þus of I may my tale endite
Aught hard / or make a processe any while
She shal no sauour han þar-In but lyte
And trowe I wolde hire in my wil bygile
For tendere wittes wenen al be wyle
Þer as þey kan nat pleynly vnderstonde
For-þi hire witte to seruen wol I fonde
¶ And loked on hire in a bysy wise
And she was ware þat he byhelde hire so
And sayd lord so faste ȝe mauyse
Sey ȝe me neuere or now what sey ȝe no
Ȝis ȝis quod he and bett wol er I go
But by my trowthe I thougth now If ȝe
But fortunat / for now men shal it se
¶ For to euery wight som goodly auenture
Som tyme shape if he it kan receyuen
And if þat he wol tak of it no cure
when þat it cometh but wilfully it weyuen
Loo noyther cas nor fortune hym deceyuen
But right his verray slouthe and wrechednesse
And swich a wight is for to blame I gesse
¶ Goode auenture o beale nece haue ȝe
Ful lightly founden and ȝe kanne it take
And for þe loue of god and ek of me
Catche it anon leste auenture it slake
What shold I longer processe of it make
Ȝif me ȝoure hond for in þis world is noon
If þat ȝow liste a wyght so wel bigone
¶ And sith I speke of goode entencion
As I to ȝow haue tolde wele here biforne
And loue as wel ȝoure honour and renown
As creature in al þis world yborne
By alle þe othes þat I haue ȝow sworne
If ȝe be wroth þer-for or wene I lye
Ne shal I neuere sen ȝow eft with eighe
¶ Beth nought agast ne qwaketh wher-to [? wh underdotted for omission]
Ne chaungeth nought for fer so ȝoure hewe
For hardely þe werste of þis is do
And though my tale as now be to ȝow newe
Ȝet trist alwey ȝe shal me fynde trewe
And were it thynge þat me thought vnsittynge
To ȝow wold I no swich[e] tales brynge
¶ Now goode Em for goddes loue I preye
Quod she / com of and tel me what it is
For both I am a-gast what ȝe wil seye
And ek me longeth it to wite I-wis
For whether it be wel or be amys
Sey on / lat me not in þis fer[e] dwelle
So wol I don now herkeneth I shal telle
¶ Now nece myn the kynges dere sone
Þe goode wyse / worthy fresshe and free
which alwey for to don wel is his wone
The noble Troilus so loueth the
Þat but ȝe helpe it wol his bane be
Lo here is alle what shold I more seye
Doth what ȝow list to mak hym lyue or deye
¶ But If ȝe lat hym deye I wol sterue
Haue here my trowth nece I nyl nought lye
Al schold I with þis knyf my throte kerue
with þat þe teres bruste oute of his eighen
And seyd If þat þe don vs both deyen
Þus gilteles þan haue ȝe fisshed faire
what mende ȝe If þat we bothe apayre
¶ Allas he whiche þat is my lord so deere
Þat trew man þat noble gentyl knyght
Þat naught desyred but ȝoure freendely cheere
I se hym deyen þer he gothe vp right
And hasteth hym with alle his ful myght
For to ben slayn if his fortune assente
Allas þat god ȝow swich a beaute sente
¶ If it be so þat ȝe so crwel be
Þat of his deth ȝow liste nat to reche
Þat is so trewe and worthy as ȝe se
Namore þan of a Iapare or a wreche
If ȝe be swiche ȝoure beaute may nat streche
To mak amend of so cruwel a dede
Auysemente is good bi-fore þe nede
¶ Wo worth þe faire comme vertuelees
wo worth þat herb also þat doth no boote
wo worth þat beaute þat is routheles
wo worth þat wyght þat tret ech vnder foote
And ȝe þat be of beaute crop and roote
If þer-with-al in ȝow þer be no routhe
Þanne is it harm ȝe lyuen by my trouthe
¶ And also thynke wel þat is no gaude
For me were leuere that thow and I and he
were hanged þan I shold ben his baude
As heigh / as men on vs alle y-see
I am þin Em the shame were to me
As wel as þe If þat I sholde assente
Thorwgh myn abet þat he þin honour shente
¶ Now vnderstonde fore I nought requere
To bynd ȝow to hym thorwgh no beheste
But oonly þat ȝe mak hym bettere chere
Than ȝe han don or þis and moore feste
So þat his lyue be saued at þe leste
This al and som and pleynly oure entente
God help me so I neuere other mente
¶ Loo þis requeste is nought but skyl I-wis
No doute of reson pardee is þer noon
I set þe werste þat ȝe dreden thys
Men wold wondren sen hym come or goon
Þer aȝeyn answere I þus anone
Þat euery wyght but he be fool of kynde
wol deme it loue of frenshippe in his mynde
¶ What wo wol demen though he se a man
To temple go / þat he þe ymages ettheth
Thynke / ek how wel and wysely þat he kan
Goueren hym self þat he no thynge forȝeteht
Þat where he comth he prys and þanke hym geteht
And ek þer-to he shal come here so selde
what fors were it though al þe town bihelde
¶ Swich louo of frendes regneth al þis town
And were yow in þat mantel euere moo
And god so wys be my sauacioun
As I haue seyde / ȝoure best is to do soo
But alway good nece to stynte his wo
So lat ȝoure daunger sucred ben a lyte
Þat of his deth ȝe be nought to wyte
¶ Creseyde which þat herd hym in þis wyse
Thoughte I shal feelen what he mene I-wys
Now Em quod she what wold ȝe deuyse
what is ȝoure rede I shold don of þis
Þat is wel seyde quod he certeyn best is
Þat ȝe hym loue certeyn for his louynge
As loue for loue is skylful guerdonynge
¶ Thynk ek how elde wasteth euery houre
In eche of ȝow a partye of beauute
And þer-for er þat age þe deuoure
Go loue / for olde þar wol no wyght of þe
Lat þis prouerb a lore vnto ȝow be
To lat I-war quod beauute when it is paste
And elde daunteht daunger at þe laste
¶ The kynges fool is wonte to [criyen] cryen lowde
when þat a womman berth hire heighe
So longe mote ȝe lyue and alle proude
Tyl crowes feete be grow vnder ȝoure eigh
And sende ȝow þanne a myrour in to prye
In whiche ȝe may se ȝoure face a morw
Nece I bydde wysshe ȝow no more sorw
¶ with þis he stynte and caste a-dowyn þe hed
And she be-gan to breste a wepe a-none
And seyd allas for wo / why nere I dede
For of þis world þe feith is al a-gone
Allas what sholden straunge folke [folke, later] to me don
when þat for my best freend I wende
Let me to loue and shold it me defende
¶ Allas I wold han tristed douteles
Þat if þat I thorugh my disauenture
Hadde loued outher hym or achilles
Ector / or any mannes creature
Ȝe nold han had no mercy ne mesure
On me / but alwey had me in repreue
Þis fals world allas who may it leue
¶ what is this al the Ioye and alle þe feeste
Is this ȝoure rede / is þis my blysful cas
Is þis þe verray mede of ȝoure byheste
Is alle þis peinted proces seyde allas
Ryght for þis fyn o lady myn pallas
Thow in þis dredeful cas for me purueye
For so astoned am I that I deye
¶ with þat she gan ful sorufully to syke
A may it be no bet quod Pandarus
By god I shal na more com here þis wyke
And god to-forne þat am mystrested þus
I se ful wele þat ȝe sette lyte of vs
Or of oure deth allas I woful wreche
Myght he ȝit lyue / of me is nought to reche
¶ Oþou cruel god / o dispitouse marte
O furies // thre / of helle on ȝow I crye
So lat me neuere / out of þis house departe
If þat I ment harm / or any vilanye
But sith I se my lord moote nedes deye
And I with hym here I me shryue and seye
Þat wikkedly ȝe don vs bothe to deye
¶ But sith it liketh ȝow þat I be dede
By neptunus þat god is of þe see
Fro þis forth shal I neuere eten brede
Vnto I myn own hertys [hertys, later] blode may see
For certein I wol deye as sone as he
And vp he sterte / and on his way he raughte
Til she agayn hym by þe lappe [a later y has been put here] kaughte
¶ Criseyde wyche þat wel neigh starf for a later pure, fere
So a later eke, put in as she was þe ferefullest wight
Þat myght be and herd ek with hire ere
And saught þe soruful hernest of þe knyght
And in his preyers saughe eke [eke, later] noon vn-right
And for þe harme þat myght ek fallen more
She gan to rew / and dredded hire wonder sore
¶ And thought þus vnhappes fallen thykke
Alday for loue / and in swiche manere cas
As men ben cruel in hem self and wykke
And if þe man sla here hem self allas
In my presaunce / it wol be no solas
what men wolde of it deme / I kan nat seye
It nedeth me ful sleughtely for to pleye
¶ And with a sorwful syk she seyde threye
A lord what me is tyd a sory chaunce
For myn estate lith now in Iupartye
And ek myn emes lyf is in balaunce
But natheles with goddes gouernaunce
I shal so done / myn honour shal I kepe
And ek his lyf / and stynte for to wepe
¶ Of harmes two þe lesse is for to cheese
Ȝet haue I leuere maken hym goode chere
In honour þan myn emes lyf to lese
Ȝe seyn / ȝe no thynge elles me requere
No wys quod [he] myn ow[e]n nece dere
Now wel quod she and I wel don my peyne
I shal myn herte aȝeynist my liste constreyne
¶ But þat I nyl nat holden hym in honde
Ne loue aman ne kan I naught ne may
Aȝeyns my wyl but elles wol I fonde
Myn honour saufe plesen hym fro day to day
Þer-to nold I nat ones seyde nay
But þat I drede as in my fantasye
But cesse cause ay cesseth maladye
¶ And here I make a protestacioun̄
Þat in þis processe If ȝe depter go
Þat certanly for no sauacion
of ȝow / though þat ȝe sterue both[e] two
Though al þe world on a day be my fo
Ne shal I neuere on hym han other rowthe
I graunt wele ouod Pandarus by my trouthe
¶ But may I truste wele þer-to quod he
Þat of þis thynge þat ȝe han hight me here
Ȝe wol it holden trewly vn to me
Ȝe trewly quod she myn vncle deere
Ne that I shal han cause in þis matere
Quod he // to plyne or efter ȝow to preche
why no pardee what nedeth more speche
¶ Tho fillen they in oothere tales gladde
Tyl at þe laste o gooode Em quod she tho
For his loue whiche þat vs bothe mode
Tel me how firste ȝe westen of his woo
Woote noon of it but ȝe he seyde no
Kan he wel speke of loue quod she I preye
Tel me / for I þe bet me shal pleye
¶ Tho Pandarus a litil gan to smyle [? MS. stuyle]
And seyde by my trowthe I wol ȝow telle
Þis oother day naught gon ful longe while
In whiche þe paleys gardyn by a welle
Gan he and I wel half a day to dwelle
Ryght for to speke of an ordynaunce
How we þe grekes myghten disauaunce
¶ Soone after þat bigonne to lepe
And casten with oure dartes to and fro
Til at þe laste he seyde he wold slepe
And on þe gres a-down he layde him tho
And I þer-after gan roman to and fro
Til þat I herde as þat I welke allone
How he bygan ful wofully to grone
¶ Tho gan I stalke hym softely by-hynde
And sykerly þe sothe for to seyne
As I kan clepe aȝeyn now to my mynde
Right þus to loue he gan hym for to pleyne
He seyde lord haue routhe vp on my peyne
Al haue I ben rebel in myn entente
Now mea culpa lord I me repente
¶ O god þat at þy dispocion̄
Ledest the fyn by Iuste purueiaunce
Of euery wight my lowe confession
Accepte in gree / and send me swich penaunce
As liketh þe / but from desesperaunce
Þat may my goost departe away fro þe
Thow be my shelde for þi benignite
¶ For certes lord so sore hath she me woundud
Þat stoode in blake with lokynge of hire eighen
That to myn hertis botme it is I-sownded
Thorugh wiche I woote I moote nedes dyen
This is þe werste I dar me nat wryen
And wel þe hootter ben þe gledes rede
Þat men hem wren wiþ asshen pale and dede
¶ with þat he smote his hed a down a non
And gan to motre I not what trewely
And I with þat gan stille away gone
And lete þer-of as no thynge wyste hadde I
And come aȝein anon and stode hym by
And seyde a-wake ȝe slepen alle to longe
It semeth nat þat loue doth ȝow longe
¶ Þat slepen swo þat no man may ȝow wake
who sey euere or þis so dul a man
Ȝe frend quod do ȝe ȝoure heddes ake
For loue / and lat me lyuen as I kan
But though þat he for wo was pale and wan
Yet made he þo as fresshe a contenaunce
As though he schold have led þe new daunce
¶ This passed forth tyl now þis oþer day
It felle þat I come romynge al allone
