And wolde hire self ben at þyn assen
Now is þis not a nyse vanyte
Rys vp a-non & lat þis sorwe be
And kyþe þou art a man for in þis houre
I wele be ded or sche beleuyn oure
// To þis answerde troylus ful softe
And seyde parde leue broþer dere
Al þis haue I myn selue þouȝt ful ofte
And more þyng þan þow demys here
But why þis þyng is lest þou schat wel here
And whan þou me hast ȝeue an audience
Þeraftyr mayst þou tellyn þyn sentence
¶ fyrst syn þou wist þis toun haþ al þis werre
Of rauaschyng of wemen so by myȝt
It schulde not be sufferid me to erre
As it stont now ne don so gret onryȝt
I schulde also han blame of euery wyȝt
Myn faderis graunt if þat I so with-stode
Sithe sche is chaungid for þe tounys goode
// I haue ek þouȝt ȝif it were hire asent
To aske hire myn fadyr of his grace
Þan þynke I þis were hire acusament
Syn wel I wot I may not hire purchase
ffor sen myn fadyr in so hey a plase
As parlement haþ hire chaunge enselid
He nil not for me his honour ben repelid
¶ Ȝit drede I moste hire herte to perturbe
With vyolence ȝif I do swych a game
ffor ȝif I wolde it opinly distorbe
It mot ben disclaundyr to hire name
And were leuere ben ded þan hire defame
As nolde god but ȝif I schulde haue
Hyre honour leuere þan myn lyf to saue
Þus am I lost for ouȝt þat I can se
ffor serteyn sithe þat I am hire knyȝt
I haue honour leuere ȝit þan me
Hadde in euery cas as louere ouȝte on ryȝt
Þus am I with desyr & resoun twyȝt
Desyr for to disturbe hire men me redyth
And resoun nyl not so myn [y corrected] herte drediþ
// So wepynge þat he coude neuere to seche
He seyde allas how schal I wreche fare
ffor wel fele I myn loue alwey encreseþ
And hope is lasse & lasse alway pandare
Encresyn ek þe causis of myn care
So welleawey whi nyl myn herte brest
ffor whi in loue is litil hertis rest
¶ Pandare answerede frend þou mayst for me
Don as þe lust but hadde I it so hote
And þyn estat / sche schulde gon with me
Þow al þis toun cryed on þis þyng with note
I nylde sette at al þe noyse a grote
ffor whan men han wel cryed let hem roune
ffor wondyr lestyþ but nyne dayis in tounne
// Deuyne not in resoun ay so depe
Ne preciously but help þynself a-non
Betere it is þat oþere þan þynself wepe
And namelich syþe ȝe to ben alle on
Rys vp for be myn hod sche schal not gon
And raþere be lytil in blame I-founde
Þat sterue hire as a gnatte [n alterd] with-oute wonde
¶ It is no iape / in myn dom ne vice
Hire to withholdyn þat ȝe louyn most
Parauntyr sche / may holde þe for nyce
To letyn hire gon / in-to þe grekys ost
Þynk how fortune / as wel þyn seluyn wost
Helpith hardi / men to his empryse
And fley from wrechis / for here cowardyse
¶ And þow þyn ladi / wolde a litil hire greue
Þou schat þyn pes / ful wel hereaftyr make
And parauntyr / it wele be to hire leue
Þat sche wolde it / as now for grif take
whi schulde þanne / for ferd þyn herte quake
Þyng how þat parys / haþ þat is þyn broþer
A loue & whi / schuldist not han anoþer
// And troylus / on þyng I dare þe swere
Ȝif þat Crisseide / wich þat is þyn lyf
Now louyth þe / as wel as þou dost hire
God helpe me so / sche schal not take at gref
Þat þou do bote / a-non in þis myschif
And ȝif sche / wele nedis fro þe passe
Þanne is sche fals / so loue hire wel þe lasse
¶ ffor whi tak herte / & þynk þus þat I a knyȝt
Þourw loue is broke / alday euery lawe
Kiþ knowe sumwhat / þyn corage [g, first d] & þyn myȝt
Haue mercy of / þyn self for ony awe
Let not þis wrechede / wo þyn herte gnawe
But nameli set / þe world on sexe or seue
And ȝif þou deye / a martyr go to heuene
// I wele myn self / be with þe at þis dede
Þow I & al myn / kyn vp-on a stounde
Schulde in strete / as doggis ligge dede
Þourw gyrt with many / wid & blody wounde
In euery cas I wele / a frend ben founde
And ȝif þe luste / here steruyn as a wreche
Adew þe deuyl / haue hym þat reche
¶ Þis Troilus gan / with þo wordis quikyn
And seyde frend / graunt merci I acente
But serteynly / þow mayȝt me not so prikyn
Ne peyne non / ne may me so turmente
Þat for no cas / it is not myn entente
At schorte wordis / þow I deye schulde
To rauasche hire / but ȝif hire self wolde
¶ Pandare answerde of þat be as be may
But tel me þan hast þow hire wel a-sayed
Þat sorwist þus & he answerde nay
Wherto quod pandarus art þou þus amayed
Þat wost not ȝif sche wolde ben euele apayed
To rauasche hire sithe þou hast not ben þere
But ony aungel told it þe in þyn ere
// ffoþ rys vp as nouȝt ne were a-non
And wasch þyn face & to þe kyng þou wende
Or he may wondere whedyr þou art þus gon
Þou mayst with wisdam him & oþere blynde
or vp on a cas he may aftyr þe sende
Ar þou be war & schortely broþer dere
Be glad & lat vs werche in þis manere
// ffor I schal schapyn it so þat sikirly
Þou schalt þis nyȝt sumtyme in summanere
Come speke with þyn ladi preuyly
And by hire wordis ek & by hire chere
Þou schal ful sone perseyue & wel here
Al hire entent of þis cas þe beste
And far now wel for in þis poynt I reste
The swyfte fane with þat false þingis
Egal reportyth lik þe þyngis trewe
wich þour-out Troye it fleþ with preste wyngis
ffrom man to man & mad þis tale newe
How calcas douȝtyr with hire bryȝte hewe
At parlement with-oute wordys more
I-grauntid was in chaung for antenore
¶ Þe which tale a-non ryȝt as Crisseide
Hadde herde sche þe wiche þat of hire fadyr rouȝte
As in þis cas ryȝt nouȝt ne whan he deyede
fful busili to Iubiter be-souȝte
Ȝif hym myschaunce þat þis tretys brouȝte
But schortly ȝif þese talis soþe were
Sche durste at no wiȝt axen it for fere
¶ As sche þat hade hire herte & al hire mynde
On Troilus be-set so wondyr faste
Þat al þis world ne myȝte hire loue onbynde
Ne Troylus out of hire herte caste
Sche wele ben his whil þat hire lyf caste
And þus sche brennyt boþe in loue & drede
So þat sche nyste what was best to rede
// But as men seyn in tounnys al aboute
Þat wemen vsyn frendis to visite
So to Crisseyde wemen come a route
ffor pitouse ioye & wende hire to delite
And with here talis / dere I-now of a myte
Þese wemen wich þat in þe cete dwelle
Þey sette hem doun & seyde as I schal telle
¶ Quod fyrst þat on I am glad trewely
Be cause of ȝow ȝe schal ȝoure fadir se
A noþer seyde I-wis so am not I
ffor alto litil haþ sche with vs be
Þe þrede answerede I hope I-wis þat sche
Schal bryngyn vs to pes in euery side
Þat whan sche goþ almyȝti god hire gide
// Þo wordis & þo womanliche þyngis
Sche herde riȝt nouȝt þow sche þere were
ffor al þis tyme hire þouȝt on oþer þyng is
Al-þow þe bodi sat amongis hem þere
God wot hire aduertens is eɫɫ where
ffor troilus hire soule ful faste sout
With-outyn alwey on hym sche þouȝt
¶ Þese wemen þat so wendyn hire to plese
A-boute nouȝt þus gunne here taɫ opende
Swich vanyte can don hire non ese
As sche þat al þis mene while brende
Of oþere passioun þan þey wende
So þat sche wende a-non ryȝt for to deye
ffor wo & wery of þat compaynye

LG.HEAD: (102) [This stanza is (partly) in Boocaccio, and in Harl. 3943: see our Filostrato and Troilus, p. 196.]
LG.L: ¶ ffor wich myȝte sche no lengere to restreyne
Here teris so gunne þei vp to welle
Þat ȝeuyn signys of þe bittyr peyne
In wich hire spirit was & muste dwelle
Remembrynge hire from heuene in-to wich helle
Sche fallyn was sithe sche forgoþ þe syȝt
Of Troylus hire owene hertys knyȝt
// And þeilke folis sittynge hire a-boute
Wende þat sche wepte & syȝede sore
Be cause þat sche schulde from þat route
Departe & neuere pleye with hem more
And þey þat haddyn knowyn hire tofore
Saw hire so wepe & þouȝte it kyndenesse
And eche of hem wepte for distresse
¶ ffor eche of heuyd to clawe hym on his hele
And busily þey gunne hire confortyn
Of þyngis god wot sche gan not fele
And with here wordis wendyn hire disportyn
And to be glad oftyn hire þey hortyn
But swich an ese þerwith þey hyre wrouȝt
Ryȝt as a man is esid þat felyth ryȝt nouȝt
// But aftyr al þis nyse vanite
Þey toke here leue & hom þey wentyn alle
Cresseyde ful of sorweful pete
In-to þe chambe wente out of þe halle
And on hire bed for ded sche gan to falle
In purpos neuere þens for to ryse
And þus sche wrouȝt as I schal ȝow deuyse
¶ Þe salte teris from hyre eyȝyn tweyn
Out ran as schour of aprille ful swyþe
Hyre white brest sche bet & for þe peyne
Aftyr þe deþ cryede a þousent sithe
Syn he þat wonyt was hire wo for to lyþe
Sche mot forgon for which disauenture
Sche held hire selue a for-lost creature
¶ Hyre owene her þat sunneliche was of hewe
Sche rente & ek hire fyngeris longe & smale
Sche wrong ofte & bad god on hire rewe
And with þe deþ don bote on hire bale
Hyre hew whilhom bryȝt þat þo was pale
Bar witnesse of hire wo & hire constreynte
And þus sche spak sobbynge in hire compleynte
// Alle quod sche out of þis regioun
I woful wreche I onfortune wyȝt
And born in cursede constolacioun
Mot gon & þus departyn from myn knyȝt
Wo worþe þe dayy & namely þat nyȝt
On wich I saw him fyrst with eyen tweyn
Þat causith me & I hym al þis peyn
¶ What schal he don what scha I don also
How schal I leue ȝif þat I from him twynne
O dere herte ek þat I loue so
Ho schal þat sorwe sle þat ȝe ben inne
O Calcas fadir þyn be al þis synne
And cursed be þat day which þat argyf
Me on hire bodi bar to ben onlef
// To what fyn schulde I leue or sorwe þus
How schulde fich withoute watyr deure
What is Crisseyde worþ with-outyn Troylus
How schulde a plante or oþer creature
Leuyn with-outyn his kynde nature
ffor wych ful softe a biword here I seye
Þat erbeles grene mot sone deye
¶ I schal don þus siþyn noþer swerd ne darte
Dar I non handelyn for þe crewelte
Þat ilke day I schal from Ȝow departe
Ȝif sorwe of Þat nyl myn bane be
Þere schal no mete ne drynk come in me
Troilus myn sorwe out of myn brest conueye
And þus myn self wele I don to deye
¶ And Troilus myne cloþis euerychone
Schul blake ben in tokenynge herte swete
Þat I am as out of þis world I-gone
Þat woned was ȝow to holde in quiete
And of myn ordere til þat þey me mete
Þe obseruance euere I in ȝoure absence
Schal sorwyn ben compleynt & abstynence
¶ Myn herte ek þe sorweful gost perin
Bequeþe I ȝoure spryȝt to compleyne
Eternally for þey schal neuere twynne
ffor-þy in erþe twynnede ben we tweyne
Ȝe in þe feld of pete out of peyne
Þere Pluteo regnyth schal we ben in fere
As Orpheus with erodice his fere
¶ Þus herte myn for antenore allas
I sone schal be ȝoldyn as I wene
But how schal ȝe don in þis woful cas
How schal ȝoure tendere herte þis susteyne
But herte myn for-ȝet þis sorwe & tene
And me also for soþly for to sey
So ȝe wel fare I reche not to dey
¶ How myȝte it euere red be or I-songe
Þe pleynt þat sche made in hire distresse
I not but as for me myn litele tunge
Ȝif I discriue wolde hire heuynesse
It schulde make hire sorwe to seme lesse
Þanne as it was & child lichera deface
Hire hye pleynt & þerfore I it pase

DIV3.P: [The next 4 stanzas are not in Gg. 4. 27.]

LG.L: ¶ Entendyth þan leue in wo or me hey
And euery wordely ioye as þynkyth me
Þe ende of blys ay sorwe it ocupie
And who-so trowyth not þat it so be
Let hym vp-on me woful wreche se
Þat myn self hate & þat is lite fors
ffelynge alwey from wikke I go to wors
¶ Who so me seþ he seþ sorwe al at onys
Peyne turnement wo & ek distresse
Out of myn sorweful body harm þere non is
As anguys langur crewel & bittyrnesse
Anoy smert dred furie & ek seknesse
I trowe I-wis from heuene terys regne
ffor pete of myn asper & crewel peyne
// O myn sustyr ful of disconfort
Quod Pandarus what þynkyst þou to do
Whi ne hast þou to þyn self sum report
Whi wilt þou þus þyn self allas so fordo
Leue al þis werk & tak now hede þerto
What I schal seyn & werkene of good entent
Þis þat by me þin Troylus þe sent
¶ Turnede hire þo Crisseyde & wo makynge
So gret þat it a day was for to se
Allas quod sche what wordis may ȝe bryng
What wil myn dere herte sendyn to me
Which þat I drede neueremore to se
Whil he haue pleynt or terys or I wende
I haue I-now ȝef þat he þeraftyr sende
¶ Sche was ryȝh [? MS. ryth] swich to se in hire vesage
As is þe wyȝt þat men on bere bynde
Hire fase lyk of radyis þe ymage
Was al chaungid in-to a noþer kynde
Þe pley þe lauȝter men were wone to fynde
In hire & oþere ioyes euerychon
Ben fled & þus from hem sche lyþ a-lon
¶ A-boute hire eyȝyn to purpure ryngis
Ben trent in soþfast tokenyng of hire peyne
Þat to beholde it was a dedly þyng
ffor wich pandare myȝte not restreyne
Þe teris from his eyȝyn for to reyne [y, alterd from n]
But naþeles as he best myȝt he seyde
ffrom Troilus þese wordys to Cresseyde
¶ Lo nece trowe I wel ȝe han herd er þis
Þe kynge with oþere lordis for þe beste
Haþ mad þe eschaung for Antenore & ȝow
Þat cause is of þis wo & þis onreste
But now þis cas doþ Troylus moleste
Þat may non wordely mannys tunge sey
As he þat schortely scharpith him to dey
¶ ffor we han boþe sorwyd he & I
Þat in to lytil wol ner It hade vs slawe
But þour myn conseyl þis day finally
And sumwhat haþ from wepynge hym withdrare
And semyth þat he desiryth fawe
With ȝow to be al nyȝt for to deuyse
Remedi in þis ȝyf þere were ony wise
¶ Þis is schort & pleyn þe effect of myn massage
And ek þe beste as myn wit can comprehende
ffor ȝe þat ben in turnemen for swich a rage
May now to no long prolong as now entende
And her-vpon ȝe may answere him sende
And for þe loue of god myn nece dere
So leuyth þis er Troylus be here
¶ GRet is myn wo quod sche & syȝhynge sore
As sche þat felith dedely scharp distrese
But ȝit to me his sorwe is meche more
Allas for me hath he swich heuynesse
And for me cast in swich drerynesse
Can he for me so pitously compleyne
Now I-wis his sorwe doubelith al myn peyne
¶ Greuous for me god wot is for to twynne
Quod sche but it hardere is to me
To sen him in þat he is in
ffor wel I wot It wele myn bane be
And deye I wolde in sertyn þe quod sche
But bid him come or deþ þat þus me þretyth
Dryf out þat gost þat in myn herte betyth
¶ Þese seyde sche & on hire armys too
fel grof & gan to wepe pitusely
Quod Pandarus allas whi do ȝe so
Sythe wel ȝe wot þe tyme is faste by
Þat he schal come arys vp softely
Þat he ȝow not be-wepyn þus I-fynde
But ȝe wele haue hym wod out of his mynde
¶ ffor wiste he þat ȝe ferde in þis manere
He wolde hym self fle & ȝif I wende
To haue þis fare he schal not comyn here
ffor al þe good þat priam may dispende
ffor to what fyn he wolde a-non pretende
Þat wot I wel & þerfore ȝit I sey
Lat be þis sorwe or platly he wele dey
¶ And schapyth ȝow his sorwe to abregge
And not to encrese o leue nece swete
Be raþere cause to hym flat þan egge
And with sum wisdom ȝe his sorwe bete
What helpith to wepe ful a strete
Or þat ȝe boþe in salte teris drenk
Betere is on tyme of cure þan ay in pleynt
¶ I mene þus whan I hym hidir brynge
Sythe ȝe ben wis & boþe of on asent
So schapyth to disturbe þis goinge
Or come a-ȝen sone aftyr ȝe ben went
Whan men ben wise of schort auysement
And let sen how ȝoure wit schal now a-vayle
And þat þat I can helpe it schal not fayle
¶ Go quod criseyde & vnkele trewely
I schal don al myn myȝt me to restreyne
ffrom wepynge in his syȝt & besily
Hym for to glade I schal don al myn peyne
And in myn herte sekyn euery veyne
Ȝif to his sor þere may ben foundyn salue
It schal not lak in serteyn on myn halue
¶ GOþ pandarus & Troylus he southe [outhe corrected]
Til in a temple he fond hym al-one
As he þat of his lyf no þyng roughthe [ghthe corrected]
But to þe pitouse goddis euerychone
fful tenderely he preyede & mad his mone
To don hym sone out of þis world to pase
ffor wel he þouȝte þer nas non oþer grace

DIV3.P: [The next 18 stanzas, 126 lines, about Free-Will, &c., are not in the Cambridge MS. or the long ledgerlike Harleian 1239, leaf 43, or the Harleian 2392, leaf 101, back. These 2 Harl. MSS. leave out also stanza 155, l. 1079-85, thus:—
Harl. 1239, leaf 43.

LG.L: Be-sykyng hem to sende hym other grace
Or fro thys worlde / to doon̄ hym̄ sone pace
O myghty gode / quod pandarus in Trone

DIV3.P: Harl. 2392, leaf 101, back.

LG.L: to doon him soone out of this word to pace
for wul he thouhte / ther was non othir grace
O myhti god / quod Pandarus / in trone

DIV3.P: Harl. 3943 has the 18 stanzas (see p. 205 of our Filos∣trato and Troilus), and so has Addit. MS. 12,044, Brit. Museum, on leaves 80-1. Harl. 4912 stops ct l. 686 of Bk IV, 'They set hem down̄ and seyde as I shaɫɫ telle.']

LG.L: ¶ Þanne seyde he þus al myȝty god in trone
Þat wost of al þis þyng þe sothfast-nesse
Rew on myn sorwe and do me deye sone
Or bryng Crisseyde & me from þis distresse
And whil he was in al þis heuynesse
Disputynge with him self in þis matere
Com pandarus & seyde as ȝe may here
¶ O myȝty god quod pandarus in trone
Ey ho say euere a wysman faryn so
Whi troilus what þynkist þow to done
Hast þou swich wil to ben þyn owene fo
[Blank line in MS.]
Whi list þou fordon þyn self for drede
Þat in þyn heuyd þyne eyȝyn semyn dede
¶ Hast þou not leuyd oftyn in þyn lyf be-forn
With-outyn hire & ferd ful wel at ese
Art þou for hire & for non oþer born
Haþ kynde wrouȝt þe only hire to plese
Canst þou non þynke þus in þyn disese
Þat on þe deþ ryȝt as þere fallyn chaunce
Ryȝt so in loue þere comyth & goþ plesaunce
¶ And ȝit þis is myn wondir Most of al
Whi þou sorwist þus & wost not ȝit
Touchynge hire goinge how þat it schal falle
Ne ȝif sche can h[i]re self disturbin it
Þu hast not ȝit asayed al hire wit
A man may al be tyme his nekke bede
Whan þe hed schal of & sorwyn at þe nede
¶ ffor-þi tak hed what I schal þe say
I haue with hire I-spoke & a-lone be
So acord was be-twixe vs twey
Þat eueremore me þynkyth þus þat sche
Haþ sumwhat in hire hertys preuyte
Wher-with sche can ȝif I schal ryȝt arede
Stynt al þis þyng of which þou art in drede
¶ ffor why myn counseyl is whan it is nyȝt
Þou to hire go & mak of þis an ende
And blysful Ioue þour his grete myȝt
Schal as I hope vn-to vs grace synde
Myn herte seyth serteyn sche wele not wynde
And for-þy put in þyn herte a while in prest
And hold þis purpos for it is þe best
¶ Þis Troilis answerde & seyde sore
Þow sest ryȝt wel & I wele don ryȝt so
And what hym lyst he seyde to hym more
But whan þat it was tyme for to go
fful priuyly hym silf with-outyn mo
Vn-to hire come as he was wone to done
And how þey wrouȝte I schal ȝow telle sone
SOþ is þat whan þey gan ferst to mete
Þey gunne þe sorwe of here hertys twiste
Þat oþer [scribe meant to put n before oþer, but mistook] nof hem oþer myȝte grete
But hem in armys hent & ofte kyste
Þe lesse woful of hem boþe nyste
What for to done ne myȝte a word out brynge
As I seyde erst for sorwe & for wepynge
¶ Þo woful teris þat þey letyn falle
As bittere weryn out of teris kynde
ffor peyne as is lignum aloes or galle
So bittere teris wepyn not þour þe rynde
Þe woful myrra wretyn as I fynde
Þat in þis world þere nys so hard an herte
Þat nulde an rewid of þere peynys smerte
¶ But whan here woful weri gostis tweyne
Turnede ben þere as hem auȝte to dwelle
And þat sumwhat to lesse gan þe peyne
Be leue of pleynt & ebbyn gan þe welle
Of here terys & þe herte onswelle
With brokyn woys al hors for feynt Crisseyde
To Troilus þese ilke wordis seyde
// O Ioue I crie & mercy I be-seche
Help troylus & þerwithal hire face
Vp-on his brest sche leyde & loste speche
Hire [first, His] woful spryt from his proper place
Ryȝt with þe word a poynt to a pase
And þus sche lyth with hewys pale & grene
Þat whilehom frosche & fayre were to sene
¶ Þis troylus on hire gan be-holde
Clepynge hire name & sche lay as for ded
With-oute answere & felte hire semys colde
Hire eyȝyn þrowyn vpward to hire heuyd
Þis sorweful man can now no maner red
But ofte tyme hire colde mout he kyste
Wheþer hym was wo god & hym self wiste
// He rist hym vp & a long streyt he hire leyde
ffor signe of lyf for ouȝt he can or may
Can he not fynde in no cas of crisseyde
ffor wich his song is ofte welleaway
And whan he say þat specheles sce lay
With sorweful voys & herte & blysse Al bare
He seyde how þat sche from þis word was fare
¶ So aftyr þat he longe hire hade compleynyd
And hondis wrong / & seyde þat was to sey
And with hise [first, hire] teris salte hire bryst be-reynyd
He gan þo teris wipyn of & dreye
And pitously be gan for þe soule preye
And seyde lord þat set art in þyn trone
Rewe ek on me for I schal folwe sone
¶ Sche cold was & with-oute sentement
ffor ouȝt he woste & breth ȝit felte he non
And þat was hym a preuaunt argument
Þat sche was forth out of þis world l-gon
And whan he say þere was non oþer won
He gan hire lemys dresse in swich manere
As men don folk þat schal ben leyd on bere
// And aftyr þis with sterne & crewel herte
His swerd out of þe schede a-non it twyȝt
Hym self to slen how sore þat hym smert
So þat his soule here soule folwe myȝt
Þere as þe dom of orynys wolde it dyȝt
Syn loue & crewel [el, corrector] fortune it ne wolde
Þat in world no more leue ne schulde
¶ Þanne seyde he þus ful fyld of hey disdeyn
On crewel Ioue and þou fortune aduerse
Þis al and som þat falsely han ȝe slayn
Crisseyde & syn ȝe can don me no werse
ffy on ȝoure myȝt & on ȝoure werkys dyuerse
Þus couardely ȝe schal me neuere wyn
Þere schal no deþ me from myn lady twyn
// ffor in þis world sithe ȝe han slayn hire þus
Wele lete & folwe hire spiryt forth in hye
Schal louere neuere seyn þat troylus
Dare not for fere with his lady deye
ffor certayn I wele hire bere cumpanye
But for ȝe wil not sufferin / vs leuyn here
Ȝit sufferyth þat oure soulis ben in fere
// And þou cite wich þat I leue Inne in wo
And þou Priame breþeren alle in fere
And þow myn madyr farwel for I go
Þow antropos þat art ful redy here
And þow Crysseyde swete herte dere
Resseyue now myn spryt wolde he sey
With swerd at herte redy for to dey
¶ But as god wolde of swow þerwith sche brayd
And gan syhe & Troylus sche cryede
And answerde herte myn Criseyde
Leue ȝe ȝit & let his swerd doun glyde
Ȝa herte myn I-thankede be cupide
Quod sche & þerwith sche sore seyȝt
And he be-gan confortyn hire as he myȝt
// Tok hire in armys too & kiste hire ofte
And hire to glade he dede al his entent
ffor whiche hire gost þat flekerede ay on loft
Al softe to hire herte a-ȝyn it went
So at þe laste as hire eyȝyn glent
A-non sche gan his swerd aspie
As it lay bare & gan for fere crye
¶ And axede hym whi he hade it drawe
And troilus a-non þe cause tolde
And how hym self he wolde þerwith a slawe
ffor wich crisseyde vp on hym gan be-holde
And gan hym in hire armys faste folde
And seide o mercy god lo wich a drede
Allas how nyȝ were we boþe dede
// Þanne ȝif I ne hadde speke as grase was
Ȝe wolde a slayn ȝoure sylf a-non quod sche
Ȝa douteles & sche answerde allas
ffor by þat ilke lord þat made me
I ne wolde a furlongwoy a-lyue a be
Aftyr ȝoure deþ to a ben crounede quene
Of al þe lond þe sunne on schynyth schene
¶ But with þis seluyn swerd whych þat here is
Myn seluyn wolde I a slawe quod sche þo
But ho for we haue ryȝt I-now of þis
And lat vs ryse & streyȝt to bedde go
And þere lat vs spekyn of oure wo
ffor by þe percher which þat I se brenne
I knowe wel þat day is not fer henne
¶ Whan þey weryn in bedde in armys foldyn
Nouȝt was it lyk þe nyȝtys þere by-fore
ffor pitousely eche oþer gan be-holdyn
As þey þat haddyn here ioyis alle bore
Seyinge allas þat euere were þey bore
Til at þe laste þis woful wyȝt Crisseyde
To Troilus þese ilke wordis seyde
// O herte myn þis wote ȝe wel quod sche
Þat alday / a wyȝt his wo compleyne
And sekyth not how helpyn for to be
It nys but foly / & encres of peyne
And sithe þat here assembelyd be we tweyne
To fynde bote of wo þat we ben inne
It were al tyme sone to begynne
¶ I am a woman as ful wel ȝe wot
And as I am a-vised sodeynly
So wele I tellyn it ȝow whil it is hot
Me þynkith þus þat oþer ȝe nor I
Auȝte half þis wo to make / skilfully
ffor þere is herte I-now for to redresse
Þat ȝit is mys & slen þis heuynesse
So is þat wo þe wich þat we ben inne
ffor ouȝt I wot for no þyng ellis is
But for cause þat we schuln twynne
Considerid al þere is no more a-mys
But what is a remedie on-to þis
But þat we schape vs sone for to mete
Þis is and sum myn dere herte swete
¶ Now þat I schal wel bryngyn it a-boute
To comyn a-ȝen sone aftyr þat I go
Þerof am I no maner þyng in doute
ffor dredeles þat in a wouke or to
I schal ben here & þat it schal ben so [later] may
By al ryȝt & in wordis fewe
I schal ȝow wel an hep of woyes schewe
¶ ffor wich I nyl not make long sarmoun
ffor tyme I-lost may not recouerede ber
But I wele go ryȝt to conclusyoun
And to þe beste in ouȝt þat I can sen
But for þe loue of god forȝeue it me
Ȝif I speke ouȝt a-ȝen ȝoure hertis rest
ffor trewely I speke it for þe best
// Makynge here a protestacioun
Þat in effect þis þyng þat I schal say
Nis but esschewe þus in mocyoun [y alterd]
To fynde on-to ȝoure helpe þe beste wey
And takyþ it not oþerwyse I prey
ffor fynally what ȝe me comaunde
Þat wele I don for þat is no demaunde
¶ Now herkenyth þis ȝe han wel vndyrstonde
Myn goinge grauntyd is be parlement
So fer þat it may not be withstonde
ffor al þis world as be myn iugement
And syn þere helpiþ non auysement
To lette it let it passe out of mynde
And let vs schape a bettere woye to fynde
// Þe soþe þis is þat twynnyng of vs tweyne
Wil vs disese & crewelly ennoye
But hym be-houyth sumtyme to haue peyne
Þat seruyth loue ȝif he wele haue ioye
And syn I schal no ferþere out of troye
Þan I may ryde a-ȝen on hal a morwe
It auȝte lesse causyn vs to sorwe
¶ So as I schal not now ben hed in mewe
Þat day be day myne owene herte dere
Syn wel ȝe wot it is now a trewe
Ȝe schal ful wel al myn estat here
And or þat trewe is don I schal ben here
And þus have ȝe boþe antenore wonne
And now beþ glad / ȝif þat ȝe now cunne
¶ And þynkith ryȝt þus crisseyde is not a-gon
But what sche schal comyn hasteliche a-geyn
And whanne allas lo hasteliche a-non
Or dayes ten þat dar I sauely seyn
And þanne at erst schal ȝe ben so fayn
Þat we schal eueremor to-gedere d[w]elle
Þat al þis world / myȝte oure ioye telle
// I se þat oftyn þere þat as we ben now
Þat for þe beste oure conseyl for to byde
Ȝe speke not with me ne I with ȝow
In fortune nyȝt to se ȝow gon ne ryde
May ȝe not þan / ten dayis a-byde
ffor myn honour / in swich auenture
I-wis ȝe moun ell lityl endure
¶ Ȝe knowyn ek how þat al myn kyn is here
Only but / if it myn fadidyr be
And ek myne oþer þyngis alle in fere
A namely myn dere herte ȝe
Þat I nolde leuyn for to se
ffor al þis world as meche as it haþ spase

LG.L: Yow first biseche .I. that youre eyen clere.

Deuyse / I prey god so mot it be.

As þough al hol hym hadde made a leche.
And day by day he gan enquere & seche.
A sooþ of þis / with al his fulle cure.
And þus he drieth forth his auenture.
Fortune whiche þat permutacion.
Of þinges hath / as it is here commytted.
Thorugh purueyaunce / and disposicion.
Of heyghe Ioue as regnes shal ben fletted.
Fro folk yn folk / or whan þey shal ben smytted.
Gan pulle a-wey þe feþeres out of Troye.
Fro day to day / til þei ben bare of Ioye.
Among al þis þe fyn of þe parodye.
Of Ector gan approchen wonder blyue.
The fate wold his soule sholde vnbodye.
And shapen hadde a mene it out to dryue.
A-yeyns which fate helpeth not to stryue.
But on a day to fyghten gan he wende.
At which allas he caught his lyues ende.
For which me þenketh euery manere wight.
That haunteth armes oughte to by-waylle.
The deth of hym þat was so noble a kn[y]ght.
For as he drough a kyng by thauentaylle.
Vn-war of þis Achille þorugh þe mayle.
And þorugh þe body gan hym for to ryue.
And þus þis worþi knyght was brought of lyue.
For whom as olde bokes tellen vs.
was mad swych wo / þat tonge may it not telle.
And namely þe sorwe of Troylus.
That next hym was of worþinesse welle.
And yn þis wo gan Troylus to dwelle.
That what for sorwe / and loue and [for] vnreste.
Ful ofte a day he bad his herte breste.
But natheles though he gan hym dispeyre.
And dradde ay þat his lady was vntrewe.
yet ay on here his herte gan repeyre.
And as þese loueres don he soughte ay newe.
To gete a-yen Criseyde bryght of hewe.
And in his herte he wente here excusynge.
That Calkas causede al here taryinge.
And ofte tyme he was yn purpos gret.
Hym self lyk a Pylgrym to degyse.
To sen here but he may not contrefete.
To ben vnknowen / of folk þat weren wyse.
Ne fynde excuse a-right þat may suffise.
yf he among þe Grekes knowen were.
For which he wep ful ofte many a tere.
To here he wrot yet ofte tyme al newe.
Ful pitously he lefte it nought for slouþe.
Bisechyng here syn þat he was trewe.
That she wolde come ayeyn & holde here trowþe.
For which Criseyde vp-on a day for rouþe.
I take it so / towchynge þis matere.
wrot hym a-yeyn and seyde as ye may here.

LG.HEAD: (228) (Criseyde's Letter to Troylus)
LG.L: Cupides sone / ensample of goodlihede.
O. swerd of knyghthod / sours of gentilesse.
How myght a wyght in torment and in drede.
And heeeles / yow sende as yet gladnesse.
I herteles .I. syke I yn distresse.
Syn ye with me nor I with yow may dele.
Yow neyþer sende ich herte may nor hele.
Youre lettres ful þe papir al y-pleynted.
Conseyued hath myn hertes pite.
I haue ek seyn wiþ terys al depeynted.
youre lettre / and how þat ye requeren me.
To come a-yen / which yet may not be.
But why / lest þis lettre founden were.
No mencion ne make I now for fere.

LG.HEAD: (230) (Criseyde's Letter continued)
LG.L: Greuous to me god wot is youre vnreste.
Youre haste and þat þe goddes ordenaunce.
It semeth not ye take it for þe beste.
Nor oþer þyng nys not yn youre remembraunce.
As þenketh me but oonly youre plesaunce.
But beth not wroth / and þat I yow byseche.
For þat I tarye / is al for wykked speche.
For I haue herd wel more þan I wende.
Towchynge vs two / how þynges han y-stonde.
which I shal with dissimulynge amende.
And beth nought wroth I haue eke vnderstonde.
Ye ne don but holden me in honde.
But now no fors I kan not in yow gesse.
But alle trouþe and alle gentilesse.
Come I wole but yet in swich disioynt.
I stonde as now þat what yer or what day.
That þis shal be þat kan I not apoynte.
But yn effect I prey yow as I may.
Of youre good word and of yowre frendship ay.
For trewely whil [þat] my lyf may dure.
As for a frend ye may in me assure.
Yet preye I yow an yuyl þat ye ne take.
That it is short which þat I to yow write.
I dar not þere I am wel lettres make.
Ne neuere yet ne koude I wel endite.
Of gret effect men write yn place lite.
Thentent is al / and nought þe lettres space.
And fareþ now wel god haue you in his grace.
This lettre þis Troylus þoughte al straunge.
whan he it saugh / and sorwefully he sighte.
Hym þoughte it lyk a kalendes of chaunge.
But fynally he ful ne trowen myghte.
That she now wolde hym holden þat she highte.
For wiþ ful yuel wil lyst hym to leue.
That loueth wel yn swich cas þough hym greue.
But naþeles men seyn þat at the laste.
For ony þing men shal þe sothe se.
And swych a cas by-tidde & þat as faste.
That Troylus wel vnderstod þat she.
Nas not so trewe / as þat here oughte be.
And fynally he wot now out of doute.
That al is lost þat he hath gon a-boute.
Stod on a day in his malencolye.
This Troylus and yn suspecion.
Of here for whom he wende for to dye.
And so bifel þat þorugh-out Troye town.
As was þe gyse y-bore was vp and down.
A manere cote arm[ur]e as seyth þe storye.
Byfore Deiphebe yn signe of his victorye.
The which cote as telleþ lollius.
Deiphebe it had y-rent from Diomede.
The same day / and whan þis Troylus.
It saugh he gan to taken of it hede.
Auysyng of þe lengthe and of þe brede.
And al þe werk / but as he gan byholde.
Ful sodeynly his herte gan to colde.
As he þat on þe coler fond with-Inne.
A broch þat he Criseyde yaf þat morwe.
That she from Troye moste nedes twynne.
In remembraunce of hym / and of his sorwe.
And she hym leyde a-yen here feyth to borwe.
To kepe it ay / but now ful wel he wiste.
Hys lady nas no lengere on to tryste.
He goth hym forth hom / & gan ful soone sende.
For Pandarus and al þis newe chaunce.
And of þis broche he told hym word and ende.
Compleynynge of here hertes variaunce.
His longe loue / his trouþe and his pennaunce.
And after deth with-outen wordes more.
Ful faste he cride his reste hym to restore.
Thanne spak he þus .o. lady myn Criseyde.
wher is youre feyth and wher is youre byheste.
wher is youre loue / wher is youre trouþe he seyde.
Of Diomede haue ye now al þis feste.
Allas I wolde haue trowed at þe leste.
That syn ye nolde yn trouþe to me stonde.
That ye þus nolde han holden me in honde.
Who shal now trowe on any oþer mo.
Allas I neuere wolde han wend er þis.
That ye Criseyde koude han chaunged so.
No but I hadde a-gylt or don amys.
So cruwel wende I not / youre herte y-wys.
To sle me þus / allas youre name of trouþe.
Is now for-don and þat is al my rouþe.
Was þere noon oþer broche yow lyste lete.
To feffe with youre newe loue quod he.
But þilke broche þat I with terys wete.
yow yaf / as for a remembraunce of me.
Non oþer cause allas ne hadde ye.
But for despit / and ek for þat ye mente.
Al outrely to shewe youre entente.
Through which I se þat clene out of youre mynde.
Ye han me cast / and I ne kan nor may.
For al þis world / with-Inne myn herte fynde.
To vnlouen yow a quarter of a day.
In Cursed tyme I born was weylaway.
That ye þat do me al this wo endure.
Yet loue I best of ony creature.
Now god quod he me sende yet þe grace.
That I may meten with þis Diomede.
And trewely yf I haue myght and space.
Yet shal I make I hope his sides blede.
O god quod he þat oughtest taken hede.
To forþeren trouthe / and wronges to punyce.
why nyltow don a vengeaunce on þis vice.
O Pandarus that in dremes for to triste.
Me blamed hast / and wont art ofte vp breyde.
Now maystow se þi selue yf þat þow lyst.
How trewe is now þi nece bryght Cryseyde.
In sondry formes god it wot he seyde.
The goddes shewen boþe Ioye and tene.
In slep and by my drem it is now sene.
And certaynly wiþ-oute more speche.
From hen[ne]sforth as ferforth as I may.
Myn owene deth yn armes wol I seche.
I recche not how soone by þis day.
But trewely Criseyde swete may.
whom I haue ay with al my myght I-serued.
That ye þus don / I haue it nought deserued.
This Pandarus þat alle þese þynges herde.
And wist wel he seyde a soth of þis.
He nought a word a-yen to hym answerede.
For sory of his frendes sorwe he is.
And shamed / for his Nece hath don a-mys.
And stant a-stoned of þese causes tweye.
As stille as ston a word ne koude he seye.
But at þe last þus he spak and seyde.
My dere broþer I may þe do nomore.
what shuld I seyn I hate y-wys Criseyde.
And god wot I wol hate here eueremore.
And þat þou me bysoughtest don of yore.
Hauynge to myn honour ne my reste.
Right no reward I dede al þat þe leste.
If .I. dede ougħt þat myght lyken þe.
It is me lef / and of þis treson now.
God wot þat it a sorwe is vn-to me.
And dredles for hertes ese of yow.
Right fayn wolde I amende it wist I how.
And fro þis world almyghti god I preye.
Delyuere here soone .I. kan nomore seye.
Gret was the sorwe / and pleynt of Troylus.
But forth his cours fortune ay gan to holde.
Criseyde loueth þe sone of Tideus.
And Troylus mot wepe in cares colde.
Swich is þis world who-so it kan biholde.
In eche estat is litel hertes reste.
God leue vs for to take it for þe beste.
In many cruwel batayle out of drede.
Of Troylus / þis ilke noble knyght.
As men may in þese olde bokes rede.
was sene his knyghthod and his grete myght.
And dredles his yre day and nyght.
Ful cruwel[y] þe Grekes ay aboughte.
And alwey most þis Diomede he soughte.
And ofte tyme I fynde þat þey mette.
with blody strokes and with wordes grete.
Assayinge how here speres were whette.
And god it wot with many a cruwel hete.
Gan Troylus vpon his helm to bete.
But naþeles fortune it nought ne wolde.
Of oþeres hond þat eyther deyen sholde.
And yf I hadde y-taken for to wryten.
The armes of þis ilke worthi man.
Than wold I of hise battayles endite[n].
But for þat I to write first bygan.
Of his loue I haue seyd as I kan.
Hese worþi dedes who-so list hem here.
Red dares / he kan telle hem alle y-fere.
Bysechynge euery lady bryght of hewe.
And euery gentil womman what she be.
That al be þat Criseyde was vntrewe.
That for þat gylt She be not wroth with me.
Ye may here gilt in oþere bokes se.
And gladlyer .I. wol write yf yow leste.
Penelopees trouthe and goode Alceste.
Ne I sey not this / al only for þese men.
But most for wommen þat by-traysed be.
Thourgh false folk / god yeue hem sorwe amen.
That with here grete wit / and subtiltee.
By-trayse yow / and þis commeueth me.
To speke / and yn effect yow alle I preye.
Beth war of men / and herkeneth what I seye.
Go litel bok / go litel myn Tregedie.
Ther god þi makere yet er þat he dye.
So sende myght to make yn som comedye.
But litel bok no makyng þow nenuye.
But subgit be to alle poesye.
And kys þe steppes þere as þow seest pace.
Virgile. Ouyde. Omer. Lukan. & Stace.
And for þer is so gret dyuersite.
In Englyssħ / and yn wrytyng of oure tonge.
So preye I god þat noon myswryte þe.
Ne þe mysmetre for defaute of tonge.
And red wher so þou be or elles songe.
That þow be vnderstonde god beseche.
But yet to purpos of my raþere speche.
The wraþe as I began yow for to seye.
Of Troylus / þe Grekes boughten dere.
For þousandys hese hondes maden deye.
As he þat was with-outen ony pere.
Saue Ector yn his tyme as I kan here.
But weylaway saue only goddes wille.
Dispitously hym slowh þe fiers Achille.
And whan þat he was slayn yn þis manere.
His lighte gost ful blysfully is went.
Vp to þe holwghnesse of þe seuenþe spere.
In conuers lettynge euery element.
And þere he saugh with ful auysement.
Th erratyk sterres herkenynge Armonye.
with sownes ful of heuenyssh melodye.
And doun from þens faste he gan auyse.
This litel spot of erþe þat with þe se.
Enbraced is / and fully gan despise.
This wrecched world / and held al vanite.
To respect of þe pleyn felicite.
That is yn heuene aboue / and at þe laste.
Ther he was slayn / his lokyng doun he caste. [Addit. 12,044 ends here.]
And yn hym self he lough right at þe wo.
Of hem þat wepten for his deth so faste.
And dampned al oure werk þat folweth so.
The blynde lust þe which may not laste.
And shuld al oure herte on heuene caste.
And forth he wente shortly for to telle.
Ther as Mercurye sorted hym to dwelle.
Swich fyn hath lo þis Troylus for loue.
Swych fyn hath al his grete worþynesse.
Swich fyn hath his estat real aboue.
Swich fyn his lust / swich fyn hath his noblesse.
Swych fyn hath false worldes brotelnesse.
And þus by-gan his louynge of Criseyde.
As I haue told / and yn þis wyse he deyde.
O yonge fresshe folkes he or she.
In which þat loue / vp groweth with youre age.
Repeyreth hom from worldly vanyte.
And of youre herte vp casteth þe visage.
To thilke god þat after his ymage.
Yow made / and thynketh al nys but a fayre.
This world / þat passeth soone as floures fayre.
And loueth hym þe which þat right for loue.
Vpon a cros oure soules for to beye.
First starf / and ros / and sit yn heuene a-boue.
For he nyl falsen no wight dar I seye.
That wole his herte al holly on hym leye.
And syn he best to loue is / and most meke.
what nedeth feyned loues for to seke.
Lo here of Payens corsed olde vyces.
Lo here what alle hire goddes may auaylle.
Lo here þese wrecched worldes appetites.
Lo here þe fyn and guerdon for trauayle.
Of Ioue / appollo / of mars / of swych rascaylle.
Lo here þe forme of olde clerkes speche.
In poetrie / yf [ye [hole in MS.]] here bokes seche.
O moral Gower þis boke I directe.
To þe / and the Philosophical Strode.
To vouchen sauf / per nede is to corecte.
Of your benygnitees and zeles garde.
And to þat sothfast Crist þat starf on rode.
With al myn herte of mercy euere I preye.
And þe lord right þus I speke and seye.
Thou / oon / and two / and þre / eterne on lyue.
That regnest ay / yn thre / and two / and oon. [l. 1863-5 from Dante]
Vncircumscript and al mayst circumscryue.
Vs from visible and Inuysible foon.
Defende / and to þi mercy eurychon.
So make vs Iesus for thi grace digne.
For loue of mayde and moder thyn benigne. Amen.

HEADNOTE.P: [Harleian MS. 2280, leaf 77.]

LG.HEAD: (1) (Proem)
LG.L: A prechen gan þe fathel destynei
That Ioues hath in dispossisioun
And to ȝow angry parcas sustren thre
Comitteth to don execucioune
For whiche Criseyde most out of þe towne
And Troilus shal dwellen forth in peyne
Til lathesis his thred no longer twyne.

LG.HEAD: (2) (The Story)
LG.L: ¶ Þe gold tressed phebus heigh on loft.
Thries hadde alle with his bemes clere
Þe snowes molte and ȝephirus as ofte
Ybrough[t] aȝeyn þe tender leues grene
Syn þat the sone Troilus of ecuba þe queene
By-gan to loue hire .i. Criseyde firste for whom his sorwe
was alle þat she departe sholde a morwe
¶ Ful redy was at prime Dyomede
Criseyde vn-to þe grekes oste to lede
For sorwe of which she felt hire herte blede
as she þat nyste what was best to rede
And trewly as men in bokes rede
Men wiste neuer womman han þe care
Ne was so loth out of a town to fare
¶ This Troilus with-outen reed or lore
as man þat hath his Ioyes ek fore
was waythynge on his lady euere more
As she þat was sothfaste crop and moore
Of his lust and Ioyes here-to-fore
But Troylus now fare wel al thy Ioye
For shaltow neuere se hire eft in Troye
¶ Soth is þat while he bode in þis manere
He gan his wo ful manly for to hyde
Þat wel vnnethes it sene was in his chere
But at þe ȝate ther she sholde oute ryde
with certeyn folk he houed hire tabide
So by-gan al wolde he nought hym pleyne
Þat on his hors vnneth he sat for pyne
¶ For ire he quook so gan his herte gnawe
when dyomede on hors gan hym dresse
And seyde vn-to hym self þis ilke sawe
Allas quod he þus foule a wrechedenesse
whi suffre ich it whi nyl ich it redresse
were it not bet at oones for to dye
Þan euere more in langoure þus to crye
¶ why nyl I make stones rich and pore
To haue Inough to done or þat she go
whi nyl I brynge alle Troie vp on a rore
whi nyl I slen þis dyomede al so
whi nyl I rather with a man or two
Stele hire a-wey whi wol þis endure
whi nyl holpen to myn swene cure
¶ But whi he nolde don so fel a dede
Þat shal I seyn and whi hym liste it spare
He hadde in herte alweyes a manere drede
Lyste þat Criseyde in Rumour of þis fare
Shold han ben slayn / lo þis was al hise care
and elles certeyn as I seyde yore
He hadde it done with-outen wordes more
¶ Criseyde when she redy was to ride.
Ful sorwfully she sighte and seyde allas
But forth she mot for ought at may bitide
And forth she rite ful sorwfully a pas
Ther is non other remedie in þis cas
Þat wonder is though þat hyre soore smerte
when she for-gothe hire owen swete herte
¶ This Troilus in wyse of curteysie
with hauke on hond and with an huge route
Of knyghtes / rood and dide hyre compaynye
Passynge alle the valeye fer with oute
And ferther wold han riden out of doute
Ful fayn / and wo was hym to gon so soone
But torne he moste and it was eke to done
¶ And right with þat was antenor ycome
Oute of þe grekes oste and euery wight
was of it glad / and seyde he was welcome
And Troilus al nere his herte lighte
He peyned hym with his ful myghte
Hym to with-holde of wepynge at þe leeste
And antenor he kyste and made feeste
¶ And ther-with-al he most his leue take
And caste his eye vp on hire pitously
And neer he rood his cause for to make
To take hire by the honde al sobrely
And lord so she gan wepen tendrely
And [he] ful soft and sleighely gan hire seye
Now hold ȝoure day and do me not to dye
¶ with þat his curser turned he aboute
with face and vnto dyomede
No worde he spak ne non of al his route
Of whiche the sone of Tideus tooke hede
As he þat couthe moore þan þe crede
In swiche a craft and by the reyne hire hynte
And Troilus to troye homwarde he wente.
¶ This Dyomede þat ledde hyre by þe bridel
when þat he saugh þe folk of troye awaye
Thoughte al my laboure shal not be vn hydel
If þat y may for somwhat shal I seye
For at þe werste it may ȝit shorte oure weye
I haue herde he seyde ek tymes twyes twelue
He is a fool þat wol for-ȝete hyme-selue
¶ But naþeles þis thoughte he wel ynoughe
Þat certeinliche I am aboute noughte
If þat I speke of loue or mak it tough
For douteles If she haue in hire thoughte
Hym þat I gesse he may not ben y-brought
So soone aweye but I shal fynde a meene
Þat she nat wit as ȝet shal what I meene
¶ This Dyomede as he þat koude his goode
when þis was don gan fallen forth in speche
Of þis and þat and aixed whi she stood
In swiche disese and gan hire ek by-seche
Þat if þat he encresse mynght or eche
with any thyng hyre ese þat she sholde
Comaunde it hym and seyde he don it wolde
¶ For treweliche he swor hire as a knyghte
Þat ther nas thyng with whiche he myght hire plese
Þat he nolde don his peyne and al his myght
To don it for to don hire hert an ese
And preyde hire she wold hire sorwe apese
And seyde I-wis we grekes kan haue Ioye
To honouren ȝow / as wel [as] folk of Troye
¶ He seyde ek thus I woot ȝow thynketh straunge
No wonder is for it is to ȝowe newe
Thaqueyntaunce of þis Troyans to chaunge
For folk of grece þat ȝe neuere knewe
But wold neuere god / but if as trew
A greke / ȝe shold amang vs al fynde
As any troyan is / and ek as kynde
¶ And by the I swor ȝow right lo now
To ben ȝoure frend and helply to my myghte
And for þat more aqueyntaunce ek of ȝow
haue ich had than a nother straunger wight
So fro this forth I preye ȝow day and nyght
Comaundeth me how sore þat me smerte
To don al þat may like vn-to ȝoure herte
¶ And þat ȝe me wolde as ȝoure brother trete
And taketh nought my frendeschipe in despit
And though ȝoure sorwes ben for thynges grete
Not I nat whi but out of more respit
Myn herte hath for tamende it grete delit
And if I may ȝoure harmes nat redresse
I am right sory for ȝoure heuynesse
¶ For though ȝe troians with us grekes wroth
Han many a day ben alwey ȝet parde
O god of loue in soth we seruen both
And for þe loue of god my laydy fre
whom so ȝe hate as beth not wroth with me
For trewely þer kan no wight ȝow serue
That half so loth ȝoure wreth wold disserue
¶ And ner it þat we ben so neigh the tente
Of calkas which þat sen vs both may
I wold of thys ȝow telle alle myn entente
But this enseled til a nother day
Ȝeue me ȝoure honde I am and shal ben ay
God helpe me so whil þat my lif may dure
Ȝoure owen abouen euery creature
¶ Þus seyde I neuere or now to womman borne
For god myn herte as wisly glade so
I loued neuer womman here be-forne
as paramoures / ne neuere shal no mo
And for þe loue of god beth not my fo
Al kan I nought to ȝow my lady deere
Compleyne aright for I am ȝit to leere
¶ And wondreth nought myn owen lady bryght
Though þat I speke of loue to ȝow þus blyue
For I haue herde or this of many a wight
Hath loued thynge he neuere saugh his lyue
Ek I am not of power for to stryue
Aȝenis the god of loue but hym obeye
I wol alwey and mercy I ȝow preye
¶ Ther ben so worthy knyghtes in þis place
And ȝe so faire þat euerich of hem alle
wol peynen hym to stonden in ȝoure grace
But myght me so faire a grace falle
Þat ȝe me for ȝoure seruaunt wold calle
So lawely ne so trewely ȝow serue
Nyl non of hym / as I shal til I sterue
¶ Criseyde vnto þat purpos lite answerde
As she þat was with sorwe oppressed so
Þat in affect she nought his tales herde
But here and þer now here a worde or two
Hire thought hire sorwful herte braste a-two
For when she gan hire fader fer espie
wel neigh down of hire hors she gan to sye
¶ But natheles she thonked dyomede
Of alle his trauaile and his goode chere
And þat hym liste his frenchep hyre to bede
And she accepteth it in goode manere
And wol do fayne þat is hym lief and deere
And trusten hym she wolde and wel she myghte
As seyde she / and from hire hors shalighte
¶ Hire fader hath hire in his armes ynome
And twenty tyme he kyste his doughter swete
And seyde / o dere doughter myn welcome
She seyde ek she was fayn with hym to mete
And stood forth muwet mylde and mansuete
But here I leue hire with hire fader dwelle
And forth I wol of Troilus ȝow telle
¶ To troye is come this woful Troylus
In sorwe a-bouen alle sorwes smerte
with felon look and face dispitouse
Þo sodeynly doun from his hors he sterte
And thorwgh his payleys with a swollen herte
To chaumbre he wente of no thyng took he hede
Ne non to hym dar speke a worde for drede
¶ And ther his sorwes þat he spared hadde
He ȝaf an issue large and deth he cried
And in hise throwes feruentike and made
He curseth Ioue. appollo and ek cupide
He curseth Ceres / bacus. and cipride
His byrthe / hym self / his fate and ek nature
And saue his lady euery creature
¶ To bedde he goth and weyleth ther and torneth
In furie as doth he Ixion in helle
And in this wyse he neigh til day soiourneth
But tho bigan his herte a lite vnswelle
Thorugh teres whiche þat gonnen vp to welle
And pitously he cried vp on Criseyde
And to hym-self right þus he spake and seyde
¶ Where is myn swene lady lief and deere
Where is hire white breste where is it where
Where ben hir armes and hire eyen clere
Þat ȝesternyght this tyme with me were
Now may I wepe allone many a tere
And graspe aboute I may / but in þis place
Saue a pilwo I fynde naught tenbrace
¶ How shal I don when shal she com aȝein
I not / allas / whi leete ich hire to go
As wold god. ich hadde as tho ben sleyne
O herte myn Criseyde o swete fo
O lady myn that I loue and namo
To whom for euere mo myn herte I dowe
Se how I dye ȝe nyl me not rescowe
¶ Whe seth ȝow now my right lode-sterre
who sit right now or stante in ȝoure presence
who kan conforten nowe ȝoure hertes werre
Now I am gon whom ȝeue ȝe audiens
who speken for me right now in myn absens
allas now wight and þat is al my care
For wel woot I as yuel as I ȝe fare
¶ How shold I þus ten dayes fulle endure
when I the firste nyght haue al this tene
How she don ek sorwful creature
For tendrenesse / how shal she this sustene
Swiche for me o pitous pale grene
Shal ben ȝoure fresche wommanliche face
For langour er ȝe torne vn-to this place
¶ And when he fille in any sloumberynges
Anon by-gynne he shold for to grone
And dremen of þe dredefulleste thynges
Þat myght ben / as mete he were allone
In place horrible makynge ay his mone
Or meten þat he was o-manges alle
his enemys / and in hire honde falle
¶ And ther-with-alle his body sholde sterte
And with þe sterte alle sodeynliche a-wake
And swiche a tremour fele a-boute his herte
Þat of þe fere his body sholden quake
And ther-with-al he sholde a noyse make
And senne as though he shold fal depe
From heigh of loft and þan he wold wepe
¶ And rewen on hym self so pitously
Þat wonder was to here hise fantasye
Another tyme he sholde myghtely
Conforte hym self and seine it was folie
So causeles / whiche drede for to drye
And eft bygynne his aspre sorwes newe
Þat euery man myghte in his sorwes rewe
¶ Who koude telle arighte or ful discryue
His wo / his pleynt / his langoure and his pyne
Nought al þe men þat han or ben on lyue
Thow redere · maist thi-self fulle wele deuyne
Þat swich a wo my wit kan not defyne
On ydel for to write it shold ȝowynke
when þat my wit is wery it to thynke
¶ On heuene ȝet þe sterres waren seene
Al though ful pale ywoxen was þe moone
And whiten gan the orisoune sheene
Al Esturwarde / as it wonte is to done
And Phebus with his rosi carte soone
Gan efter þat to dresse hym vp to fare
When Troilus hath sente efter Pandare
¶ This Pandare þat of al þe day byforne
Ne myght han comen Troilus to see
Al-though he on his hed it hadde sworne
For witht þe kynge Priam alday was he
So þat it lay nought in his liberte
Nower to gon but on þe morwe he wente
To Troilus / when þat he for hym sente
¶ For in his herte he koude wel deuvne
Þat Troilus al nyght for sorw wooke
And þat he wold telle hym of his pyne
Þis knew he wele ynowgh with-outen booke
For which to chaumbre streght þe wey he tooke
And Troilus tho sobrelich he grete
And on þe bed ful soone he gan hym sette
¶ My Pandarus quod Troilus the sorwe
which þat I drye I may not longe endure
I trow I shal not lyuen til to morwe
For whiche I wolde alweys on auenture
To the deuysen of my sepulture
Þe fourme / and of my moble thow dispone
Right as the semeth best is to done
¶ But of þe fir and flaumbe funeral
In which my body brennen shal to glede
And of þe feste and pleyes palestral
At my vigile I preye the take gode hede
Þat þat be wel. and offre mars my stede
My swerd. my helme And leeue brother deere
My shelde to palas ȝef þat shyneth clere .i. dea.
¶ The poudre in whch myn herte ybrend shal turne
Þat preye I the thow tak and it conserue
In a vesseɫɫ þat men clepeth a vrne
Of gold / and to my lady þat I serue
For loue of whom þus pitouslyche I sterue
So ȝeue it hire and do me þis plesaunce
To preyen hire kepe it for a remembraunce
¶ For wel I fele by my maladye
And by my dremes now and yoore a-go
Al certeinly that I mot nedes dye
The owle ek which þat hette esciphilo
hath efter me shright al þis nyghtes two
And god mercurie of me now woful wreche
Þe soule gide and when þe list it fecche
¶ Pandare answerde and seyde Troilus
My deere frende as I haue told þe yoore
Þat it is folie for to sorwen thus
And causels / for whiche I kan namore
But who so wol / nat trowen rede ne lore
I kan not sen in hym no remedie
But lat hym worchen with his fantasie
¶ But Troilus I preye the telle me nowe
If þat thow trowe er þis þat any wight
Hath loued paramours as wel as thow
Ȝe god woot and fro many a worthy knyght
Hath his lady gon a fourtenyghte
And not ȝit made haluendel þe care
What nede is þe to maken alle this fare
¶ Syn day by day thow maist thy-seluen see
Þat from his loue / or elles from his wyf
A man mot twynnen of necessite
Ȝe though he loue hire as his owen life
Þet nyl he thus with hym self þus mak stryf
For wel thow woost my leue brother deere
Þat alwey frendes may nought ben I-feere
¶ How don þis folk þat seen hire loues wedded
By frendes myght / as [it] bitit ful ofte
And sen hem in hire spouses bed y-bedded
God woot / they take it wysely faire and soft
For-whi goode hope halt vp hire herte o loft
And for they kan a tyme of sorwe endure
As tyme hem hurt. a tyme doth hem cure
¶ So sholdestow endure and laten slyde
Þe tyme / and fonde to be glad and light
Ten dayes nys so longe nought tabide
And syn she the to comen hath behight
She nyl hire hest breken for no wight
For drede þe nought þat she nyl fynden weye
To come aȝein / my lif þat dorst I leye
¶ Thy sweuenes ek and alle swich fantasie
Dryue oute / and late hem faren to myschaunce
For they procede of thy malycolye
Þat doth the feele in slepe al þis penaunce
a straw for alle sweuenes signifiaunce
God help me so I counte hem nought a bene
Ther woot no man a right what dremes [re alterd] mene
¶ For prestes of þe temple tellen þis
that dremes ben the reuelacions
Of goddes / and as wel they telle ywis
Þat they ben Infernals illusions
And leches seyn þat of complexions
Proceden they / or fast / or glotonye
who woot in soth þus what they signifie
¶ Ek oother seyn þat thorwgh impressions
As if a wight hath fast a thynge in mynde
Þat þer-of commeth swiche auysions
And oother seyn as they in bokes fynde
Þat efter tymes of þe ȝere by kynde
Men dreme and þat þefect goth by þe moone
But leue no dremen. for it is nought to done
¶ Wel worth of dremes ay this old vyues
And treweliche ek augurye of thise fowelis
For fere of which men wenen leese hire lyues
As rauenes qualm / or schrychynge of thise owlis
To trowen on it both fals and foul is
Allas allas so noble a creature
As is a man / shal dreden swich ordure
¶ For which with alle myn herte I þe beseche
Vn-to þi-self þat alle þis thow foryiue
And ryse now up with-outen more speche
And lat vs cast how forth may best be dryue
Þis tyme / and ek how fresshly we may lyue
when þat she cometh / þe whiche shal be right soone
God help me so thy best is thus to doon
¶ Ris lat vs speke of lusty lif in Troye
Þat we han led / and forth the tyme dryue
And ek of tyme comynge vs reioye
Þat bryngen shal oure blisse now so biliue
And langour of þis twye dayes fyue
we shal þer-with so forȝete oure oppresse
Þat wel vnneth it don shal vs duresse
¶ Þis town is ful of lordes alaboute
And trewes lasten al þis mene qwyle
Go we pleye vs in som lusty route
To sarpeden / not hennes but a myle
And þus thow shalt þe tyme wel bygile
And dryue it forth / vn-to þat blisful morw
Þat thow hire se þat cause is of þi sorwe
¶ Now ris my dere brother Troilus
For certes it non honur is to the
To wepe / and in thy bed to Iouken þus
For trewliche of o thynge trust to me
If thow þus ligge a day or two. or thre
Þe folk wol wene þat thow for cowardyse
The feynest sik / and þat thow darst not rise
¶ This Troilus answarde o brother deere
Þis knowen folk þat han suffred pyne
Þat though he wepe and make sorwful cheere
Þat feeleth harm and smert in euery veyne
No wonder is / and though ich euere pleyne
Or alwey wepe / I nam no thynge to blame
Syn I haue lost þe cause of al my game
¶ But syn of fyne force I moot a-ryse
I shal a-ryse as soone as euer y may
And god to whom myn herte I sacrifise
So send vs hastely the tenthe day
For was ther neuere fowl so fayn of may
As I shal ben / when þat she cometh in troye
Þat cause is of my tormente and my Ioye
¶ But whider is þi reed quod Troilus
Þat we may pleye vs best in al this town
By god my conseile is quod Pandarus
To ryde and pleyne vs with kynge Sarpedoun
So longe of þis they speken vp and down
Til Troilus gan at þe last to assente
To ryse / and forth to Sarpedon they wente
¶ This Sarpedoun as he þat honourable
was euere hys lyue / and ful of heigh prowesse
with al þat myght yserued ben on table
Þat deynte was / al cost it grete rychesse
He fed hym day by day þat swich a noblesse
As seyden bothe þe meest and ek the leeste
was neuere er þat day wiste at any feeste
¶ Nor in þis world ther is noon Instrumente
Delicious / thorugh wynde or touch on corde
As fer as any wight hath euer wente
Þat tonge telle or herte may recorde
Þat at þat feste it nas wel herd a-corde
N of ladyes ek so faire a compaignye
On daunce / er tho / was neuere yseyn with eye oculo
¶ But what auailleth þis To troylus
Þat for his sorwe / no thynge of it roughte
For euere in oon as herte pietus
Ful bisily Criseyde his lady soughte
On hire was euere al þat his herte thoughte
Now þis now that so faste ymagynynge
Þat glad y-wis kan hym no feestynge
¶ Thise laydyes ek þat at þis feeste ben
Seyn þat he saugh his lady was aweye
It was his sorwe vp-on hem for to sen
Or for to here on Instrumentȝ so pleye
For she þat of his herte bereth þe keye
was absente / lo þis was his fantasie
Þat no wight solde maken melodye
¶ Nor ther nas houre in al þe day or nyghte
when he was ther / as nought myght hym here
Þat he ne seyde o lufsom lady bryghte
How haue ȝe farne syn þat ȝe were here
welcom ywys myn owen lady deere
But walaway al this nas boot a maze
Fortune his howen entended bet to glaze
¶ Þe lettres ek þat she of olde tyme
Hadde hym sente / he wold allone rede
An hondreth sythe attwexen none and prime
Refigurynge hire shap hire wommanhede
with-Inne his herte and euery worde or dede
Þat passed was / and þus he droofe tanende
Þe ferth day / and seyde he wolde wende
¶ And seyde leue brother Pandarus
Intendestow þat we shal here bleue.
Til Sarpedon wol forth congeyen vs
Ȝet were it fayrer þat we toke oure leue
For goddes loue lat vs now soone at eue
Oure leue take and hamwarde lat vs torne
For trewely I nyl not thus soiorne
¶ Pandare answerde / be we comen hyder
To fecchen fir / and rennen hom aȝein
God help me so I kan tellen whider
we myghte goon / If I shal sothely seyn
Ther any wight is of vs moore feyn
Than Sarpedon / and we hennes hye
Thus sodeynly / I holde it vilenye
¶ Syn þat we seyden þat we wold bleue
with hym a wowke / and now þus sodeynly
Þe ferth day / to take of hym oure leue
He wold wondren on it trewly
Lat vs holden forth oure purpos fermely
And sen þat ȝe byhighten hym to bide
Holde forward now / and efter lat vs ride
¶ This Pandarus with al peyne and wo
Made hym to dwelle / and at þe wekes end
Of Sarpedon / they tok hire leue tho
And hire weye they spedden hem to wende
Quod Troilus / now lorde me grace sende
Þat I may fynden at myn home comynge
Criseyde comen / and þer-with gan he synge
¶ Ȝe hastow thought this Pandare
And to hym self ful softly he seyde
God woot refreyden may this hoot fare
Er Calkas sende Troilus Criseyde
But natheles he iapet þus and seyde
And swor I-wis / his herte hym wel bihighte
She wold com as soone as euere she myghte
¶ When they vn-to þe peleys were ycomen
Of Troilus / they doun of hors alighte
And to þe chaumbre hire wey than han they nomen
And in to tyme þat it gan to nyghte
They spaken of Criseyde the brighte
And efter þis when þat hem both liste
They spedde hem fro þe soper vn-to reste
¶ O morw as soone as day bigan to clere
This Troilus gan of his slepe to breyde
And to Pandare his owen brother deere
For loue of god ful pitously he preyed
As go we sene þe paleys of Criseyde
For syn we ȝit may haue namoore feeste
So lat vs seen hire paleys at þe leste
¶ And ther-with-alle his menyȝe for to blende
A cause he fonde in towne for to go
And to Criseydes hous they gonnen wende
But lord þis cely Troilus was wo
Hym thought his sorwful herte braste a two
For when he saugh hire dorres spered alle
wel neigh for sorwe a doun he gan to falle
¶ Ther-with when he was ware and gan biholde
How shet was euery wyndow of þe place
As frost hym thoughte his gan to colde
For which with chaunged deellich pale face
with-outen word he forth bygan to pace
And as god wolde he gan so faste ryde
Þat no wight of his contenaunce espied
¶ Than seyde he þus .o paleys desolat
O hous of housses whylom beste yhight
O paleys empti and disconsolat
O thow lanterne of which queynte is þe light
O payleys whilom day þat now ert nyght
wel oughtestow to falle and I to dye
Syn she is wente þat wonte was vs to gye
¶ O paleys whilom crowne of houses alle
Enlumyned with sonne of alle blisse
O rynge fro which þe ruby is out falle
O cause of wo. þat cause hast ben of blisse
Ȝit syn I may no bet fayn wold I kysse
Þe cold dors / dorst I for þis route
And fare wel shryne of which þe seint is oute
¶ Ther-with he caste on Pandarus his ye
with chaunged face / and pitous to beholde
And when he myght his tyme a right espie
ay as he rode to Pandarus he told
His new sorwe / and ek his Ioyes olde
So pitously and with so dede an hewe
Þat euery wight myght on his sorwes rewe
¶ Fro tennes forth he rydeth vp and down
And euery thynge com hym to remembraunce
As he rode forth by þe places of þe town
In which he whilom had alle his plesaunce
Lo ȝonder saugh ich myn owen lady daunce
And in þat temple with hire eyen clere
Me caught firste my right lady deere
¶ And ȝonder haue I herd ful lustili
My deere herte laugh and ȝonder pleye
Saugh ich hire oones ek ful blisfully
And ȝonder oones to me gan she seye
Now goode swete loue me wel I preye
And ȝonder so gladly gan she me be-holde
Þat to þe deth myn herte is to hir holde
¶ And at þat corner in þe ȝonder place
herde I myn alderleuest lady deere
So wommanly with vois melodyous
Syngen so wel / so goodely and so clere
Þat in my soule ȝit me thynketh ich here
Þe blisful sown / and in þat ȝonder place
My lady first me tooke vnto hire grace
¶ Than thought he thus O blisful lord cupide
When þe processe haue in memorye
how thow me hast weryed on euery syde
Men myght a book mak of it lyk a story
What nede is þe to seke on me victorye
Syn I am thyn and holly at þi wille
what Ioye hastow thyn swene folk to spille
¶ Wel hastow ywroke on me thyn Ire
Thow myghty god and dredeful for to greue
Now mercy god thow woost wel I desire
Thy grace / moost of alle lustes leeue
And lyue and dye I wol in thi beleue
For which I naxe in guerdon but a boone
Þat thowe Criseyde aȝein me sende soone
¶ Destreyne hire herte as fast to retourne
As thow doost myn / to longen hire to see
Þan woot I wel þat she nyl naught soiourne
Now blisful lorde so cruwel thow ne be
Vn-to þe blode of Troye I preye þe
as Iuno was vn-to þe blode Thebane
For which þe folk of thebes caught hire bane
¶ And efter this he to þe ȝates wente
Þer as Criseyde oute rode a ful goode pace
And vp and doun þer made he many a wente
And to hem self ful oft he seyde allas
Fro hennes rod my blisse and my solas
As wold blisful god now for his Ioye
I myght hire seen aȝein com in to Troye
¶ And to þe ȝonder hiɫɫ I gan hire gyde
Allas / and ther I took of hire my leeue
And ȝonde I saugh hire to hire fader ryde
For sorwe of which myn herte shal to-cleue
And hider hom I com when it was eue
And here I dwelle out cast from alle Ioye
And shal til I may seen her eft in troye
¶ And of hym-self ymagyned he oft
To ben defet / and pale and waxen lesse
Than he was wont / and þat men seyde softe
what may it be / who kan þe soth gesse
Whi Troylus hath alle þise heuynesse
And al this nas but his malencolye
Þat he hadde of hym-self swich fantasye
¶ Another tyme ymagynen he wolde
Þat euery wyght þat wente by þe weye
Hadde of hym routhe and at they seyne schold
I am right sory Troilus wol deye
And þus he drof a day ȝit forth or tweye
As ȝe han herde swich lyf right gan he lede
As he þat stood bitwixen hope and drede
¶ For whic[h] hym liked in his songes shew
Thenecheson of his wo as he best myghte
And made a song of wordes but a fewe
Somwhat his woful herte for to lighte
And when he was from euery mannes sighte
with soft vois / he of his lady deere
That absent was / gan synge as ȝe may here

LG.HEAD: [C]antus Troili [in margin] (92)
LG.L: ¶ O sterre of which I lost haue alle þe lighte
with herte soore wel oughte I to bewaylle
Þat euere derk in tormente nyght by nyght
Towarde my deth / with wynde in steere I saylle
For whiche þe tenthe nyght If þat I faile
Þe gidynge of þi bemes bright an houre
My ship and me Caribdes wol deuoure
¶ Þis songe when he þus songen hadde soone
He fel aȝein in to his sikes olde
And euery nyght as was his wone to doone
He stood þe bryght mone to be-holde
And al his sorwe he to þe moone tolde
And seyde I-wis / when thow ert horned newe
I shal be glad / if alle þe world be trewe
¶ I saugh thyne hornes old ek by þe morw
When hennes rode my right lady deere
Þat cause is of my torment and my sorwe
For which o bryght latona the cleere
For loue of god renne fast aboute thy spere
For when thyne hornes new gynnen sprynge
Þan shal she come þat may my blisse brynge
¶ The dayes moore and longer euere nygh
Þan þey ben wonte te be hym thought tho
And þat þe sonne wente his course vnright
By longer weye þan it was wonte to go
And seyde I-wis me dredeth euere moo
The sonnes sone / Pheton be on lyue
And þat his fader carte a-mys he dryue
¶ Vp on the walles fast ek wold he walke
And on þe grekes Oost he wold se
And to hym self right þus he wold talke
Lo ȝonder is myn swene lady free
Or elles ȝonder ther the tentes bee
And thennes cometh this eyr þat is so soot
Þat in my soule I feele it doth me boote
¶ And hardyly þis wynde þat moore and moore
Þus stoundemele encresseth in my face
Is of my ladys depe sykes sore
I preue it thus / for in noon nother place
Of al this town / saue oonly in þis space
Feele I no wynde / þat souneth so lyke peyne
It seith allas / whi twynned be we tweyne
¶ This longe tyme he dryueth forth right þus
Tiɫɫ fully passed was the nynthe nyght
And ay by syde hym was Pandarus
Þat bisily dide al his ful myght
Hym to conforth and mak his herte light
Ȝeuynge hym hope alweye þe tenthe morwe
Þat she shal come and stenten al his sorwe
¶ Vp on þat other syde eke was Crisseyde
with wommen few / omange þe grekes stronge
For which ful oft a day / allas she seyde
Þat I was borne / wel may myn herte longe
after my deth / for now lyue I to longe
Allas / and I ne may it not amende
For now is wers þan euere ȝit I wende
¶ My fader nyl for thynge do me grace
To gon aȝein / for nought I kan hym queme
And if so be þat I my terme pace
My Troilus shal in his herte deme
Þat I am fals / and so it may wel seme
Þus shal ich haue vnthonke on euery syde
Þat I was borne / so walawey þe tyde
¶ And if þat I me put in Iupartye
To stele awey by nyght / and it be-falle
Þat I be caught / I shal be hold a spye
Or elles lo / þis drede I moost of alle
If in þe hondes of som wreche I falle
I nam but lost / al be myn herte trewe
Now myghty god thow on my sorwe rewe
¶ Ful pale ywoxen was hire bright face
Hire lymes lene / as she þat al þe day
Stood when þat she dorste / and loked on þe place
Ther she was borne / and she dwelt had ay
And al þe nyght wepynge allas she lay
And þus despeyred oute of alle cure
She ledde hire lyf this woful creature.
¶ Ful oft a day she sighte ek for destresse
And in hire-self she wente ay portreynge
Of Troilus the grete worthinesse
And alle his goodely wordes recordynge
Syn first þe day hire loue bigan to sprynge
And þus she sette hire woful herte afire
Thorugh remembraunce of þat she gan desire
¶ In al þis world ther nys so cruwel herte
That hire hadde herd compleyne in hire destresse
Þat nold han wopen for hire peynes smerte
So tendrely she wepte bothe eue and morwe
Hire neded non teris for to borwe
And þus was ȝet the werste of al hyre peyne
Ther was no wight to whom she dorst hire pleyne
¶ Ful Ioyful she loked vp on troye
By-helde þe toures heigh and ek þe hallis
Allas quod she the plesaunce and þe Ioye
The which that now al tourned in-to galle is
Haue ich hadde oft with-Inne þo ȝonder wallis
O Troilus what dostow now she seyde
Lord whether thow thy[n]ke ȝet vp-on Criseyde
¶ Allas I madde ytrowed on ȝoure lore
And wente with ȝow / as ȝe me redde or this
Thanne hadde I now not siked half so sore
who myght han seyde þat I had don a-mys
To stele away with swich oon as he is
But al to late cometh the latuarye
when men the cors vn-to the graue [carye]
¶ To late is now to speke of þat matere
Prudens allas oon of thyn eyn thre
Me lakked alwey er þat I com here
On tyme presente wel remembred me
And present tyme ek koude ich wel ysee
But future tyme er I was in þe snare
Koude I not sen þat causeth now my care
¶ But natheles bitide what bitide
I shal to morw at nyght by est or weste
Out of þis oost stele in som manere syde
And gon with Troilus wher as hym leste
This purpos wol I hold and this is beste
No fors of wikked tonges Ianglerye
For euere on loue han wreches hadde envye
¶ For who so wole of euery worde tak hede
Or rulen hym by euery wightes wit
Ne shal he neuere thryuen out of drede
For þat at som men blamen euere ȝit
loo other maner folk comenden it
And as for me for alle swich variaunce
Felicite clepe I my suffisaunce
¶ For which with-outen any wordes moo
To Troye I wol as for conclusion
But god it woot er fully monthes two
She was ful fer fro þat entencioun
For both Troilus and Troyes town
Shal knotles thorugh-out hir herte slyde
For she wol take a purpos for tabide
¶ This Dyomede of whom ȝow telle I gan
Goth now with-Inne hym self ay arguynge
with al þe sleughte / and alle þat euere he kan
How he may best with shortest taryinge
In to his net Criseydes herte brynge
To þis entente he koude neuere fyne
To fisshen hire he layde out hook and lyne
¶ But natheles wel in his herte he thoughte
Þat she nas nat with-out a loue in Troye
For neuere sithen he hire thennes broughte
Ne koude he sen hire laughe or maken Ioye
He nyst how best hire for tacoie
But for tassie he seyde nought it ne greueth
For he þat nought nasayeth nought nacheueth
¶ Ȝet sayde he to hymself vp-on a nyght
Now am I nought a fool þat woot wel how
Hire wo for loue his of a nother wight
And hire-vp-on to gon asaye hire nowe
I may wel wete it nyl not ben my prow
For wyse folk in bokes it expresse
Men shal nought wowe a wight in heuynesse
¶ But who-so myght wynnen swich a floure
From hym for whom she morneth nyght and day
He myght seyn he were a conqueroure
And right anon as he þat bolde was ay
Thought in his herte happe how happe may
Al shold I dye I wol hire herte seche
I shal namore lesen but my speche
¶ This Dyomede as bokes us declare
was in his nedes prest and corageus
witht stierne vois / and myghty lymes square
Hardy / testis / strong / and chiualrus
Of dedes like his fader tydeus
And som men seyn he was of tonge large
And heire he was of Calidoyne and arge
¶ Criseyde men was of hire stature
Ther-to of shap / of face / and ek cheere
Þer myght be no fairer creature
And oft tyme this was hire manere
To gon ytressed with hire heres clere
Doun by hire coler at hire bak by-hynde
with which a threde of gold she wold bynde
¶ And saue hire browes Ioyneden Ifeere
Þar nas no lakke in ought I kan espien
But for to speken of hyre eyen clere
Loo trewely they writen þat hire syen
Þat paradys stood formed in hire yen
And hire riche beaute euere more
Strof loue in hire / ay whiche of hem was moore
¶ She sobre was / ek symple and wyse wiþ alle
Þe best y-norissed ek þat myght be
And goodely of hire speche in general
Cherytable estatliche lusty / and free /
Ne neuere moo ne lakked hire pyte
Tendre herted / slidynge of corage
But trewly I kan not telle hire age
¶ And Troilus wel woxen was in heighte
And complet formed by proporcioun
So wel þat kynde it nought amenden myght
Yongh fresshe / strong / and hardy as lyon
Trew as steele in ech condicioun
On the best enteched creature
Þat is or shal / while þat þe world may dure
¶ And certeinly in story it is y-founde
Þat Troilus was neuere vn-to no wight
As in his tyme in no degre secunde
In duryng do þat longeth to a knyghte
Al myght a geaunt passen hym of myght
His herte ay with þe firste and with þe beste
Stod paregal to durre to do þat hym leste
¶ But for to tellen forth of Dyomede
It fel þat efter on þat tenthe day
Syn þat Criseyde out of þe Cite ȝode
This Dyomede as fressh as braunche in may
Com to þe tente ther as Crisseyde lay
And feyned hym with Calkas han to doon
But what he mente I shal ȝow tellen soone
¶ Criseyde at shorte wordes for to telle
welcom hym / and doun by hire hym sette
And he was ethe y-nough to maken dwelle
And efter þis with-outen longe lette
Þe spices and þe wyn men forth hym fette
And forth they speke of þis and þat yfeere
As frendes don / of whiche som shal ȝe here
¶ He gan firste to fallen of þe werre in speche
By-twyxen hem / and þe folk of Troye toun
And of thassege he gan hire ek be-seche
To telle him what was hire opynyoun
Fro þat demaunde he so descendeth doun
To axen hire / if þat hire straunge thought
Þe grekis gyse / and werkes þat they wroughte
¶ And whi hire fader tarieth so longe
To wedden hire / vn-to som worthy wighte
Crisede þat was in hire peynes stronge
For loue of Troilus hire swene kynghte
As fer forthe as she konnynge hadde or myght
Answerde hym tho / but as of his entente
It semed not she wiste what he mente
¶ But natheles this ilke Dyomede
Gan in hym self asseure / and thus he seyde
If ich arighte haue taken of ȝow hede
Me thynketh this o lady myn Crisseyde
Þat syn I firste honde on ȝoure bridel layde
when ȝe out com of Troye by þe morwe
Ne koude I neuere sen ȝow but in sorwe
¶ Kan I not seyn / what may þe cause be
But if for loue of som Troyan it were
Þe which right soore woolde a-thynken me
Þat ȝe for any wighte þat dwelleth there
Sholden spille a quarter of a teere
Or pitously ȝoure-seluen so bygile
For dredeles it is nought worth the while
¶ The folk of Troye as who seith alle and some
In prison ben / as ȝe ȝoure-seluen see
For thennes shal not oon on lyue come
For al þe gold atwixen sonne and see
Trusteth wel and vnderstondeth me
Þer shal not oon to mercy gon on lyue
Al were he lord of worldeles twyes fyue
¶ Swich wreche on hem for fecchynge of Eleyne
Þer shal ben take er þat we hennes wende
Þat manes which þat goddes ben of pyne
Shal ben agaste þat grekes wol hem shende
And men shul drede vn-to þe worldes ende
From hennes forth to rauysshen any queene
So cruel shal our wreche on hem be seene
¶ And but if Calkas lede vs with ambages
Þat is to seyn with dowble wordes sleye
Swich as men clepe a worde with two visages
Ȝe shal wel knowen þat I nought ne lye
And al this thynge right syn it with ȝoure ye
And þat anoon / ȝe nyl not trow how soone
Now taketh hede / for it is for to doone
¶ what wene ȝe ȝoure wyse fader wolde
Haue ȝeuen antenor for ȝow o-noon
If he ne wiste þat þe Cite sholde
Destrued ben / why nay so mot I gon
He knewe ful wel ther not scapen oon
Þat Troian is / and for þe grete feere
he dorst not ȝe dwelt longer there
¶ What wol ȝe moore lufsom lady deere
Late Troye and Troian fro ȝoure herte pace
Dryue oute þat bittre hope and make goode shere
And clepe aȝein þe beaute of ȝoure face
Þat ȝe with salt teeris so deface
For Troye is brought in swich a Iupartye
Þat it to saue is now no remedye
¶ And thenketh wel ȝe shal in grekes fynde
A moore parfite loue / or it be nyght
Thanne any Troian is / and moore kynde
And bet to seruen ȝow wol don his myght
And if ȝe vowche saufe my lady bryghte
I wol ben he to seruen ȝow me-selfue
Ȝe leuere þan ben a lord of grekes Twelue
¶ And with þat worde he gan to wexen rede
And in his speche a litel wight he quooke
And caste a-side a litel wight his hed
And stynte a while / and efter-warde he wooke
And sobreliche on hire he threw his looke
and seyde I am / al be it ȝow no Ioye
As gentil man / as any wighte in Troie
¶ For if my fader Tydeus he seyde
Yliued hadde / ich hadde ben or this
Of Calidoyne and arge a kyng Criseyde
And so hope I þat I shal ȝit ywys
But he was slayne allas þe moore harme is
Vnhapplye at Thebes al to rathe
Polymyte and many a man to scathe
¶ But herte myn syn þat I am ȝoure man
And ben þe firste / of whom I seche grace
To serue ȝow as hertly as I kan
And euere shal. while I to lyue haue spece
So er þat I departe out of þis place
Ȝe wol me graunte þat I may to morwe
At better layser telle ȝow my sorwe
¶ What sholde I telle hise wordes þat he seyde
He spake I-nowgh for a day atte meeste
It preuet wel / he spak so þat Criseyde
Graunted on þe morwe at his requeste
For to speken with hym atte leste
So þat he nold speke of swiche matere
And þus she to hym seyde / as ȝe mow here
¶ As she þat hadde hire herte on Troilus
So faste // þat ther may it noon arace
And straungely she spak and seyde þus
O Diomede I loue þat ilke place
Þer I was borne / and Ioues for his grace
Delyuere it soone / of alle þat doth it care
God for þi myght so lene it wel to fare
¶ That grekes wolde hire wrath on Troye wreke
If þat they myght / I know it wel ywis
But It schal nought byfallen as ȝe speke
And god to-forne / and ferther ouer this
I woot my fader wyse and redy is
And þat he me hath bought as ȝe me tolde
Soo deere / I am þe more vn-to hym holde
¶ Þat grekes ben of heigh condicioun
I wot ek wel but certein men shal fynde
As wory folk with-Inne Troye town
As konnynge and as parfite and as kynde
As ben betwyxen Orcades and Inde
And that ȝe koude wele ȝoure lady serue
I trow ek wel hire thenke for to desserue
¶ But as to speke of loue I-wis she seyde
I had a lord to whom I wedded was
The whos myn herte al was til þat he sayde
And other loue as help me now pallas
Ther in myn herte nys ne neuere was
And þat ȝe ben of noble and heigh kynrede
I haue wel now herd it tellen out of drede
¶ And þat doth me to han so grete a wonnder
That ȝe wol scornen any womman so
Ek god woot loue and I ben fer a sonder
I am disposed but so mot I go
Vn-to my deth to pleyne and maken wo
what I shal efter don I kan not seye
But trewlich as ȝet me luste not pley
¶ Myn herte is now in tribulacion
And ȝe in armes bysi day and day
Here-efter when ȝe wonnen han þe town
Paraunter than so it happen may
Þat when I se þat I neuere er say
Thanne wol I werk þat I neuere wroghte
Þis word to ȝow ynough suffisen oughte
¶ To morwe eke wol I speke with ȝow fayne
So þat ȝe touchen nought of þis matere
And when ȝow luste ȝe may com here aȝeynne
And er ȝe gon thus muche I seye ȝow here
As helpe me pallas with hire eres clere
If þat I sholde of any greke han routhe
It shold be ȝoure-seluen be my trouthe
¶ I say not þer-fore þat I wol ȝow loue
Ny say not nay but in conclusioun
I mene wele by god that sitt a-boue
And þer-with-al she caste hire eyen down
And gan to syke and seyde o Troilus town
Ȝit bid I god in quiete and in reste
I may ȝow sen or do myn herte breste
¶ But in affect and shortly for to seyne
Þis Diomede alle fresshly newe aȝein
Gan presen on and fast hyre mercy preye
And efter þis the soth for to seyne
Hire gloue he toke of wiche he was ful fayne
And finaly when it was woxen eue
And alle was wel / he roos and tooke his leue
Þe bright venus folwed and ay taughte
Þe wey Ther brode Phebus doun a-lighte
And Cynthea hire char hors ouer raughte
