To whirle out of þe leon if she myghte
And signifer his candels sheweth brighte
when þat Criseyde vn-to hire bedde wente
In-with hire fadres faire bryghte tente
¶ Retournynge in hir soule ay vp and doun
Þe wordes of þis sodeyn diomede
his grete estate and peril of the town
And þat she was allon and hadde nede
Of frendes help and þus bygan to brede
Þe cause whi þe soth for to telle
Þat sche tok fully þe purpos for to dwelle
¶ The morwen com and gostly for to speke
Þis Diomede is com vn-to Criseyde
And shortly liste þat ȝe my tale
So wel he for hym self spake and seyde
Þat alle hire sykes soore adown he layde
And finaly þe sothe for to seyne
He ref hire of þe grete of al hire peyne
¶ And efter þis þe storye telle vs
Þat she him ȝaf þe faire bay steede
The whiche he ones wan of Troilus
And eke a broch and þat was litel nede
That Troilus was / she ȝaf þis Diomede
And ek þe bet from sorw hym to releue
She made hym were a pensel of hire sleue
¶ I fynde ek in þe stories elles where
when thorugh þe body hirte was Dyomede
Of Troilus / þo wepte she many a teere
When þat she saugh hise wyde woundes blede
And þat she toke to kepen hym good hede
And for to helen hym of his sorwes smerte
Men seyn I not þat she ȝaf hym hire herte
¶ But trewelyche the storye telleth vs
Ther made neuere womman more wo
Than she when þat she falsed Troylus
She allas for now is clene ago
My name of trouthe in loue for euere mo
For I haue falsed oon the gentileste
Þat euere was / and oon the worthyeste
¶ Allas of me vn-to the wordes ende
Shal noither ben y-writen nor y-song
No good worde / for this boks wol me shende
O rolled schal I ben on many a tonge
Thorugh-out þe wold my bel schal be ronge
And wommen most wol haten me of alle
Allas þat swich a cas me sholde falle
¶ They wol seyn in as muche as in me is
I haue hem don deshonoure walaway
Al be I not þe firste þat dide amys
what helpeth þat to don my blame away
But syn I se þer is no better way
And þat to late is now for me to rewe
To dyomede algate I wol be trewe
¶ But Troilus syn I no bettre may
And syn þat þus departen ȝe and I
Ȝet preye god so ȝeue ȝow right good day
as for þe gentileste trewely
Þat euere y say to seruen faithfully
And beste kan ay his honour kepe
And witht þat word she braste anon to wepe
¶ And certes ȝow to haten shal I neuere
And frendes loue / þat shal ȝe han of me
And my good worde / al shold I lyue euere
And trewly I wol sory be
For to sen ȝow in aduersite
And giltelees I wot wel I ȝow leeue
But alle shal passe and þus tak I my leue
¶ But trewly how longe it was betweyne
Þat she forsoke hym for this Dyomede
Ther is non auctour telleth it I wene
Tak euery man now to his bokes hede
He shal no terme fynden out of drede
For though þat he bigan to wow hire soone
Er he hire wan ȝet was there more to doone
¶ Ne me ne list this sely womman chyde
For-ther þanne the storie wol deuyse
Hire name allas is punyshed so wyde
That for hire gilte it ought y-nough suffise
And if I myght excuse hire any wyse
For she sory was for vntrouthe
I-wis I wold excuse hire ȝet for routhe
¶ This Troilus I before haue told
Þus dryueth forth as wel as he hathe myght
But oft was his herte hote and colde
And namely þat ilke nynthe nyght
whiche on þe morwe she hadde hym by-hight
To com aȝeyn god woot ful litel reste
hadde he þat nyght no thynge to slepe hym liste
¶ The laurer crowned phebus with his hete
Gan in his cours ay vpwarde as he wente
To war men of þe est se þe wawes wete
And nysus doughter song with fressh entente
When Troilus his Pandare efter sente
And on þe walles of þe town þei pleyde
To loke if they kan sen ought of Criseydo
¶ Til it was none they stood for to se
who ther come and euery manere wight
Þat com fro fer they seyden it was she
Til þat thei koude knowen hym aright
Now was his herte dul / now was it light
And thus bi-Iaped stonden for to starei
Aboute nought this Troilus and Pandare
¶ To Pandarus This Troilus tho seyde
For ought I woot by-for noon sykerly
In to þis town ne cometh not here Criseide
She hath y-nough to don hardily
To wynnen from hire fader so trow I
Hire olde fader wol ȝet make hire dyne
Er þat she go. god ȝeue his herte pyne
¶ Pandare answarde it may wel be certein
And for-thy lat vs dyne I the beseche
And after noon than maistow com Aȝein
And hom they go with-outen moore speche
And comen aȝein / but longe may they seche
Er þat thei fynde þat they efter cape
Fortune hem both thenketh for to Iape
¶ Quod Troilus I se wel now that she
Is taried with hire olde fader so
Þat er she come it wol neigh euen be
Come forth I wol vnto ȝe ȝate go
Thise portours ben vnkonnynge euere mo
And I wol don hem holden vp the ȝate
As nought ne were al-though she come late
¶ The day goth fast and efter þat cometh eue
And ȝet com nought To Troilus Criseyde
He loketh forth by hegg by tre by greue
And fer his hed ouer þe walle he layde
And at þe laste he torned hym and seyde
By god I wot hire menynge now pandare
Al-moost I-wys al new is my care
¶ Now douteles this lady kan hire good
I wote she meneth riden priuely
I comende hire wysdom by myn hode
She wol not maken peple nycely
Gaure on hire when þat she comth [overline but here: P later] softly
By nyght in to the town she thenketh ride
And dere brother thenke not longe tabide
¶ We han nought elles for to don I-wys
And Pandarus now woltow trowen me
Haue here my trouthe I se hire ȝonde she is
Heue vp thyn eyen man maistow not se
Pandare answerde nay so moot I the
Al wronge by god what seistow man wher arte
Þat I se ȝond is but a fare carte
¶ Allas thow saist right soth quod Troilus
But hardely it is not al for nought
Þat in myn herte I now reIoysse thus
It is aȝeins som good I haue a thought
Not I not how / but sen þat I was wroughte
Ne felt I swich a confort dar I seye
She comth to nyght my life þat dorste I laye
¶ Pandare answerd it may be wel ynough
And helde with hym of al þat euer he seyde
But in his herte he thought and softly lough
And to hym self sobreliche he seyde
From haselwodde ther Iolye robin pleyde
Shal com al þat thow abydest here
And fare wel al the snowgh of fernyere
¶ The wardeyn of þe ȝates gan to calle
Þe folk which þat with-oute þe ȝates were
And bad hem dryuen in hire bestes alle
Or al þe nyght they most bleuen there
And fer wiþ-Inne nyght wiþ many a teere
This Troilus gan homwarde for to ride
For wel he seth it helpeth nought tabyde
¶ But natheles he gladded hym in this
He thoughte he mysacounted hadde his day
And seyde I vnderstonde I haue al amys
For þilke nyght I laste Criseyde seye
She seyde I shal ben here If þat I may
Er þat þe moone o deere herte swete
The leon̄ passe oute of this ariete
¶ For which she may ȝet holde al hire biheste
And on þe morwe vn-to þe ȝate he wente
And vp and down by weste and ek bi este
Vp on the walles made he many a wente
But al for nought / his hope alwey hym blente
For which at nyght in sorwes and sikes sore
He wente hym home with-outen any moore
¶ His hope al clene out of his herte fledde
He nath wher-on now longer for to honge
But for þe peyne hym thought his hert bledde
So were his throwes sharpe and wonder stronge
For when he saugh þat she aboode so longe
He nyste what he Iuggen of it myghte
Syn she hath broken þat she hym byhighte
¶ The / thridde / ferthe / fyfte / sexte day
After þo dayes ten. of whiche I tolde
Betwixen hope and drede his hert lay
Ȝet somwhat trusten on hire hestes olde
But when he saugh she nold hire terme holde
He kan now sen non other remedye
But for to shape hym sone for to dye
¶ Ther-with þe wykked spirit god vs blisse
whiche þat men clepeth wode Ialousie
Gan in hym crepe in al þis heuynesse
For whiche be cause he wold soone dye
He ne ete ne dranke for his melencolye
And ek from euery compaynye he fledde
This was þe lyf þat al þe tyme he ledde
¶ He so defet was that no maner man
Vnneth hym myght knowen there he wente
So was he leen and ther-to pale and wan
And fieble þat he walketh by potente
And with his Ire he thus hym seluen shente
But who-so axed hym wher-of hym smerte
He seyde his harme was al aboute his herte
¶ Priam ful ofte and ek his moder deere
His bretheren and his sustren gonne hym freyne
Whi he so sorwful was in al his cheere
And what thyng was þe cause of al his peyne
But al for nought he nold his cause pleyne
But seyde he felte a greuous maladye
Aboute his herte / and fayne he wolde dye
¶ So on a day he layde hym down to slepe
And so byfel þat in his slepe hym thoughte
Þat a forest faste he welke to wepe
For loue of hire þat hym thise peynes wroughte
And vp and doun as he þat forest soughte
He mette he saugh a boor with tuskes grete
Þat slepte aȝein the brighte sonnes hete
¶ And by þis boor fast in hir armes folde
Lay kyssyng ay his lady bright Criseyde
For sorw of which whan he gan biholde
And for despit out of his slepe he breyde
And loude he criede on Pandarus and seyde
O Pandarus now know I crope and roote
I nam bot ded ther is non other boote
¶ My lady bryghte Criseyde hath me bytrayed
In whom I trusted moost of any wighte
She elles where hath now hire herte apeyde
Þe blisful goddes thorwgh hire grete myghte
han in my drem y-shewed it ful righte
Þus in my drem Criseyde haue I biholde
And al þis thynge to Pandarus he tolde
¶ O my Criseyde allas what subtilite
what new luste what beaute / whate science
what wrathe of Iuste cause have ȝe to me
what gilte of me what fel experience
hath fro me raft allas thyn aduertence
O trust / o feith / o depe eseuraunce
who hath me reft Criseyde al my plesaunce
¶ Allas whi lett ich ȝow from hennes go
For which wel neigh out of my wit I breyde
who shal now trowe on any othes moo
God woot I wende o lady bright Criseyde
Þat euery word was gospel þat ȝe seyde
But who may beste bigile If hym liste
Þan he on whom men weneth best to triste
¶ what shal I don my Pandarus allas
I fele nowe so sharpe a new peyne
Syn þat ther is no remedye in þis cas
Þat bet were it I with myn hondes tweyne
My-seluen slewe alwey þan thus to pleyne
For thorwgh þe deth my wo shold haue an ende
Þat euery day with lif my self I shende
¶ Pandare answerde and seyde allas þe while
Þat I was born haue I not seyde or this
Þat dremes many a maner man bigiles
And whi for folk expounden hem amys
How darstow seyn þat fals thy lady is
For any dreme / right for thyn owen drede
Lat be þis thought thow kanst no dremes rede
¶ Paraunter ther thow dremest of þis boor
It may so be þat it may signifye
Hire whiche þat old is and ek hoor
Aȝein þe sonne lyth o poynte to dye
And she for sorwe gynneth wepte and crye
And kysseth hym þer he lyth on þe grounde
Þus sholdestow thy dreme aright expounde
¶ How myght than don quod Troilus
To know of this ȝe were it neuere so lite
Now seystow wisely quod this pandarus
My rede is þis syn thow kanst wel endite
Þat hastily a letre thow hire write
Thorugh whiche thow shalt wel bryngen it aboute
To knowe a soth of þat thow ert in doute
And se now why for this I dar wel seyn
Þat if so is þat she vntrewe be
I kan not trowen þat wol write aȝein
And if she write thow shal ful soon se
As whether she hath any liberte
To come aȝein or elles in som clause
If she be let she wol asigne a cause
¶ Thow hast not writon hire syn þat she wente
Nor che to þe / and this I dorst laye
Ther may swich cause ben in hire entente
Þat hardily thow wolt thy-seluen seye
Þat hire abood þe best is for ȝow tweyne
Now write hire than and thow shal fele soone
A sothe of al ther is na moore to doon
¶ Acorded ben to þis conclusion
And þat anon thise ilke lordes two
And hastily sit Troilus a doun
And rolleth in his herte to and fra
How he may best descryuen hire his wo
And to Criseyde his owen lady deere
He wrote righte right thus and seyde as may here

LG.HEAD: (189) [Epistola Tr]oili [in margin]
LG.L: ¶ Right fresshe floure whos I ben haue and shal
with-outen part of elles where seruyse
with herte body lyf lust thought and alle
I woful wight in euerych humble wyse
Þat tonge telle or herte may deuyse
As oft as matere occupieth place
Me recomaunde vn-to ȝoure noble grace
¶ Liketh ȝow to wyten swete herte
As ȝe wel knowe how longe tyme agon
Þat ȝe me left in aspre peynes smerte
when that ȝe wente of which boote non
Haue I non had / but euere wors bigoon
Fro day to day am I and so mot dwelle
while it ȝow liste of wele and wo my welle
¶ For which to ȝow with dredeful herte trewe
I write / as he þat sorwe drifth to write
My wo þat euery houre encresseth new
Compleynynge as I dar or kan endite
And þat defaced is þat may ȝe wite
Þe teres which þat fro myn eyen reyne
They wolden speke If þat they koude and pleyne
¶ Ȝow first beseche I þat ȝoure eyen clere
To look on þis defouled ȝe nat hold
And ouer al þis þat ȝe my lady dere
Wol vouch-saufe this letre to be-holde
And by þe cause ek of my cares colde
Þat sleth my wit if ought amys masterte
For-ȝeue it me myn owen swete herte

DIV3.P: (A leaf out of Harl. 2280.)

LG.L: ¶ But in hire letre made she swich feeste
Þat wonder was and swerth she loueth hym beste
Of which he fonde boot botmeles biheste
But troilus thou maist now est or weste
Pipe in an Iuy leefe if þat the leste
thus goth þe world god shilde vs fro meschaunce
And euery wight þat meneth trouthe 1 auance 1 [1-1 late]
¶ Encressen gan the wo fro day to nyght
Of Troilus / for tarrynge of Criseyde
And lessen gan his hope and ek his myght
For which al doun he in his bed hym layde
He ne ete / ne / dronk / ne slepe / ne worde seyde
Ymagynynge ay þat she was vnkynde
For which wel neigh he wex out of his mynde
¶ This dreme of which I tolde haue ek biforne
May neuere come out of his remembraunce
He thought ay wel he had his lady lorne
And þat Ioues of his purueiaunce
Hym shewed hadde in slepe the signifiaunce
Of hire vntrouth and his disauenture
And þat þe boor was shewed hym in figure
¶ For which he for sibille his suster sente
Þat called was cassandre al aboute
and al his dreme he told hire or he stente
And hire bysought assoylen hym the doute
Of þe stronge boor with tuskes stoute
And finaly with-Inne a litel stounde
Cassandre by-gan right thus his dreme expounde
¶ She gan first smyle and seyde brother deere
If thow a soth of this desirest knowe
Thow most a fewe of oldde stories here
To purpos how þat fortune ouer-throwe
Hath lordes old / thorwgh which with-Inne a trowe
Thow wel þis boor shalt know and of what kynde
he comen is / as men in bokes fynde
¶ Diane which þat wroth was and in Ire
For grekes nold don hire sacrifise
Nencens vp on hire auter sette a fire
So for þat greekes gonne hire so despise
Wrak hir in a wonder cruwel wyse
For with a boor as grete as ox in stalle
She made vp frete hire corne and vynes alle
¶ To sle þis boor was al þe contre raysed
O-manges which ther come þis boor to se
A maide on of þis worlde þe best preysed
And melage lorde of that contre
He loued so this fresshe mayden free
Þat with his manhode or he wolde stente
Þis boor he slough and hire þe hed he sente
¶ Of which as old bokes tellen vs
Ther roos a contek and a grete enuye
And of this lorde descended Tideus
By ligne / or elles old bokes lye
And how this meleagre gan to dye
Thorwgh his moder wol I ȝow nought telle
For al to long it were for to dwelle
¶ She told ek how Tideus or she stente
Vn-to þe stronge cite of thebes
To cleymen kyngdom of the cite wente
For his felawe daun Polimytes
Of whiche the brother daun Ethiocles
Ful wrongfully of thebes held þe strenghthe
This told she by proces al bi lengthe
¶ She told ek how hemonydes asterte
when Tideus slough fifty knygthes stoute
She told ek al þe prophecies by herte
And how þat vij kynges with hire route
Be-segeden the Cite alle a-boute
And of þe holy serpent and the welle
And of þe furies al she gan hym telle

DIV3.P: [Argument of the 12 Books of Statius's Thebais.]

LG.L: ¶ Associat profugum Tideo primus polymytem
Tidea legatum docet insidiasque secundus
Tercius Hemoduden canit & vates latitantes
Quartus habet reges ineuntes prelia septem
Mox furie lenne quinto narrantur & anguis
Archimori bustum sexto ludusque leguntur
Dat grayos thebes & vatem septimus vmbris
Octauo cecidit Tideus spes vita pelasgis
Ypomedon nono moritur cum parthonopes
Fulmine percussus decimo Cappaneus superatur
Vndecimo sese perimunt per vulnera fratres
Argiua flentem narrat duodenus & ignem
¶ Of archimoris burynge and þe pleyes
And how amphiorax fil thorwgh þe grounde
How tideus was slayn lord of argeyes
And how ypomedon in litel stounde
was dreynt / and ded parthonopo of wounde
Also how cappaneus the proude
With thonder dynt was slayn þat cried loude
¶ She kan ek telle hym how þat either brother
Ethiocles and Polymyte also
At a scarmyche ech of hem slough other
And of argyues wepynge and hire wo
And how the town was brente she told ek tho
And so descendeth doun from gestes olde
To diomede / and þus she spak and tolde
¶ This ilke boor bitokneth diomede
Tideus sone / that doun descended is
Fro meleagre þat made þe boor to blede
And thy lady wher-so she be y-wis
This dyomede hire herte hath and she is
wepe if thow wolt or lefe for out of doute
This Diomede is Inne and thow ert oute
¶ thow saist nat soth quod he thow sorceresse
with al thi fals goost of prophecie
Thow wenest ben a grete deuineresshe
Now sestow nat þis fool of fantasie
Peyneth hire on ladys for to lye
Awey quod he ther Ioues ȝeue the sorwe
Thow shalt be fals paraunter ȝet to morwe
¶ As wel thow myghtest lyen on alceste
Þat was of creatures ben men lye
That euer wern kyndest and þe beste
For when hire housbonde was in Iupartye
To dye hym self / but if she wold dye
So ches for hym to dye and gon to helle
And starf anon / as vs þe bokes telle
¶ Cassandre goth and he wit cruel herte
Forȝat his wo / for angre of hire speche
And from his bed al sodeynly he sterte
As though al hool hym hadd ymade leche
And day by day he gan enquere and seche
A soth of this with al his ful cure
And thus he drieth forth his auenture
¶ Fortune which that permutacioun
Of thynges hath as it is here committed
Thorwgh purueiaunce and disposicioun
Of heigh Ioue as regne shal ben fletted
Fro folk in folk / or when they shal ben smitted
Gan pul awey þe fetheres bright of troie
Fro day to day til they ben bare of Ioie
¶ Amange al this þe fyne of the Parodye .i. duracion
Of Ector / gan a prophecie wonder blyue
The fate wold his soule shold vnbodye
And shapen hadde a mene it out to dryue
Aȝeins which fate hym helpeth not to stryue
But on a day to fighten gan he wende
At which allas he caughte his lyues ende
¶ For which me thenketh euery manere witht
Þat haunteth armes ought to bewayle
Þe deth of hym þat was so noble a knyght
For as he drough a kynge by thauantaile
vnder of this achilles thorwgh þe maylle
And thorwgh þe body gan hym for to ryue
And þus the worthy knyght was brought of lyue
¶ For when as old bokes tellen vs
was made swiche wo þat tonge it may not telle
And namely the sorwe of Troilus
Þat next hym was of worthinesse welle
And in þis wo gan Troilus to dwelle
Þat what for sorwe and loue and for vnreste
Ful oft a day he bad his herte breste
¶ But natheles though he gan hym despaire
And drede ay þat his lady was vntrewe
Ȝet ay on hire his herte gan repaire
And as þis louers don he sought ay newe
To gete aȝein Criseyde bright of hewe
And in his herte he wente hire excusynge
Þat Calkas caused alle hire taryinge
¶ And oft tyme he was in purpos grete
Hym seluen like a pilgrym to degyse
To sen hire / but he may not conterfete
To ben vnknowen [Ist n alterd from o] of folk þat weren wyse
Ne fynde excuse aright þat may suffise
If he o-mange the grekes knowen weere
For whiche he wepte ful oft and many a teere
¶ To hire he wroot ȝet oft tyme al newe
Ful pitously he left it nought for slouthe
Besechynge hire syn þat he was trewe
Þat she wol come aȝein and hold hir trouthe
For which Criseyde vp-on day for routhe
I take it so touchynge al þis matere
wroot hym aȝein and seyde as ȝe may here
¶ Cupides sone ensaumple of goodlyhede Litera Criseydis [later]
O swerde of knyghod sours of gentilesse
How myght a wight in tormente and in drede
and heleles thow sende as ȝet gladnesse
I herteles I sik I in destresse
Syn ȝe with me nor I with ȝow may dele
Ȝow neither sende iche herte may nor hele
¶ Ȝour letres ful þe papir al ypleynted
Conceyued hath myn hertes pite
I haue ek seyn [with] teeris alle depeynted
Ȝoure letre / and how þat ȝe requeren me
To come aȝein / which ȝet ne may not be
But whi liste þat þis letre founden were
No mencion ne make I nowe for fere

LG.HEAD: (230) (Criseyde's Letter continued)
LG.L: ¶ Greuous to me god woot is ȝoure vnreste
Ȝoure haste / and þat þe goddes ordinaunce
It semeth nat ȝe take it for the beste
Nor other thyng nys in ȝoure remembraunce
As thenketh me but oonly ȝoure plesaunce
But beth not wroth and þat I ȝow beseche
For þat I tarye is al for wikked speche
¶ For I haue herde weI more than I wende
Touchynge vs two how thynges han ystonde
whiche I shal with dissimulynge amende
And beth not wroth I haue ek vnderstonde
How ȝe ne don but holden me in honde
But now no fors I kan not in ȝow gesse
But al trowthe and al gentilesse
¶ Com I wole / but ȝet in swich disioynte
I stonde as now þat what ȝere or what day
Þat þis shal be þat kan I nought a-poynte
But in effect I preye ȝow as I may
Of ȝour good word and of ȝoure frendschip ay
For trewly while þat my lif may dure
as for a frend ȝe may in me assure
¶ Ȝet preye ioh ȝow an euyl ȝe it take
Þat it is short which þat I to ȝow write
I dar not ther I am wele letres make
Ne neuere ȝet ne koude I wel endite
Ek grete effect men write in place lite
The entente is alle and not letres space
And farth now wel god haue you in his grace
¶ This Troilus þis letre thought al straunge
When he it saugh and sorwfullyche he sigchte
Hym thought it like a kalendas of chaunge
But finaly he ful ne trowen myghte
Þat she ne wold hym holden þat she hyghte
For with ful yuel wil list hym to leue
Þat louet wel in swich cas though hym greue
¶ But natheles men seyn þat at þe laste
For any thyng men shal the soth see
And swich a cas bited and þat as faste
That Troilus wel vnderstood þat she
Nas not so kynde as þat hire oughte be
And finaly he woot now out of doute
Þat al is lost þat he hath ben a-boute
¶ Stood on a day in his malencolye
Þis Troilus / and in suspicioun
Of hire / for whom he wende for to dye
And so bifel þat thorwgh-out Troie town
as was þe gyse I-born was vp and down
A manere cote armur as seith þe storie
Biforn deiphebe in signe of his victorie
¶ Þe which cote as telleth lollius
Deiphebe it hadde rent fro diomede
Þe same day / and when þis Troilus
It saugh he gan to taken of it hede
Auysinge of þe lenghte and of þe brede
And al þe werke but as he gan bihold
Ful sodeynli his herte gan to colde
¶ As he þat on þe coler fonde with-Inne
A broche þat he Criseyde ȝaf þat morwe
Þat she from Troie most nedes twynne
In remembraunce of hym and of his sorwe
And she hym layde aȝein hire feith to borwe
To kepe it ay / but now ful wel he wiste
His lady nas no langer on to truste
¶ He goth hym hom and gan ful soone sende
For Pandarus and al þis new chaunce
And of þis broche he told hym word and ende
Compleynynge of hire herte variaunce
His longe loue his trouth and his pennaunce
And efter deth with-outen wordes moore
Ful fast he cried his rest hym to restoore
¶ Þan spak he thus o lady myn Criseide
wher is ȝoure feith and wher is ȝoure biheste
Wher is ȝour loue where is ȝoure trouth he seyde
Of diomede haue now al þis feeste
Allas I wold han trowed at þe leeste
Þat syn ȝe nold in trouthe to me stonde
Þat ȝe thus nold han holden me in honde
¶ who shal now trow on any othes mo
Allas I neuere wold han wende or this
Þat ȝe Criseide koude han chaunged so
Ne but I hadde a-gilt and don amys
So cruel wende I nought ȝoure herte I-wys
To sle me þus / allas ȝoure name of trouthe
Is now for-don / and þat is al my routhe
¶ was ther non other broch ȝow list lete
To feffe with ȝoure newe loue quod he
But þilk broch þat I with teris wete
Ȝow ȝaf / as for a remembraunce of me
Non other cause allas ne hadde ȝe
But for despit / and ek for that ȝe mente
Al outerly to shewen ȝoure entente
¶ Thorwgh which I se that clene out of ȝoure mynde
Ȝe han me caste / and I ne kan nor may
For al þis world with-Inne myn herte fynde
To vnlouen ȝow a quarter of a day
In corsed tyme I borne was walawey
Þat ȝow þat dothe me al þis wo endure
Ȝet loue I best of any creature
¶ Now god quod he me sende ȝet þe grace
Þat I may meten with this Diomede
And trewly if I haue myghte and space
Ȝet shal I make I hope his sides blede
O god quod he þat oughtest taken hede
To ferthren trouthe and wronges to punice
whi nyl to don a vengeaunce of þis vice
¶ O Pandarus þat in dremes for to truste
Me blamed hast and wonte oft ert vpbreyde
Now maistow sen þi self if þat the liste
How trew is now thi nece bright Criseide
In sondry formes god it woot he seyde
Þe goddes shewen both ioye and teene
In slepe and by dreme it is now seene
¶ And certeinly with-outen more speche
From hennes forth as fer-forth as I may
Myn owen deth in armes wol I seche
I recch nat how sone be þe day
But trewly Criseyde swete may
whom I haue ay with al my myght serued
Þat ȝe þus don I haue it not deserued
¶ This Pandarus þat al þise thynges herde
And wist wel he seyde a soth of þis
He nought a word aȝein to hym answarde
For sory of his frendes sorwe he is
And shamed for his nece hath don amys
And stont astoned of thise causes twye
As stille as stone a word ne koude not seye
¶ But at þe laste þus he spak and seyde
My brother deere I may do the namore
what shold I seyn I hate I-wis Criseyde
And god woot I wol hat hire euere more
And þat thow me bisoughtest don of yore
Hauyngnge vn-to myn honour ne my reste
Right no rewarde I dide al þat the leste
¶ If I dide ought þat myght lyken the
It is me liefe and of this treson now
God woot þat it a sorwe is vnto me
And dredeles for hertes ese of ȝow
Right faine I wolde amende it wiste I how
And fro þis worlde almyghty I preye
Deliuer hire soone I kan na mor seye
¶ Grete was þe sorwe and pleynte of Troilus
But forth hire cours fortune ay gan to holde
Criseyde loueth þe sone of tydeus
And Troilus mot wepe in cares colde
Swich is þis world who-so it kan biholde
In ech estat is litel hertes reste
God lene vs for to take it for the beste
¶ In many cruel bataille out of drede
Of Troilus this ilke noble knyghte
As men in this olde bokes rede
Was seen his knyghthod and his grete myghte
And dredeles his ire day and nyghte
Ful cruely þe grekes ay aboughte
But alwey moost þis diomede he soughte
¶ And oft tyme I fynde þat they mette
with blody strokes and with wordes grete
Assayinge how hire speres weren whette
And god it woot with many a cruel hete
Gan Troilus vp on his helm bete
But natheles fortune it nought ne wold
Of otheres honde þat either dyen sholde
¶ And if I hadde taken for to write
Þe armes of this ilke worthi man
Þan wold Ich of his batailles endite
But for þat I to writen first bygan
Of his loue I haue seyde as I kan
His worthy dedes who lest hem here
Red dares he kan telle hem al Ifeere
¶ Besechynge euery lady bright of hewe
And euery gentil womman what she be
Þat al be þat Criseyde was vntrewe
Þat for þat gilt she be not wroth with me
Ȝe many hire gilt in otheres bokes se
And gladlier I wol write If ȝow leste
Penelopes trouthe and good alceste
¶ Ny sey nat this al only for thise men
But moost for wommen þat betraised be
Thorwgh fals folk god ȝeue hem sorwe ameN
Þat with hire grete wit and subtilite
Betraise ȝow / and þis commeueth me
To spek in affect ȝow al I preye
Be war of men and herknet what I seye
¶ Go litel bok go litel myn tregedie
ther god thy maker ȝet er þat he dye
So sende myght to make in som comedye
But litel book no makynge thow nenvye
But subgit be to alle poesie
And kysse þe steppes whar as thow seest space
Virgile / Ouyde / Omer Lucan and stace
¶ And for ther is so grete dyuersite
In Englissh and in writynge of our tonge
So preye I to god þat non myswrite the
Ne the mysmetere for tefaute of tonge
And red wher-so thow be or elles songe
Þat thow be vnderstonde god I beseche
But ȝet to purpos of my rather speche
¶ The wrath as I bigan ȝow for to seye
Of Troilus / the grekes boughten deere
For thousandes his hondes maden dye
As he þat was with-outen any peere
Saue Ector in his tyme as I kan here
But walawey saue only goddes wille
Dispitously hym slough the fiers achille
¶ And when þat he was slayn in þis manere
His light gost ful blisfully is wente
Vp to holughnesse of the seuenthe spere
In conuers letynge euerych elemente
and ther he saugh with ful avysemente
The erratyk sterres herkenynge armonye
With sownes ful of heuenyssh melodie
¶ And down from thennes faste he gan auyse
This litel spot of erth þat with þe se
Enbraced is and fully gan despice
This wreched world and helde al vanyte
To respect / of þe pleyne felicite
Þat is in heuene aboue / and at þe laste
ther he slayn his lokynge down he caste
¶ And in hym self he lough right at þe wo
Of hem þat wepten for his deth so faste
And dampned al our werk þat folweth so
The blynde luste þe which þat may not laste
And sholden al oure herte on heuene caste
And forth he wente shortly for to telle
Þer as mercurie sorted hym to dwelle
¶ Swich fin hath lo this Troilus for loue
Swich fyn hath al his grete worthynesse
Swich fyn hath his estat real aboue
Swich fyn his luste swich fyn hath his noblesse
Swich fyn hath fals worldes brotelnesse
And thus bigan his louynge of Criseyde
As I haue tolde and in this wise he deyed
¶ O ȝonge fresshe folkes he or she
In which þat loue vp groweth with ȝoure age
Repeireth hom fro wordly vanyte
And of ȝoure herte vp casteth þe visage
To thilke god þat efter his ymage
Ȝow made / and thynketh al nys but a faire
Þis worlde þat passeth soon as flours faire
¶ And loueth hym þe which right for loue
Vp on a crois oure soules for to beye
First starffe and roos and sitt in heuen above
For he nyl falsen no wight dar I seye
Þat wol his herte alle holly on hym leye
And syn he best to loue is and most meke
what nedeth feyned loues for to seke
¶ Lo here of payens corsed old rites
Lo here what alle hire goddes may auaille
Lo here þis wreched worldes appetites
Lo here þe fyre and guerdon for trauaille
Of Ioue appollo of mars of swich rescaille
Lo here þe forme of olde clerkes speche
In poetrie if ȝe hire bokes seche
¶ O moral Gower this boke I directe
To the / and þe philosophical strode
To vouchen sauf ther nede is to correcte
Of ȝoure benignites and ȝeles good
And to þat sothfast criste þat sterf on roode
With al myn herte of mercy euere I preye
And to þe lord right þus speke and seye
¶ Thow oon and two and thre eterne on lyue
That regnest ay in iij. and ij. and oon
Vncircumscript and al maist circumscriue
Vs from visible and invisible foon
Defende / and to thi mercy euerichon
So mak vs iesus [MS. iħc] for thy mercy digne
For loue of maide and moder thyn benigne

HEADNOTE.P: [Camb. Univ. Libr. MS. Gg. 4. 27, leaf 103: leaf 102 has been cut out of the MS.]

LG.L: ¶ ffor yre he quok so gan his herte gnawe
Whan diomede on horse gan hyr [r, corrected] dresse
And seyde to hym self þis ilke sawe
Allas quod he þus foul a wrechedenes
Whi suffere I it whi nyl I it [I it, corrector] redresse
Were it not bet at onys for to deye
Þan eueremore þus langurynge to drye
// Whi nyl I make at onys ryche or pore
To haue I-now to don or þan sche go
Whi nyl I brynge al Troye vp on a rore
Whi nyl I sle þis diomede also
Whi nyl I raþere with a man or to
Stele hire a-way whi wil I [wil I, corrector] þis endure
Whi nyl I helpyn to myn owene cure
¶ But whi he nolde do so fel a dede
Þat schal I say & whi hym liste it spare
He hadde in herte alwoy a maner drede
Lest Crisseide in rumur of þis fare
Scholde a be slayn lo þis was al his care
And eɫɫ serteyn as I seyde to-fore [eɫɫ = ellis]
He hadde it do with-oute wordis more
// Criseyde whan þat sche was redi for to ryde
fful sorwefully sche syhede & seyde allas
But forth [rth, corrector] sche muste for ouȝt þat may be-tyde
And forthe sche rauȝt ful sorwefully apas
And ofte sche syhede & seyde allas
What wondyr ist þow þat hire sore smert
Whan sche for-goþ hire owene dere hert
¶ Þis Troylus in wise of curteysye
With hauk & hound & with an heuge route
Of knyȝtis rede & dede hire cumpany
Passynge al þe valey fer with-oute
And ferþere wolde han redyn with-outyn doute
fful fayn & wo was hym to gon so sone
But turne he muste & ek it was to done
¶ And ryȝt with þat was antenore I-come
Ouȝt of grekis ost & euery wiȝt
Was of it glad & seyde he was wolcome
And Troilus al nere his herte lyȝt
He peynyde hym with al his fulle myȝt
Hym to withholde of wepynge at þe leste
And antenore kyste & made feste.
// And here with al he muste his leue take
And caste his eyȝyn vp on hym pitousely
And ner he rod his cause for to make
And tok hire by þe hond al soberely
And lord so he gan wepyn tenderely
And he ful softe & slyly gan hire sey
Now help þis day & do me not to dey.
¶ With þat his coursir turnede hym aboute
With face pale & on-to diome[de]
No word he spak ne non of al his rout
Of which þe sone [o, corrected] of Tideus tok hede
As he þat coude more þan þe crede
IN swich a craft & bi þe [r, first v] reyne he hent
And Troilus to Troyeward hom he went.
// Þis diomede þat lad hire bi þe bridil
Whan þat he say þe folk of troye awoye
Þouȝte al myn trauayl schal not ben ydil
Ȝif þat I may for sumwhat schal I seye
ffor at þe werste it may ȝit schorte myn woye
I haue herd seyd ek be tymys twiis & twelue
He is a fol þat wele for-ȝete hym selue.
¶ But na-þeles þus þouȝte he wel I-now
Þat certeynly I am a-boute nouȝt
Ȝif þat I speke of loue & make it tow
ffor douteles ȝif sche haue in hire þouȝt
Hym þat I gesse he may not ben I-bouȝt
So a-way but I schal fynde a mene
Þat sche not wete schal / as ȝit what I mene.
¶ Þis diomede as he þat coude his good
Whan tyme was gan falle forth in speeche
Of þis & þat & axede why sche stode
In swich de-sese & gan hire ek be-seche
Ȝif þat by encres myȝte or eche
With ony þyng hire ese þat sche schulde
Comaundyn it hym & he don it wolde
¶ ffor treweliche he swor hire as a knyȝt
Þat þere was þyng with which he myȝte hire plese
Þat he nyl don his herte & al his myȝt
To don it for to don his herte an ese
And preyede sche wolde hire sorwe pese
And seyde I-wis we grekys can haue ioye
To honoure ȝow as wel as folk in troye
¶ He seyde ek þus I wot ȝow þynkiþ straunge
No wondyr is for it is to ȝow newe
Þe aqueyntau[n]se of þis Troylus for to chaunge
ffor folk of grece þo ȝe neuere knewe
But wolde neuere god but as [s, corrector] trewe
A grek ȝe schulde a-mongis vs alle fynde
As ony troyan is & ek as kynde.
¶ And bi þe cause I swor ȝow ryȝt lo now
To ben ȝoure frend & helpyn to myn myȝt
And for þe more aqueyntauns ek of ȝow
Haue I had / þanne anoþer straungere wyȝt
So from þis forth I prey ȝow day & nyȝt
Comaundith it me so sore so me smert
To don al þat may like to ȝoure hert.
¶ And þat ȝe woldyn me as ȝoure broþer trete
And takyth not myn frenschepe in dispyȝt
And þow ȝoure sorwe be for þyngis grete
Not I not whi but out of more respyt
Myn herte haþ to amendyn it gret delyȝt
And ȝif I may ȝoure harmys not redresse
I am ryȝt sory for ȝoure heuynesse.
¶ ffor þow þe troyanys with þe grekis wroþe
Han manyaday ben alwey ȝit parde
On good loue in soþ we were beþe
And for þe loue of god myn lady fre
Whom so ȝe hate as beþ not wroþ with me
ffor trewely þere can no wyȝt ȝow serue
Þat half so soþ ȝoure wrethe wolde deserue.
¶ And nere it þat we ben so ner þe tent
Of calcas which þat sen vs boþe may
I wolde of þis telle ȝow of al myn entent
But be þis enselyd / tyl a noþer day
Ȝif me ȝoure honde / I am & schal ben ay
God helpe me so whil þat myn lyf may dure
Ȝoure owyn a-bouyn euery criature.
¶ Þus seyde I neuere er now to woman born
ffor god myn herte as wisely glade so
I louede neuere woman here be-forn
As paramour ne neuere schal no mo
And for þe loue of god beþ not myn fo
Al can I not to ȝow myn lady dere
Compleyne aryȝt for I am ȝit to lere.
¶ And wonderith nouȝt myn owene lady bryȝt
Þow I speke to ȝow of loue þus blyue
ffor I haue herd or þis of manye a wyȝt
He louede þyng he saw neuere in his lyue
ffor I am not of power for to stryue
Aȝens þe god of loue but hym obeye
I wele alwey & mercy I ȝow preye.
¶ Þere ben so worþy knyȝtis in þis place
And ȝe so fayr þat eueryche of hem alle
Wele peynyn hem to stondyn in ȝoure grace
But myȝte me so fayr a grace falle
Þat ȝe me for ȝoure seruaunt wolde calle
So louely ne so trewely ȝow serue
Nil non of hem as I schal til I sterue.
¶ Crisseyde vn-to þat purpos litil answerde
As sche þat was with sorwe opressed so
Þat sche in effectis sche not his talys herde
But here & þere now here a word or to
Hire þouȝte hire sorweful herte brast oto
Whan sche gan hire fadyr fer asspye
Wel ny doun of hire hors sche gan to sye.
¶ But naþeles sche þankede dyomede
Of al his trauayle & his goode chere
And þat him lust his frenschepe here to bede
And sche acceptid it in good manere
[. . . . . . . no gap in the MS.]
And trostyn hym sche wolde & wel sche myȝt
Asyde & from hire hors sche a-lyȝt.
¶ Hire fadir haþ hire in his armys nome
And xxti time he kyste his douȝtir swete
And seyde o dere douȝter myn wolcome
Sche seyde ek sche was fayn with hym to mete
[A blank line in the MS.]
But here I lete hire with hire fadyr dwelle
And forth I wele of troylus ȝow telle
TO Troye is comyn þis woful troylus
In sorwe a-boue alle sorwis smert
With feloun lok & fase dispetous
Is sodeynly from his hors [I, corrected] I-stert
And þour his paleys with a sorweful hert
To chambere he wente of non [of non m, corrected] man tok he hede
Ne non to hym dar speke a word for drede
¶ And þere his sorwis þat he sparyd hadde
He ȝaf an isseu large & loude he cryede
And in his þrowys frentyk he made
He cursede Ioue appollo & cupide
He cursede seres Bacus & Cypride
His burħ hymself his stat & ek nature
And saue his lady euery creature.
¶ To bede he goþ & walwith þere & turnyth
In furie as 3 thow he leye in helle 3 [3-3 by corrector]
And þis wise he ny til day soiornyth
But þo be-gan a lityl his herte vnswelle
Þour teris wich þat gan vp te welle
And pitousli he cryede vp-on crisseyde
And to hym self þus he spak & seyde
¶ Where is myn owene lady leue & dere
Where is hire white brest where is it where
Where ben hire armys & hire eyen clere
Þat ȝistyr nyȝt þis tyme with me were
Now may I wepe alone manye a tere
And graspe a-boute I may but in þis place
Saue a pilwe fynde not to embrase
¶ How schal I don whanne schal sche comyn a-ȝen
I not allas whi let I hire to gon
As wolde god I hadde as þo ben slayn
O herte myn Criseide o swete fo
O lady myn þo I loue & no mo
To whom for eueremor myn herte is holde
And þus he pleynyd & ferþere more he tolde
¶ Who sey ȝow now myn ryȝte lodis sterre
Who sit ryȝt now or stont in ȝoure presense
Who can conforte now ȝoure hertis werre
Whan I am gon ho ȝeuyth ȝow audience
Who spekith for me ryȝt now in myn absense
Allas no wiȝt & þat is al myn care
ffor wel I wot as iuele as I ȝe fare
¶ How schal I þus ful ten dayis endure
Whan I þe ferste nyȝt haue al ȝis tene
How schal sche do ek sorweful cryature
ffor tendirnesse how schal sche ek susteyne
Whiche for me o pitous pale & grene
Schal ben ȝour frosche womanliche fase
ffor longyng or ȝe turne vn-to þis plase
¶ And whan he fel in ony slomberyng
A-non begynne 1 he schulde for to grone 1 [1-1 by corrector]
And dremyn of þe dredfuleste þynge
Þat myȝte ben þat mette he þere a-lone
In plase oribele makynge haþ his mone
Or metyn þat he was a-mongis alle
Hise enemyis & in here hondis falle.
// And þerwithal his body schulde sterte
And with þe stert al sodeynly a-wake
And swich a tremour fel a-boute his herte
Þat of þe fer þe body schulde quake
2 And for that fer anon he dede a-wake 2 [2-2 by a corrector]
And semyn þanne as he schulde falle depe
ffrom hye on loft & þanne wolde he wepe.
¶ And rewyn on hym self so pitousli
Þat wondir was to hire his fantasye
A noþer tyme he schulde myȝtily
Conforte him self & sey it were folye
So causeles swich drede for to drye
And eft be-gan his asper sorwe newe
Þat euery man myȝt on his sorwe rewe
// Ho so wil telle / aryȝt or ful discrye
His wo his pleynt his langure & his pyne
Not alle þe men þat han or ben on lyue
Þu redere wel þou mayȝ þyn self deuyne
Þat swich a wo myn wit can not defyne
In ydil for to write [ȝ. corrector] ȝit schulde I swynke
Whan þat myn wit is wery it to þynke
¶ On heuene ȝit þe sterris were sene
Al-þow ful pale wexen gan þe mone
And whityn gan eche oryȝonte schene
Al est-ward as it was wone to done
And phebus with his rosy carte sone
Gan aftyr to dresse hym vp to fare
Whan Troilus haþ sent aftyr pandare
¶ Þis Pandare þat of al þe day be-forn
Ne myȝte a come Troilus for to se
Al-þow he on his heuyd it hadde sworyn
ffor with þe kyng Priame alday was he
So þat it lay not in his liberte
Nowher to gon but on þe morwe he went
To Troylus whan þat he for hym sent
// ffor in his herte he coude wel deuyne
Þat Troilus alnyȝt for sorwe wok
And þat he wolde tellyn hym of his pyne
Þis knew he wel I-now with-oute bok
ffor which þe woye streyt to his chambir tok
And Troilus sobereliche grette
And on þe bed ful sone he gan hym sette
¶ Myn pandarus quod Troilus þe sorwe
Which þat I drie may not longe endure
I trowe I schal not leuyn tyl to morwe
ffor which I wolde alwoy on auenture
To deuyse of myn sepulture
Þe forme & of myn moble þou dispone
Ryȝ as þe semyst best is for to done
// But of þe fyr & flambe feuneral
In wich myn body brenne schal to glede
And of þe feste & pleyes palestral
At myn vigile I preye ȝow takyth hede
Þat it be wel & offere mars myn stede
Myn swerd myn helm & leue broþer dere
Myn child to paɫɫ ȝif þat schynyth clere
¶ Þe poudir wich myn herte brent schal turne
Þat preye I þe þou take & ek conserue
In a vessel þat men callyn vrne
Of gold & to myn lady þat I serue
ffor loue of whom þus pitously I sterue.
So ȝeue it hire & do hire þis plesaunce
To prey hire kepe it for a remembraunce
¶ ffor wel I fele be myn malady
An myne dremys now & ȝore agon
Þat serteynly I mot nedis deye
Þe owle ek wich þat hiȝte eschaphilo
Haþ aftyr me schriht alle þese nyȝtis too [too, corrected]
And god mercurye on me now woful wreche
Þe soule gyde & whan ȝe luste it feche.
PAndarus answerde & seyde troilus
Myn dere frend as I haue told þe ȝore
Þat it is foly for to sorwe þus
And causeles for which I can no more
But who so wele not trowe red ne lore
I can in hym sen no remedy
But let hym wercħyn with his fantasy
¶ But Troylus I preye þe telle me now
Ȝif þat þow or I or ony wyȝt
Haþ louyd paramour as wel as ȝow
Ȝa god wot * so haþ many a worþi knyȝt
Haþ his lady forgon a fortenyȝt
And he not ȝit made haluyndel þe fare
What nediþ it þe / to make al þis [c, corrected] care.
¶ Syn day be day / þow mayȝt þyn seluyn se
Þat from his loue / or eɫɫ from his wif
A man mot twynnyn / of necescite
Ȝa þow he loue hire / as as his owene lyf
Ȝit nyl he with hym self / make þis stryf
ffor wel þow wist / myn owene lady dere
Þat alwey frendis / may not ben in fere
¶ How don þese folk / þat sen here louys weddit
Be fryndis myȝt / & as it be-tydyth ofte
And sen hem in here . spousis bed . ben beddit
God wot þey takyn it wisely & softe
ffor whi good hope / holt vp here herte on lofte
And for þey can a tyme / of sorwe endure
As tyme hem hirt / a tyme doþ hem cure
¶ So schuldist þow endure & let slyde
Þe tyme & fonde to ben glad & lyȝt
Ten dayis is not so longe to on-byde
And sithe sche to come haþ be-hyȝt
Sche nyl hire heste brekyn for no wyȝt
ffor dred þe not þat sche ne wil fynde way
To comyn a-ȝen myn lyf þanne durste I lay.
// Þynne swenys ek & al þyn fantasye
Dryf owt & lat hem faryn to myschaunce
ffor þey procedyn of þyn malencoly
Þat doþ þe fele in slep al þis penaunce
A straw for alle sweuenys signefyaunce
God help me so I counte hem not a bene
Þere wot no man a-ryȝt 1 what 1 [1-1 corrected] dremys mene
¶ ffor pristis of þe tempele tellyn þis
Þat dremys ben þe reuelaciouns
Of goddis & as wel þey tellyn Iwis
Þat þey ben enfernal illusionys
And lechis seyn þat of complexiounnys
Procedyn þey or fast or glotenye
Who wot in soþ þus / what þey signefye.
// Ek oþere seyn þour enpressiounnys
As ȝif a 2 whiȝt 2 [2-2 corrected] haþ fast a þyng in mynde
Þat þere comyth sweche auisiounys
And oþere seyn þat þey in bokys fynde
Þat aftyr tymys of ȝer be kynde
Men dremyn & þat effectis gon bi þe mone
But leue no drem for it is not to done.
¶ Who [o, corrected] worþi of dremys / alle þese olde wyuys
And trewelyche augery of þese olde foulis
ffor fere of whiche men wene [wene, corrected] lese here lyuys
And rauenys qualme & strichinge of þese oules
To trowe on it / boþe fals & foul is
Allas 5 allas so noble a creature 5 [5-5 corrected]
As is a man schal dredyn swich ordure
¶ ffor which with [with, overline, later] al myn herte I þe be-seche
On-to þyn self þat al þis þow for-ȝif
And rys now vp with-oute more speche
And lat vs cast how we may best forþ dryf
Þis tyme & how froschely we may lyf
Til þat sche come & þat may ben ryȝt sone
God help me so / best is þus to done
¶ Rys lat vs speke / of lusty lyf in troye
Þat we han led / & forth þe tyme dreue
And ek of tyme comynge / vs þe ioye
Þat bryngyn schal oure blysse now so blyue
And langur of þese / twyis dais fyue
We schal þerwith forȝetyn oure opresse
Þat wel oneþe it schal don vs duresse.
¶ Þis toun is ful of lordis al aboute
And treus lestith al þis mene while
Go we pley vs in sum lusty route
To Sarpedoun not henys but a myle
And þus þou schalt þe tyme wel be-gyle
And dryue it forth on to þat blysful morwe
Þat þow hire se þat cause is of 2 thyn 2 [2-2 corrected] sorwe
¶ Now rys vp myn dere broþer Troylus

Ne coude I neuere se ȝow but in sorwe
¶ Can I not sen what may þe cause ben
But ȝif for loue of som Troyan it were
Þe whiche ryȝt sore wolde aþynkyn me
Þat ȝe for ony wiȝt þat dwellyn þere
Scholde spille a quarter of a tere
[No gap in the MS.]
ffor dredeles it nys not worth þe while
ffor folk of troye as wis sithe alle an som
In presoun ben as ȝe ȝoure seluyn se
Nor þens schal not on on lyue comyn
ffor al þe good be-twixe sünne & se
Trostiþ wel & vndirstondiþ me
Þere schal not on for mercy gon on lyue
Al were he lord of worldis twyis fyue.
¶ Swich fechyng 1 hom of Eleyne 1 [1-1 corrected]
Þere schal be take er þan we henys wynde
Þat mannes which þat goddis ben of peyne
Schal ben a-gast þat grekys wil hem sende
And men schul drede vnto þe worldis ende
ffrom henys forþ to rauych ony quene
So crewel schal oure wreche on hem ben sene.
// And but ȝif Calcas lede vs with a[m]bages
Þat is to seyne with doubele wordis slye
Which as men clepe a word with twey vesagis
Ȝe schal wel knowe þat I not lye
And al þis þyng ryȝt sen it with ȝoure eye
And þat a-non ȝe nyl not trowe how sone
Now takyth hed for it nys not to done
¶ What wene ȝe þat ȝoure fadir wolde
Haue ȝouyn antenore for ȝow a-non
Ȝif he ne woste þat þe cete schulde
Distroyed ben whi nay so mote I gon
He knew ful wel þere scal not schappyn on
Þat Troyan is & for þe grete fere
He durste ȝow lete / no lengere dwelle þere
¶ What wele ȝe more louesum ladi dere
Lat troye & troyan oute of ȝoure herte pase
Drif out þat bittir hope & make good chere
And clepe a-ȝen þe beute of ȝoure face
Þat ȝe with salte teris so deface 2 yow heere 2 [2-2 by corrector]
ffor Troye is brouȝt in swich a iupardi
Þat is to seyne is now no remedy
// And þynkiþ wel ȝe schal in grekys fynde
A more parfyȝt loue or be myȝt
Þan ony troyan is & more kynde
And bet to seruyn ȝow wele don his myȝt
I wele ben he to seruyn ȝow myn selleue [line 922 is want∣ing in the MS.]
Ȝa leuere þan ben kyng of grecis. vij.
[A blank line in the MS.]
¶ And with þat word he gan to wexen red
And in his speche a lityl he quok
And caste a-syde a lite with his hed
And stynte a while & aftyrward a-wok
And sobirly on hire dede þrowe his lok
And seyde I am al be it to ȝow no ioye
As gentil man as ony wyt in troye
// ffor ȝif myn fadyr Thedeus he seyde
I-leuid hadde I hadde ben er þis
Of al calidrion & arge a kyng Crisseide
And so I hope & þat I schal I-wis
But he was slain allas more harm is
Vnhappi at Thedes al to rathe
Polymyȝt & many man al to skaþe
¶ But herte myn syn I am ȝoure man
And ben þe fyrste of whom I seche grace
And serue ȝow as hertely as I can
And euere schal whil myn lyf haue spase
So er þat I departe out of þis place
Þat ȝe me grauntyþ þat I may to morwe
At bettere leyser telle ȝow al myn sorwe
¶ What schulde I telle þe wordis & þe sorwe
He spak I-now for on day at þe meste
It preuyth he spak so þat Crisseyde
Grauntyd on þe morwe at his requeste
ffor to speke with hym at þe leste
So þat he nolde speke of swich matere
And þus sche seyde to hym as ȝe schul here
AS sche þat hire herte on troilus
So faste hadde set þat þere myȝt non arase
And straungely sche spak & seyde þus
O Diomede I loue þat ilke place
Þere I was born & ioue for his grace
Deliuere it sone of alle þat don it care
God for þyn myȝt so leue it wel to fare
¶ Þat grekis wolde hire wrethe [r, later] on troye wreke
Ȝif þat þey myȝte I knowe it wel I-wis
But I[t] schal not be-fallyn þat ȝe speke
And god to-forn & ferþere ouer þis
I wot myn fadir wis & redi is
And he me haþ bouȝt as ȝe me tolde
So dere I am þe more to hym holde
¶ Grekis ben of [of, overline, later] hey condicioun
I wot ek wel but sertein men schal fynde
As worþi folk with-inne troye toun
As cunnyng as þarfit & as kynde
As ben be tweþe orchades & ynde
And þat ȝe couþe wel ȝoure ladi serue
I trowe it wel hire þank for to deserue
¶ But as ȝe speke of loue I-wis sche seyde
I hadde a lord to whom I weddid was
Whos myn herte was tyl þat he deyede
And oþer loue as helpe me now Pallas
Þere in myn herte nys ne neuere nas
And þat ȝe ben of nobil & hy kenrede
I haue wel herd it telle out of drede
¶ And don me han so gret a wondir
Þat ȝe wele scornyn ony woman so
Ek good loue & I / ben fer a sundir
I am disposed bet so mote I go
Vn-to myn deþ to pleynyn & make wo
What I schal aftyr don can I not say
But trewely as ȝit luste me no play
¶ Myn herte is now in tribulacioun
And ȝe in armys besi day be day
Here-aftyr whan ȝe wonyn haue þe toun
Parauenture þanne so it happyn may
Þat whanne I se / þat neuere ȝit ne say
Þanne wil I werke þat I neuere ne wrouȝte
Þis is word I-now for ȝow / suffiseþ it nouȝt
¶ To morwe wele I ek speke with ȝow fayn
So þat ȝe touche not of þis matere
And whan ȝe leste ȝe may come aȝeyn
And er ȝe gon þus meche I sey ȝow here
As helpe me pallas with hire eyyn clere
Þat ȝif I schulde of ony grek han [h, corrected] reuthe
It schulde be ȝoure sylf be myn treuthe
¶ I sey not þerfore þat I wele ȝow loue
Ne I sey not nay but in conclusioun
I mene wel bi god þat sit a-boue
And þerwithal sche cast hire eyȝyn doun
And gan to sike & seyde o troye toun
Ȝit bidde I god / in quyete & in reste
I may þe sen / or do myn herte breste
¶ But in effect & soþli for to seyen
Þis diome[de] al newely now a-ȝen
Gan 1 mersi presyn here to preye 1 [1-1 by corrector]
But aftyr þis þe soþe for to seyn
Hire gloue he tok of whiche he was ful fayn
And fynally whan it was waxen eue
And al was wel he ros & tok his leue
¶ THe bryȝte Venus folwede ay & tauȝte
Þe way / þe brode phebus doun a-lyȝte
And synthea hire char hors ouer rauȝte
To whirle out of þe lyoun ȝif sche myȝte
And signifer hire candelis schewede bryȝt
Whan þat Cresseyde vn-to hire reste went
With-inne hire faderis fayre bryȝte tent
// Returnynge in hire soule vp & doun
Þe wordis of þis sodeyn diomede
His grete estat & peril of þe toun
And þat sche was a-lone & hadde nede
Of frendis helpe & þus be-gan to brede
Þe causis wich soþ for to telle
Þat sche tok fully purpos for to dwelle
¶ Þe morwe com & gostly for to speke
Þis diomede is comyn to Crisseyde
And schortly lest þat sche myn tale breke
So wel for hymself he spak & seyde
Þat alle hire sikis sore doun he leyde
And finally þe soþe for to seyn
He reuyth hire þe grete of al hire peyn
// And aftyr þis þe story tellyth þus
Þat he hire ȝaf þe fayre baye stede
Þe whiche he onys wan of Troylus
A-ȝen a broche þat was lityl nede
Þat Troilus [o, later] was / sche ȝaf þis diomede
An þe bet of sorwe / him to releue
Sche made hym to were a pensel of hire sleue
¶ I fynde ek in storyies eɫɫ where
Þat þour þe body gert was diomede
Of Troilus / þo wep sche manye a tere
Whan þat sche saw hise wide wondis blede
And þat sche tok hym to kepe good hede
And for to hele hym / of hise sorwis smert
Men sen not þat / sche ȝaf hym hyre herte
¶ But trewely þe story tellyth þus
Þere made neuere woman more wo
Þan sche whan sche falsede troilus
Sche seyde allas for now clene a-go
I mene of treuthe / for now & euere mo
ffor I haue falsed on þe gentilleste
Þat euere was born & on þe worþyeste
¶ Allas of me vn-to þe worldis ende
Schal noþer ben wretyn noþer I-songe
No good word for bokys wele me schende
On rolled schal I ben in manye a tonge
Þour þe world no belle schal be ronge
O wemen most / wele hatyn me of alle
Allas þat swich a cas me schulde be-falle
¶ Þey wele seyn in as meche as in me is
I haue hem don dishonour & velony
Al be I not þe ferste þat dede a-mis
What helpith þat to don myn blame a-way
But syn I se þere is no betere way
And þat to late it is now for to rewe
To diomede algate I wele be trewe
¶ But Troilus sin I no betere may
And syn þat þe departyn þus & I
Ȝit preye I god so ȝeue ȝou god day
As for þe gentilleste trewely
Þat euere I say to serue feyithfully
And best can ay his honour wel kepe
And with þat word sche brast on for to wepe
¶ And sertis ȝow ne hatyn schal I neuere
And frendis loue þat I schal haue of me
And myn godde word al myȝty leuyn euere
And trewely I wolde sory be
ffor to se ȝow in aduersite
And gilteles I wot I ȝow leue
But al schal passe & þus take I myn leue
¶ But trewely longe it was be-twene
Þat sche for-sok him for þis diomede
Þere nyis non autour tellyþ it I wene
Take euery man now to hise bokys hede
He schal non terme fynde out of drede
But þow he gan to wowe hire sone
Or he hire wan ȝit was þere more to done
¶ Ne me ne leste þis sely woman chide
fferþere þan þe story wele deuyse
Hire name allas is ponschede to wyde
Þat for hire gilt it auȝte I-now suffyse
And ȝif I myȝte excuse hire ony wise
ffor sche so sory was for hire ontreuthe
I-wis I wilde excuse hire for reuthe
THis Troilus as I be-fore haue told
Þis drieeth as wel as he haþ myȝt
But ofte was his herte hot & cold
And namely þat ilke tenthe nyȝt
Which on þe morwe sche haþ hym be-hyȝt
To comyn aȝyn god wot ful litil reste
Hadde he þat nyȝt no þyng to slepe hym leste
¶ Þe laurer crounnede phebus with his hete
Gan in his cours vpward whan he went
To warmyn of þe est þe waɫɫ wete
And nysus is douȝtyr song with frosch entent
Whan Troilus aftyr his pandarus sent
And on þe wal of þe toun þey pleyede
To loke ȝif he can ougȝt sen of Crisseyde
¶ Til it was non þey stode for to se
Who þat þere come & euery maner wyȝt
Þat come from fer þey seydyn it was sche
Til þat þey coude knowyn hym a-ryȝt
Now was his herte dul now was it lyȝt
And þus beiapid stodeþey for to stare
Abouȝte nouȝt Troylus & Pandare
¶ To Pandarus þis Troilus þus seyde
ffor ouȝt I wot bi-fore non sikirly
In-to þis toun ne comyth not Crisseyde
Sche haþ I-now to done hardily
To wyndyn from hire fadir so trowe I
Hire olde fadir wele makyn hire dyne
Er þan sche go god ȝif his herte pyne
// Pandarus answerde it may wel ben serteyn
ffor-þi lat vs dyne & þe be-seche
And aftyr non þanne mayst þou comyn a-ȝen
And hom þey gon with-outyn more speche
And comyn a-geyn but longe may þey seche
Er þat þey fynde þat þey aftyr gape
ffortune hem boþe þynkyþ for to iape
¶ Quod Troilus I se wel now þat sche
Is taried with hire [first, his] olde fadyr so
Er þan sche come it wele ner euyn be
Come forþ I wele vn-to þe ȝate go
Þese porterys ben vncunnynge eueremo
And I wele don hem holdyn vp þe ȝate
as nouȝt ne were ȝif þat sche come late
// Þe day goþ faste & aftyr þat comyth euene
And ȝit come not to Troilus Crisseyde
He lokede forþ by hegis by treis be grene
And ouer þe waɫɫ his hed he leyde
And at þe laste he turnede hym & seyde
By god I wot hire menyng pandare
Al most I-wis was now al myn care
¶ Now douȝteles þis ladi can hire good
I wot sche menyth to ryde priuyly
I commende hire wisdom by myn hod
Sche nyl not make þe puple nysely
Gauryn on hire whan sche comyth but softely
Be nyȝt in-to þe toun sche þynkyth ryde
And dere broþer þynkith not longe to a-byde
¶ We haue not eɫɫ for to done I-wis
And Pandarus wilt þow trowe me
Haue here myn treuthe I se hire ȝondir sche is
Heue vp þynne eyȝyn man mayst þu not sen
Pandarus answerede nay so mote I þe
Al wrong bi god what seyst þou man where arte
Þat I se ȝondir is but a fare carte
Allas þou seyst ful soþ quod Troilus
But hardili it is al for nouȝt
Þat in myn herte I-now reioye þus
It is a-ȝen sum goode I haue a þouȝt
Not I not how but syn þat I was wrouȝt
Ne felte I swiche a confort soþ to seyne
Sche comyth to nyȝt myn lyf I durste leyne
¶ Pandarus answerde it may be wel I-now
And held with hym of al þat euere he seyde
But in his herte he þouȝte & softe low
And to hym self ful soberely he seyde
ffram hasil wode þere ioly robyn pleyede
Schal come al þat þow abydyst here
Ȝa farwel al þe snow of fernere
// Þe wardeyn of þe ȝatis gan to calle
Þe folk wich þat ouer þe ȝatis were
And bad hem driue in here bestis alle
Or al þat nyȝt muste hem bleue þere
an fer with-inne nyȝt with manye a tere
Þis Troilus gan homward for to ryde
ffar wel sey he it helpiþ not to a-bide
¶ But neuer-þe-les he gladede hym in þis
And seyde he mystondit hadde his day
And seyde vndirstonde haue I a-mys
ffor þeilke nyȝt I last Crisseide say
Sche seyde I schal be þere ȝif þat I may
Er þat mone / O dere herte swete
Þe lyoun passe out of þat aryete
¶ ffor which sche ȝit may holde al hire heste
And on þe morwyn vnto þe ȝatis he went
And vp & doun he west & ek he est
Vp on þe waɫɫ made he manye a went
But al for nouȝt his hope alwey hym blent
ffor whiche at nyȝt with sorwe & sikis sore
He wente hym hom with-outyn ony more
// His hope al clene out of his herte fledde
He ne haþ no lengere wheron for to honge
But for þe peyne hym þouȝte his herte bledde
So weryn hise þrowis scharpe & wondyr stronge
ffor whan he say þat sche a-bod so longe
He nyste what to iugen of it myȝt
Syn sche haþ brokyn þat sche hym be-hyȝt
¶ Þe þredde day þe forþe þe fifte þe sexte day
Aftyr þe dayis ten þe whiche I tolde
Be-twixe hope & dred his herte lay
Ȝit sumwhat trostynge on hire hestis olde
But whan he say sche nolde here hestis holde
He can not sen non oþer remedy
But for to schape hym sone for to dey
// Þerwiþ þe wekede sprit god vs blys
Which þat men clepyn wode Ielosye
Gan in hym crepe in as his heuynesse
ffor cause of which he wolde sone deye
He noþer et ne drank for his malencoly
And ek from euery companye he fledde
Þis was þe lyf þat al þis tyme he ledde
¶ He so disfigured was þat no maner man
Vn-neþe myȝte hym knowe wher he wente
So was he lene & þerto pale & wan
And febele þat he walkede by potent
And with his yre he þus hym seluyn schent
But who so axe hym wherof hym smert
He seyde his harm was al aboute his hert
¶ Priam ful ofte & ek his modir dere
Hise breþeren his sisteren gon hym frayn
Whi he sorweful was in al hise chere
And with þat þyng was cause of al his payn
But al for nouȝt he nolde his cause playn
But seyde he felte a greuous maledy
A-boute his herte & sone he wolde dey
// So on a day he leyde hym doun to slepe
And so be-fel þat in his slep hym þouȝte
Þat in a forest faste he walkede to wepe
ffor loue of hyre þat hym þis peyne wrouȝte
And vp & doun as he þe forest souȝte
He mette he say a bor with toschhis grete
Þat slep a-ȝen þe bryȝte sunnys hete
¶ And bi þis bor faste in hyre armys 1 ffolde 1 [1-1 corrected]
Lay kyssynge ay his ladi Crisseyde
ffor sorwe of wich whan he gan hire be-holde
And for dispit out of his slep he breyde
And loude he criede o pandaris he seyde
O pandarus now knowe I crop & rote
I am but ded þere is non oþer bote
// Myn lady bryȝt Crisseyde haþ me be-trayed
In whom I trostede most of ony wyȝt
Sche ell wher haþ now hire herte apayed
Þe blisful goddis þour here grete myȝt
Han in myn drem schewid it ful ryȝt
Þus in myn drem Crisseyde haue I beholde
And al þis þyng to pandarus he tolde
¶ O myn Crisseyde allas what suptilite
What lust what beute what sience
What wreþe of iuste cause haue ȝe to me
What gilt of me what fel experience
Haþ from me raft allas ȝoure aduertence
O trust of fayth o depe assuraunce
Ho haþ me raft crisseyde al my plesaunse
¶ Allas whi let I hire henys from me go
Wo schal wol nyh out of myn wit me brayde
Who schal now trowe on ony oþis mo
But wel I wende O lady bryȝt Crisseyde
Þat euery word was gospel þat sche seide
But who may bet begile ȝif sche luste
Þan þey on whom men wenyn best to truste
// What schal I don myn pandarus allas
I fele now so scharpe a newe peyne
Syn þat þere lyþ no remedie in þis cas
But best were it I with myne hondis tweyne
Myn self to sle þan þus alwoy to pleyne
ffor þour þe deþ myn wo schal han an ende
Þere euery day with lyf myn seluyn I schynde
¶ Pandarus answerde & seyde allas þe while
Þat I was born haue I not seyd or þis
Þat dremys manye a man be-gile
And whi for folk expoungyn hem a-mys
How durstist þow seyn þat fals þyn lady is
ffor ony drem ryȝt for þyn owene drede
Let be þis þouȝt þou canst no dremys rede
// Perauenture þere þou dremyst of þis bor
It may so be þat it may signefye
Hire fadir which þat old is & hor
A-ȝen þe sunne lyth a poynt to deye
And for sorwe sche gynnyth wepe & crye
And hym kysseþ þere he lyth on þe gronde
Þus schuldist þow þynne dremys a-ryȝt expounde
¶ How myȝte I þanne don quod Troilus
To knowe of þis ȝe were it neuere so lite
Now seyst þu wisely quod þis pandarus
Myn red is syn þou canst wel endite
Þat hastily a lettere þow here [here corrected]
Þour which þow schat wel bryngyn it aboute
To knowyn a soþ þere þow art now in doute
¶ And se now why for þis dar I wel seeyn
Þat ȝit so is þat sche ontrewe be
I can not trowe sche wele wryte a-ȝen
And ȝif þat sche write þow schat sone se
As wheþer sche haþ ony liberte
To comyn a-ȝen or eɫɫ in sum clause
Ȝif sche be lettid sche wele a-sygne a cause
// Þow hast not wrete to hyre syn þat sche went
Ne sche to þe & þis I durste ley
Þere may swich cause be in hire entent
Þat hardily þou wylt þyn seluyn sey
Þat hire abod best is for ȝow twey
Now write to hire þan & þou schat fele sone [le sone corrected]
Asay of alle þere is no more to done
¶ A-corded þey ben to þis conclusioun
And þat a-non þese ilke lordis too
And hastyli sit Troilus a-doun
And royled in herte to & fro
How he may best discryuyn hyre his wo
And to Crisseyde his owene lady dere
He wrot ryȝt þus & seyde as ȝe schul here

LG.HEAD: (189) (Troylus's Letter to Criseyde)
LG.L: // Ryȝt frosche flour whos I haue ben & schal
With-oute part of ellys where seruyse
With herte body lyf lust þouȝt & al
I woful wiȝt in euery vmbele wise
Þat tonge telle or herte may deuyse
As ofte as mater ocupieþ plase
Me recommende on-to ȝoure nobele grace
// Lykyth it ȝow to wetene swete herte
As ȝe wel knowe how longe tyme a-gon
Þat ȝe me lefte in asper peynys smerte
Whan þat ȝe wente of which ȝit but non
Haue I non had but euere werse be-gon
From day to day lyn & so mot dwelle
Wil it ȝow lust of wele & wo myn welle
¶ Which to ȝow with dredful herte drewe
I write as he þat sorwe dryuyth To wryte
Myn wo þat euery our encreseþ newe
Compleynynge as I can or dar endite
And þat defasid is þat may ȝe weiȝte
With Teris whiche þat from mynne eyen reyne
Þat woldyn spekyn ȝif þat þey couþe pleyne

LG.HEAD: (192) (Troilus's Letter to Criseyde, continued.)
LG.L: // Ȝow fyrst be-seche I þat with ȝoure eyen clere
To lokyn on þis lettere 1 that ȝe vn-folde 1 1-1 corrector]
And ouer al þis þat ȝe myn lady dere
Wele vouche-saf þis lettere to beholde
And bi þe cause ek of myne caris colde
Þat sleth myn wit þat ouȝt a-mys me asterte
ffor-ȝeue it me myn owene swete herte
¶ Ȝif ony seruaunt durste or auȝte of ryȝt
Vp-on his lady pitously compleyne
Þanne wene I þat I auȝte ben þat wiȝt
Considerid þis þat ȝe þese moneþis tweyne
Han taried þere ȝe seyde soþ to seyne
But dayes ten ȝe woldyn in heste soiourne
But in to monythis ȝit ȝe not retourne
// But for as meche as me muste nedis like
Al þat ȝow lust I dar not pleyne more
But humili with sorweful sikis I sike
Ȝite wite I myn onreste & myne sorwis sore
ffrom day to day desirynge euere more
To knowe fully ȝif ȝoure wille it were
How ȝe han ferd & don whil ȝe ben þere
¶ Whos wel-fare & ese god encrese
In honour swich þat vpward in degre
It growe al wey so þat it neuere sere
Ryȝt as ȝoure herte ay can ladi fre
Deuyse I preye to god so mote it be
And grante it þat ȝe sone vp-on me rewe
As wisely as I am in alle þynge to ȝow trewe

LG.HEAD: (196) (Troylus's Letter to Criseyde, continued.)
LG.L: ¶ And ȝif ȝow likyth to knowyn of þe fare
Of me whos wo þere may no wiȝt descryue
I can no more but cheste of euery care
At þe writyng of þis lettere I was on lyue
Al redy out myn woful gost to dryue
Whiche I delaye & holde him ȝit in honde
Vp-on þe syȝt of mater of ȝoure sonde
// Myne eyȝyn to I veyn with whiche I se
Of sorweful teris salte aryn waxen well
Myn song in pleynt of myn aduersite
Myn good in-to harm myn ioye ek waxen helle is
Myn myrthe In-to wo I can sey ȝow not ell
But turnyd is for which myn lyf I warie
Euery ioye or ese is in his contrarye
¶ Whiche with ȝoure comynge a-ȝen hom to Troye
Ȝe may redresse & more a þousent siþe
Þan euere I hadde encresyn in me ioye
ffor was þere neuere herte ȝit so blyþe
To haue his lyf as I schal be as swyþe
As I ȝow se / & þow no maner routhe
Remeue ȝow ȝit þynk vp-on ȝoure treuthe
// And ȝif so be myn gylt haue deþ deseruyd
Or if ȝe lust no more vp-on me se
In guerdoun ȝit þat I haue ȝow seruyd
Be-seche I ȝow myn hertis ladi fre
Þat here-vp-on ȝe wolde wryte to me
ffor loue of god myn ryȝte lode sterre
Þat deþ may make an ende of al myn werre

LG.HEAD: (200) (Troylus's Letter to Criseyde, continued.)
LG.L: ¶ Ȝif oþer cause doþ ȝou ouȝt to dwelle
Þat with ȝoure lettere ȝe me reconforte
ffor þow to me ȝoure absence be an helle
With pacience I wele myn wo comporte
And with ȝoure lettere of loue I wil disporte
Now writyth swete let me not compleyne
With hope or deþ delyuere 1 me from this peyne 1 [1-1 by a corrector]
¶ I-wis myn owene dere herte trewe
I wot þan whan ȝe next vp-on me se
So lost haue I myn hele & ek myn hewe
Crisseyde schulde not cunne knowe me
I-wis myn hertis day myn ladi fre
So trustyth ay myn herte to by-holde
Ȝoure beute þat myn silf vn-neþe I holde
// I sey no more al haue I for to sey
To ȝow wel more þan I telle may
But weþer ȝe do me leue oþer deye
I preye god so ȝeue ȝow ryȝt good day
And farwel goodly fayre frossche may
As sche þat lyf or deþ me may comaunde
And to ȝoure hertis pete / ay I me recommaunde
¶ Which hele which þat but ȝe ȝeuyn me
Þe same hele I schal non hele haue
In ȝow lyth whan ȝow lyste þat it so be
Þe day on which me cloþyn schal myn graue
In ȝow myn lyf lyth holly for to saue
Me from desesis from alle peynys smert
And fareþ now wel myne owene swete hert.
// Þis lettere forþ was sent on to Crisseyde
Of wich in effect hire answere was þis
fful pitously sche wrot a-ȝen & seyde
Þat also sone as þat sche myȝte I-wis
Sche wolde come & mende al þat was a-mys
And finally sche wrot & seyde hym þan
Sche wolde come ȝa but sche nyste neuere whan
¶ But in hire lettere made sche sweche festis
Þat wondyr was & swerith sche louyth hym best
Of which he fond but bottemeles behestis
But Troilus þou mayt now est or west
Pypyn in yuy lef / ȝif þat þou lest
Þus goþ þe world god schilde vs from mys-schaunce
And euery wiȝt þat menyth / treuthe a-vaunce
¶ Encresyn gan þe wo from day to nyȝt
Of Troilus for taryinge of crisseyde
And lessyn gan his hope & ek his myȝt
ffor which al doun he in þe bed hym leyde
He net ne drank ne no word he ne seyde
ymaginyng þat sche was vn-kynde
ffor which wel nyh he wex out of his mynde
// Þis drem of which I told haue ek by-fore
May neuere out of his remembraunce
He þouȝte ay wel he hadde his lady lorn
And þat þat Iouys hadde of his puruyaunce
Hym schewid in slep þe signyfiaunce
Of hire ontreuthe & his disauenture
And þat þis boþe was schewid in figure
¶ ffor which for sibile his sustyr he sente
Þat callid was cassaundere al a-boute
And al his drem he tolde hire or he stente
And hire be-souȝte to a-soylyn hym þat doute
Of þe stronge bor with his toschhis stoute
And fynally withinne a lytil stounde
Cassaundere hym gan ryȝt þus expounde
// Sche gan fyrst smyle & seyde o broþer dere
Ȝif þou a soþe of þis desirist to knowe
Þow a fewe / of olde storyis here
To purpos / how þat fortune ouer þrowe
Haþ lordis olde þour which with-inne a þrowe
Þow wel þis forn. schalt knowe & of what kynde
He comyn is as men in bokys fynde
¶ Dyane which þat wroþ was in yre
ffor grekys wolde not hire sacrifise
Þe ensens vp-on hyre auter settyn a fyre
Sche for þat grekys gan hire so dispise
Wrok hire in a wondyr crewel wise
ffor with a bor as gret as oxe in stalle
Sche made vp frete here corn & vynys alle
// To sle þis bor was al þe cuntre reysed
A-mong whiche þere come þis for to se
A mayde on of þis world þe beste I-preysede
And meleagre lord of þat cuntre
He louede so þis frossche mayde fre
Þat with his manhod or he wolde stynt
Þe bor he slow & hire þe hed he sent
// Of whiche as olde bokys tellyn vs
Þere ros a contek & gret enuye
And of þis lord dessendede thidius
Be lyue or olde bokys lye
But how þis Mellager dude dye
Of hire modir wil I ȝow not telle
ffor to longe it were for vs to dwelle
¶ Sche tolde ek how Cithideus or sche stente
On to þe stronge sete of thebes
To cleymyn kyndom of þe cete went
ffor his falawe dan polymites
Of which þe broþer dan Etthiocles
fful wrongfully of thebes held þe strenthe
Þus told sche be proces al on lenthe
// Sche tolde ek how hermoneades a-stert
Whan thedeus slow fifty knyȝtis stoute
Sche tolde ek al þe profecy be herte
And how þat seuene kyngis on a route
Besegede þe cete al a-boute
And of holy serpent & þe welle
And of furies also sche gan hym telle

DIV3.P: [Argument of the 12 Books of Statius's Thebais.]

LG.L: Versus Associat profi thedeus prinnus polimite
Versus Thidea legatum docet incidias-que secundus
Versus Tercius sinoduden canes & vates latitantes
Versus Quartus habet reges in-euntees prelia septem
Versus Mox furie lenne quinto narratur in anguis
¶ Archi-mosi bustum sexto ludi-que leguntur
Dat graios Thebes & vatem septimus Vmbris
Octauo cecidit thedeus spes vita pelasgis
Ypominon nono moritur cum parte-nopea
Fulmine percussus decimo cappanius superatur
Vndecimo [MS. s for o] sese perimunt per vulnera fratres
Argina flentem narrat duodenus & ignem
// Of arichmoure brenynge & þe pleyes
And how anphiorax fel þour grounde
How Tideus was slayn lord of Argeys
And how ypomidoun with blody wounde
And parthonope in litil stounde
Ben slayn & how cappaneus þe proude
With þondirdent was slayne & cryede loude
¶ Sche gan hym ek tellyn how eyþer broþer
Ethiocles & pollinute also
At a scharmoth eche of hem slow oþer
And of arthmes wepynge & hire wo
And how þe toun was brend sche tolde hym þo
And so dissendiþ he doun from gestis olde
To Diomede & þus sche spak & tolde
// Þis ilke bor be-tokenyth Diomede
Thedeus sone þat doun dissendid is
ffrom meliagre þat made þe bor to blede
And þyn lady where-so sche be I-wys
Þis Diomede hire herte haþ & sche his
Wepe ȝif þou wilt or lef / for out of doute
Þis diomede is inne & þow art oute
¶ Þow seyst not soþ quod he þou sercheresse
Wyþ al þyn false gost of professye
Þow wenyst to be a gret deuyneresse
Now sest not þis fool of fantasye
Paynyth hire on ladiis for to lye
A-woy quod he þere iouus ȝeue þe sorwe
Þow schalt ben fals parauntyr er to morwe
¶ As wel þow myȝtist lyen on altest
Þat was of criaturis but men lye
Þat ewere were þe kyndest & þe best
Þat whan hire hosbande was in iupardie
To deye hym self But ȝif sche wolde deye
Sche ches deþ & ek to gon to helle
And starf a-non as vs þe bokys telle
¶ Cassaundere goþ / & he for crewel herte
ffor-ȝat he wo for angir of hire speche
And from his bed al sodeynly he sterte
As þow hym al hol hym hadde mad a leche
And day be day he gan enquere & seche
A soþ of his wit al his fulle cure
And þus he dryuyth forth his auenture
FOrtune þat with permutacioun
His wille haþ as it is here knyttid
Be puruyaunce & dispocicioun
Of heye ioue as regnes schal be kyttid
ffor folk in folk or whan þey schal ben flittid
Can pulle awoy þe federis bryȝte of troye
ffrom day to day til þey be in were of ioye
A-mong al þis þe fyn of þe parodye
Of ector gan aprochyn wondir blyue
Þe face wolde his soule schulde on-bodye
And schape hadde a mene it out to dryue
Aȝens whiche face hym helpyth not to stryue
But on a day to fyȝtyn gan he wynde
At þe whiche he cauȝte his lyuys ende
¶ ffor which me þynkeþ euery maner wiȝt
Þat hancory harmys auȝte to biwayle
Þe day of hym þat was so nobel a knyȝt
ffor as he drow a knyȝt be þe auentayle
On-war of his Achilles þour þe mayle
Lenne þour þe body gan hym for to ryue
And þus þis worþi knyȝt was brouȝt of lyue
¶ ffor which as olde bokys tellyn vs
Was mad swich wo þat tonge may not telle
And namely þe sorwyn of troilus
Þat next him was of worþinesse þe welle
And in þis wo gan Troilus to dwelle
Þat what for sorwe & loue & for vnrest
fful oft [t, corrector] on day he bad his herte brest
¶ But neuer-þe-les þow he gan hym self dispaire
And drede þat his lady was vn-trewe
Ȝit in his herte gan repayre
And as þese loueris don he souȝte anewe
To gete aȝen Crisseyde bryȝt of hewe
And in his herte he wente hire excusynge
Þat Calcas causede al hire tarying
¶ And ofte tyme he was in purpos gret
Hym selue lyk a pilgrym to disgise
To sen hire but he may not counterefete
To ben ouknowe of folk þat were wyse
Ne fynde excuse aryȝt þat may suffyse
Ȝif he a-mong þe grekys knowe were
¶ ffor whiche he wepte ful ofte manye a tere
To hire he wrot ful ofte tyme al newe
fful pitously he lefte not for þe slouthe
Be-sechyng hire þat syn þat he was trewe
Þat sche wolde come ageyn & holde hyre trouthe
ffor whiche crisseyde vp-on a day for routhe
I tok it so touchynge al þis matere
Wrot hym a-geyn & seyde as ȝe may here

LG.HEAD: (228) (Criseyde's Letter to Troylus)
LG.L: Cupidis sone en-saumpele of godly-hede
O swerd of knythod ground of gentilles
How myȝte a wyȝt in turnement & in drede
And heleles ȝow sende ȝit gladnesse
I herde telle in seek & in distresse
Syn ȝe with me / ne I with ȝow may dele
Ȝow noþer sende / .I. may herte ne hele
¶ Ȝoure letteris of paper ful I-peynted
Conseyuyd haþ myn hertis pete
I haue ek sen with terys al depeyntid
Ȝoure lettere & how þat ȝe requeryn me
To come a-geyn whiche may not 1 ȝet be 1 [1-1 corrector]
But whi lest þis lettere fonde were
Non menoioun make I now for fere

LG.HEAD: (230) (Criseyde's Letter continued)
LG.L: // Greuous to me god wot is ȝoure vnrest
Ȝoure haste & at þe goddis ordenaunce
It semyth not ȝe takyn it for þe beste
Nor oþer þyng is in ȝoure remembr[a]unce
As þynkyþ me but only ȝoure plesaunce
But beþ not wroþ & þat I ȝow be-seche
ffor þat I tarie is al for wekede speche
¶ ffor I haue herd wel more þan I wende
Touchinge vs to how þyngis han I-stounde
Whiche I schal with dishomblynge a-mende
And be not wroþ I haue ek vndirstonde
How ȝe ne don but holdyn me in honde
But now nofors I can not in ȝow gesse
But alle treuthe & al gentillesse
// Come I wolde But ȝit in swich disioynt
I stonde as now but what ȝer or what day
Þat þis schal ben þat can I not a-poynt
But in effect I prey ȝow as I may
Of ȝoure goode & of ȝoure frenschep ay
But trewely whil þat myn lyf may dure
As for a frend ȝe may en me assure
¶ Ȝit preye I ȝow on euyl ȝe ne take
Þat it is schort whiche þat I to ȝow wryȝte
I dar not þere I am wel letteris make
Ne neuere ȝit ne couþe wel endite
Ek gret effectis men write in space lite
Þe centence is al & not þe letterys spase
And farith now wel god haue ȝow in his grace
¶ Troylus þis lettere þouȝte al strong
Whan he it sey & sorwefully he sight
Hym þouȝte it lik a kalandis of chung
But fynnally he ful ne trowe myȝte
Þat sche ne wolde holde hym þat sche hyȝt
ffor which with euelle wil luste hym to leue
Þat louyȝt wel in swich cas þow hym greue
// But neuer-þe-les men seyn at þe last
ffor ony þyng men schal þe soþe se
And siche be-tyd & þat also fast
Þat Troilus wel vndirstant þat sche
Nas not so kynde as þat hire auȝte to be
And finally he wot now out of doute
Þat al is lost þat he haþ ben a-boute
¶ Stod on a day in his malencoly
Þis Troilus & ine suspeciounne
Of hire for whom he wende for to deye
And so be-fel þat þour troye toune
As was þe gise was boryn vp & dounne
A naue of cotearmure as seyth þe storye
Be-fore Deiphebe in signe of his victorye
// Þe whiche cote as tellyth lollyus
Deyphebe it hadde I-rent from diomede
Þe same day & whan þis Troilus
It saw he gan to takyn of it hede
Auysynge of þe lenthe & of þe brede
And al þe werk but as he gan beholde
fful sodeynleche his herte be-gan to colde
¶ As he þat on þe coler fond with-inne
A broche þat he ȝaf þat morwe
Þat sche from troye muste nedis twynne
In remembraunce of hym & of his sorwe
And sche hym ledde a-ȝen hire feþ to borwe
To kepyn it ay but now ful wel he wiste
His lady was no lengere on to triste
¶ He goþ hym hom & gan ful sone sende
ffor Pandarus & al þis newe chaunce
And of þis broche he told hym word & ende
Compleynynge of his hertis varyaunce
His longe loue his trouthe & his penaunce
And aftyr day with-oute wordis more
fful faste he cryede his reste hym to restore
// Þanne spak he þus o lady bryȝt Crisseyde
Where is ȝoure fayth & where is ȝoure beheste
Where is ȝoure loue where is ȝoure trouthe he seyde
Of diamede haue now al þis feste
Allas I wolde a trowed at þe leste
Þat syn ȝe nolde in [in corrected] trouthe to me stonde
Þat ȝe þus nolde haue holdyn me in honde
¶ Who schal now trowe on ony oþis mo
Allas I neuere wolde han wend or þis
Þat ȝe Cresseide wolde a chaunged so
No but I hadde gilt & don a-mys
So crewel wende I not ȝoure hert had be I-wis
To sle me þus allas ȝoure name of trouthe
Is [s corrected] now fordon & þat is al myn routhe
// Was þere non oþer broche ȝow leste lete
To feffe [ffe corrected] with ȝoure newe loue qud he
But þat ilke broche þat I with terys wete
Ȝow ȝaf as for a remembraunce of me
Non oþer cause allas ne haddyn ȝe
But for dispit & ek for þat ment
At vttyrly to schewyn ȝoure entent
¶ Þour whiche I se þat clene out of ȝoure mynde
Ȝe han me cast & I ne can ne may
ffor al þis world with-inne myn herte fynde
To vn-loue ȝow a quarter of a day
In cursede tyme I born was weyleaway
Þat ȝe þat don me al þis wo endure
Ȝit loue I ȝow best of ony creature

DIV3.P: [Leaves 127-131, the end of Troylus and the beginning of the Canterbury Tales, have been cut out of this Cambridge MS., Gg. 4. 27.]
